story:
Globally significant wilderness forests are under renewed threat in Tasmania – help us keep them safe. The new Australian government is threatening to open up World Heritage listed forests for logging and to scuttle plans for further protection. 

Our group of high profile forest defenders have established a forest hub in Tasmania’s capital city, Hobart, where we can work collaboratively. Staunch campaigners Miranda Gibson of Still Wild Still Threatened, Peg Putt of Markets for Change, and Jenny Weber, Paul Kimbell, Jaque Ashworth and Ali Alishah of Huon Valley Environment Centre appeal for donations to pay the rent for this office space.

Funds raised will pay 4 months’ rent and internet.

We have the passion and commitment to confront the ongoing threats and tragic destruction of Tasmania’s magnificent wild forests. We volunteer our time and energy. We need financial assistance to maintain the hub as we take on well-resourced logging corporations.

Alongside the rising threat to open up World Heritage forests to the chainsaws sit new plans to burn our loved native forests for electricity or trash them to create biofuels. Sarawak logging cartel Ta Ann is entrenched here, receiving wood from high conservation value forests and selling it as eco-wood in international markets. Large, well-funded conservation groups have done an about-face to support this dubious company. They have backed off to merely watching biomass plans that will revitalise industrial clearfell logging.

Between us we work all aspects of this vital campaign, from deep in the threatened forests to dialogue with overseas markets and investors in their high rise offices.

  • Peg is one of the elders of the environment movement in Australia, previous Parliamentary leader of the Tasmanian Greens and now an international advocate on forests and climate who works the markets. She is listed on the Tasmanian Honour Roll of Women for services to the environment.
  • Jenny is a full time forest activist who earned the inaugural Bob Brown Foundation award for Environmentalist of the Year in 2012 for her strong stand and unwavering dedication in the face of extreme local hostility. She advocates from the grass roots with a regional environment centre in Tasmania through to markets and solidarity with Sarawak.
  • Miranda entranced the world from the Observer Tree with her record-breaking 457 day tree sit that stalled logging of world heritage value forests and also earned her a Bob Brown Foundation award as Environmental Young Achiever 2012.
  • Paul is a design and film making wizard who takes messages from the forests to the globe. His design work, for The Last Stand’s markets action - a Harvey Norman QR Code Action - was a finalist in the Memefest International Awards for Socially Responsive Communication and Art.
  • Jacque is a dedicated activist with art, music and organising at her core.
  • Ali is a forest advocate and human rights defender. He spent three months in jail for protests against Ta Ann and continues the campaign.

Above: Peg Putt

Above: Jenny Weber

Above: Miranda Gibson



Above: Paul Kimbell

Above: Jacque Ashworth

Above: Ali Alishah

More Ways You Can Help

If you don’t have any money to support the hub, there are other ways you can help our forest campaigns.

Sign our cyber campaign's
Take action online for Tasmania's forest protection.

Say No to a Biomassacre!
Join us in telling fuel and electricity companies to rule out selling bioenergy that comes from trashing Australia's native forests. Click here

Dob in Ta Ann for selling Tasmanian forest destruction!
One of Malaysia's biggest wood cartels is still selling timber from the ongoing destruction of Tasmania's forests, including old growth and threatened species habitat, help us inform customers that this timber cannot be accepted as "eco-friendly” plywood on the international market. Click here


And that’s all there is to it.

Tasmanian Forest Campaign Hub
Location: Hobart, Australia

story:
Reforestation of Coffee Trees

The farmers of the world have a difficult job. Their arduous work provides important resources for humanity. But more and more, farmers have been receiving less and less, with the percentage of profits going directly into their pockets at an all time low. And then Nature happens.  Leaf rust, a debilitating fungus that infects plants, has devastated coffee trees in Latin America. Coffee farmers in Haiti are now in an even more difficult position. The leaf rust has gotten so bad that reforestation is now the best option to keep the Haitian coffee trade afloat. But this means planting thousands of new trees that take three years to mature and produce market quality beans.  Cafe Kreyol, has started a tree-planting program that allows sponsors to participate financially in the reforestation process.

The Impact

A network of farmers in Haiti directly profit from your contributions.  Farmers operate based on a direct trade model where the middle man is cut out entirely.  Coffee is sold to the folks at Cafe Kreyol, who then roast and distribute the coffee. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your contribution is greatly appreciated. We host events and love seeing new people who are interested in our mission!

story:
The Neotropics harbours almost 50% of amphibian species. Yet high levels of deforestation occur due to logging, agriculture and mining. This project will be undertaken in the buffer zone of the Manu National Park, in the Peruvian Amazon, this is one of the most biodiverse places on the planet but still faces threats from illegal logging and unsustainable agriculture.

The project will focus on three frog species: The Manu Poison Frog (Ameerega macero), the Three-Striped Rocket Frog (Allobates trilineatus) and it sister species Allobates conspicuus.

Ameerega macero has been identified as likely to be threatened and A.conspicuus is listed as Data Deficient on the IUCN red list, as no information is known about its ecology and habitat requirements and there is still some contention regarding whether A.conspicuus is a separate species to A. trilineatus.

The main objectives of this project are to a) estimate the populations of A. Macero in the three main habitat types. b) Estimate population sizes and compare habitat selection and ecology of sympatric sister species: Allobates conspicuus and Allobates trilineatus.

This project will provide vital information about the ecology and habitat of these species, increase understanding of the threats to these frogs and thus improve conservation.

£700 will pay for a Peruvian university student to be employed as a field assistant giving them an incredible opportunity to learn about their local species and conservation and provide them with valuable experience that will help kick start their career. Ultimately the conservation of the Peruvian Amazon lies in the hands of the local people, not international researchers, so involving local people in conservation research is vital.

The remaining funds will contribute to the cost of essential equipment.

This project is being undertaken in collaboration with the crees foundation, a small peruvian not for profit organisation that runs conservation research and sustainable development initiatives in Manu. For more information about crees and their opportunities for researchers, volunteers, interns and tourists, visit www.crees-manu.org

story:
We urgently need your help to save Cambodia's wildlife! Cambodia is home to a wide array of wildlife, however species populations are in rapid decline as a result of hunting, the illegal trade in wildlife, logging and massive habitat loss.

Why we need your help

Phnom Kulen National Park (PKNP) is a 39,500ha protected area 40km north of Siem Reap. It is also Cambodia's most sacred mountain and a vital source of water for the region. However, the alarming rate of deforestation poses a huge threat to PKNP, wildlife and the surrounding communities. It is estimated that PKNP has less than 25% of its original forest cover left. As detailed biological surveys have not been undertaken to date, it is unknown what effect this has had on wild animal populations. In PKNP, large mammals such as Asian Elephants and Tigers are already locally extinct.

Preliminary research from previous years has indicated PKNP may harbour endangered species  such as sun bears, binturong, pileated gibbons and silvered langurs. It is also home to threatened tortoises, snakes, northern pig-tailed macaques, slow loris and the Lesser Adjutant stork. The presence of some of Cambodia's most threatened primate taxa warrants greater study and protection. Unless urgent conservation action is taken soon these species will continue to decline.

According to the IUCN Red List of threatened primates, over 70% of Asian primates (including all gibbon species) are are threatened with extinction. Out of all primate range countries, Cambodia ranks fifth with the greatest percent of threatened primate species.There is a clear lack of information on the distribution and densities of remaining wildlife in PKNP, especially on primate populations.Vital data for species study and conservation is necessary and as the area is so understudied, there is even the possibility of discovering new species. 

More exact knowledge and capacity building is required to assist in directing long term effective community work to the relevant areas of the park as well as the overall protection of the park's natural resources. 

The impact

We have been through the rigorous application process for the Mohamed Bin Zayed Species Conservation Fund. Our organisation ISAC (Integrated Solutions Asia Cooperation) an NGO, was awarded partial funding but we need your help to support our goals. With your help we aim to conduct critically important biological surveys in PKNP and surrounding areas over a 6 month period. ISAC and affiliated partners - Angkor Centre for Conservation of Biodiversity (ACCB) and the Archaeology Development Foundation (ADF) will work together to implement comprehensive and scientifically rigorous surveys. In addition, we aim to assist in developing long term strategies for communities within the park to help them manage their natural resources more sustainably.

Surveys will be conducted using methodologies such as transect walks, establishing listening posts (for gibbons), motion activated cameras (camera traps), night spotting for mammals, mist-netting for bats and GPS habitat mapping. Local counterparts will be provided with much needed capacity building and training in field methodologies and monitoring, thus enabling them to contribute towards future conservation and community work. 

The results of these surveys will be directly linked to facilitating community development within the park and ensuring stable wildlife populations. Our data will help target the needs for alternative livelihood programs in the surrounding communities and identify further conservation efforts needed to protect the park's natural resources. 

Where your contribution will go

You can help us conserve Cambodia's amazing wildlife by donating whatever you can - no donation is too small, every dollar is a step closer to reaching our goal. Your contribution will directly support the operational costs of conducting the surveys, carrying out training and maintaining equipment. 

All contributors will receive access to our Flickr account where our camera trap pictures can be instantly accessed. Additionally, contributors will receive an email copy of our Biodiversity report of PKNP with acknowledgement in the credits. 

Please spread the word about our campaign and share this page with your friends and family. With your help and donations, we can take significant steps to ensure a future for Cambodia's remarkable wildlife.

story:
WHERE WERE YOU WHEN GOOGLE,

        APPLE OR FACEBOOK WENT PUBLIC?

 

         DID YOU GET AN OPPORTUNITY

    TO INVEST BEFORE THEY WENT PUBLIC?

          

    HERE'S YOUR CHANCE TO  

      GET IN & NOT MISS OUT!

My name is George Spears, CEO of ENRG-X and I am an entrepreneur having owned/operated successful businesses across the last 25years. (Pyramid Paging, Blimpie, Nemo's Seafood)

Going "Green" has become a hot topic over the last decade and global warming has finally come to the forefront as being recognized as a problem that must addressed sooner than later.  We have noticed the damaging effects that technology and our past generations lifestyles and decisions have had on our air, land and water quality.ENRG-X has a solution that will provide a major impact in reversing this problem. We can eliminate the landfills, lessen carbon emissions, and keep our natural water resources and the environment clean. Our patented pyrolisis system can do just that! 

We have been successful at raising almost $200,000 through friends and family. Now we are branching out the public to raise our final $100,000 which will allow us to take our company public. Through our Initial Public Offering (IPO) we will be able to raise $60M which will allow us to build the plant.

 

                         What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $100,000 more to take the company public. We have engaged a company that is primed to get the ball rolling.

We are offering those investing:

$1-$2,500 earns 1 share/dollar

$2,501-$5,000 earns 2 shares/dollar

$5,001 -$10,000 earns 3 shares/dollar

$10,001+ earns 3 shares/dollar and a seat on our board of directors

We are excited about how far we've come! Now you can be one of those contributors who is directly responsiple for leaving the world better off than when they've received it! IMAGINE THAT! 

 

                                       The Impact

Just imagine:

  • Thousands of acres of land being used by landfills toxifying our land and our water.
  • The invisible pollutants that we inhale from the emissions of the other  plants that are active.
  • The pollutants from our environment causing the increase in various debilitating & life threatening health conditions directly related to toxicity.

All of which will be positively impacted by our proposed solution! 

We boast a rate of 2-5% waste that is observed from our process. NO air pollution. NO ground Contamination. The plant is self reliant providing our own water, heat and electricity to operate. Our proprietary design will recycle all forms of trash and turn it into a reusable energy; such as electricity, bio-fuels, ink by-products, asphalt and charcoal briquettes.

Another hot topic in the world that we will impact is JOBS! We have the ability to create about 100 new jobs at our facility. Because of our lower cost and our ability to receive more trash, our vendors will be able to get more business, hire more people and ultimately impact our local economy. 

Have you heard of any other plant that can do that?! I hadn't either and you can be directly responsible for one that does!  HELP US MAKE A DIFFERENCE!

 

                          Other Ways You Can Help

            DON'T HAVE THE MONEY TO FINANCIALLY CONTRIBUTE?

If you can't contribute financially at this time, there are other ways that you can help out!

Tell your friends, family or even your enemies!

You can post our link onto your Facebook, Pinterest, Twitter, Google, LinkedIn, Meet Me pages.

story:
We will open a Pop-Up Repair shop in Inwood, Manhattan, and for four weeks we will see what people want fixed, and whether we can fix it! The shop is the pilot program for a larger project aimed at breaking the cycle of use-and-discard consumer goods.

The shop will be staffed by theatre artisans. In theatre, we make things by hand, one at a time. We will apply these skills to real-world challenges - the broken stuff that would otherwise be thrown away. As designers, technicians, and craftsmen, Pop-up Repair is a chance to effect social change not only with the theatre we make, but with the way we make theatre - by hand.

We will be focussing on household objects - lamps, chairs, kitchen stuff, small electronics, bags, etc. But we will do our best on anything you bring in (no house calls in this first phase). The first few customers will be "pay what you will," and from then on we will charge a reasonable fee (this is part of the experiment, to learn whether and how much people will pay). Any money we earn from the shop will go into starting the next phase of the project - more on that later!

Your Indiegogo dollars will get us started by paying for: a workspace for 4 weeks, payment for the theatre artisans/repair wizards, materials to work with, and other basic supplies.

Please come by the shop - and bring your broken stuff!

story:
No More Throw-away Plastic

GOOD2GO is a company of like-minded individuals, based on St. Maarten in the north east Caribbean and the only specialist supplier of sustainable packaging and disposable tableware in the region.  What unites this small, energetic team is a heartfelt commitment to ridding the islands of single-use plastic products and replacing them with innovative and practical alternatives; products made from corn, sugar cane, bamboo and palm leaves, all of which break down in our natural environment.

 

The people at GOOD2GO, like many others in the region, are thoroughly sick of seeing the shameful tide of plastic that is sweeping through their beautiful islands, ruining the oceans and beaches and killing wildlife.  GOOD2GO believes that the harmful effects of plastic pollution in the environment cannot be overstated and they are determined to rid the Caribbean of throw-away plastic products; from packaging, food containers and beverage bottles, through to bags, cups, plates, trays and cutlery. 

 

Thankfully, many enlightened  businesses, and some government departments, are working with GOOD2GO to move away from ‘nasty plastic’.   It’s comforting to know that in this plastic-filled world, people everywhere are turning to biodegradable alternatives and becoming more aware of how an individual’s action, no matter how small, really can make a contribution to the environment. 

GOOD2GO disposables come from nature and go back to nature:

Disposables should be disposable, right?  At GOOD2GO we believe that it’s insane to make a single-use item from a material that lasts for hundreds or even thousands of years.  But that is exactly the situation with petrochemical plastics.  GOOD2GO products are made from plants, like corn, sugar cane waste or fallen leaves, and go back to nature after they are disposed of.  They are truly disposable.   From trash bags to a wide variety of food and beverage containers, GOOD2GO supplies them all.

 

GOOD2GO needs a delivery truck: 

Our poor little old car just couldn’t take the pressure.  Despite our efforts to keep it on the road and having poured far too much money into keeping it going, it finally gave up the ghost one Saturday morning in late June.  A very dear friend and supporter of GOOD2GO offered us his pick-up truck but we need the funds to buy it.  It’s in great condition and is perfect for our needs.  If we don’t reach our target we’ll still buy the truck but it will take us longer.  If we receive more than our target we’ll put the money towards the purchase of a hard top for the pick-up to protect our wonderful products from the harsh tropical sun and regular tropical downpours.   Some of the funds raised will pay to have the pick-up adorned with the GOOD2GO logo and other information (like your name if you pledge more than $100) so more people get to know about GOOD2GO.

 

Other ways you can help GOOD2GO to reach our target: 

Please share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter.  Check out the ‘share’ tools on the IndieGOGO website.


It’s good to know we’re GOOD2GO!
story_txt:
No More Throw-away Plastic

GOOD2GO is a company of like-minded individuals, based on St. Maarten in the north east Caribbean and the only specialist supplier
of sustainable packaging and disposable tableware in the region.  What unites this small, energetic team is a heartfelt
commitment to ridding the islands of single-use plastic products and replacing
them with innovative and practical alternatives; products made from corn, sugar
cane, bamboo and palm leaves, all of which break down in our natural
environment.
 
The people at GOOD2GO, like many others in the region,
are thoroughly sick of seeing the shameful tide of plastic that is sweeping
through their beautiful islands, ruining the oceans and beaches and killing
wildlife.  GOOD2GO believes that the harmful effects
of plastic pollution in the environment cannot be overstated and they are
determined to rid the Caribbean of throw-away plastic products; from packaging,
food containers and beverage bottles, through to bags, cups, plates, trays and
cutlery. 

 
Thankfully, many
enlightened  businesses, and some government
departments, are working with GOOD2GO to move away from ‘nasty plastic’.   It’s
comforting to know that in this plastic-filled world, people everywhere are
turning to biodegradable alternatives and becoming more aware of how an
individual’s action, no matter how small, really can make a contribution to the
environment. 




GOOD2GO disposables come from nature and go
back to nature: 
Disposables
should be disposable, right?  At GOOD2GO we believe that it’s insane to make a single-use item from a material
that lasts for hundreds or even thousands of years.  But that is exactly the situation with
petrochemical plastics.  GOOD2GO products are made from plants, like corn, sugar cane waste or fallen
leaves, and go back to nature after they are disposed of.  They are truly disposable.   From trash bags to a wide variety of food and
beverage containers, GOOD2GO supplies
them all.
 
GOOD2GO needs a delivery truck: 

Our poor little old car just couldn’t take the pressure.  Despite our efforts to keep it on the road
and having poured far too much money into keeping it going, it finally gave up
the ghost one Saturday morning in late June. 
A very dear friend and supporter of GOOD2GO offered us his pick-up truck but
we need the funds to buy it.  It’s in
great condition and is perfect for our needs. 
If we don’t reach our target we’ll still buy the truck but it will take
us longer.  If we receive more than our
target we’ll put the money towards the purchase of a hard top for the pick-up
to protect our wonderful products from the harsh tropical sun and regular
tropical downpours.   Some of the funds raised will pay to have the pick-up
adorned with the GOOD2GO logo
and other information (like your name if you pledge more than $100) so more
people get to know about GOOD2GO.
 
Other ways you can help GOOD2GO to reach our
target:  
Please share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter.  Check out the ‘share’ tools on the IndieGOGO
website.


It’s good to know we’re GOOD2GO!

story:
Endorsements

We're honored to count North Vancouver Mayor Darrell Mussatto as a backer. Show your support today.

We would also like to thank the following organizations for their support:

Burnaby School District

Burnaby Youth Sustainability Network

Metro Vancouver (Youth4Action Program)

The Green Events Program: Spreading Sustainability

I'm Tomas, a Grade 10 student in Burnaby, BC, and I created the Green Events Program to spread the practice of "Reduce before recycle."

My roots in sustainability were planted when I was a small child, but my passion started just two years ago. Since then, I have been immersing myself in the world of environmental justice. I wanted to share with my peers what I believe deep down: that we cannot keep tossing everything into landfills for the sake of convenience. 

On my own, I set out to educate the people around me in responsible waste management. For those as passionate as me, I want to make it easier for them to take the lead. And so, with the Green Events Program, I begin my journey to help others take care of our earth. I’m very excited to now have Jacqueline, the Chair of the Burnaby Youth Sustainability Network, on the team!

The Green Events Program is designed so that students reduce waste at their school events by putting in place a simple waste management system and a reusable event materials library. The library is an inventory of materials (dinnerware, utensils, decorations, etc.) that are frequently used at school functions (banquets, breakfasts, club meetings, etc.).

Here's a look at how the program works at one of our school events:


Since the program's launch at my school, Alpha Secondary, we've seen more than 2500 uses of knives, forks and plates. We now want to empower more youth leaders at other schools and spread the program across the region and beyond... with your help!

What We Need

We need $5000 dollars in order to expand to seven more schools at just over $700 per set of 250 plates, forks, and knives (at retail price). We also plan to look to hotels and restaurants to donate their old inventory.

  • A $40 donation will pay for 12 sets of plates, forks and knives at retail price, and put $2 towards our field trip and a daylong workshop for new Green Events Program ambassadors. 
  • A $25 donation will pay for 7 sets and put $2.50 towards our field trip and our workshop for new Green Events Program ambassadors.

Giving schools a library to work with helps speed up the change we want to see. If we don't provide an initial set of plates and utensils, students at each school would have to spend some time fundraising, delaying the adoption of the program.

The funds will also help us take student leaders on a field trip to the Vancouver Landfill and a composting facility to see where all our waste ends up.

We will also hold a daylong workshop to train students some essential skills:

  • how to do a waste audit of school events
  • how to measure impact of the program
  • how to spread adoption of Reduce before Recycle

If we raise 50% of our goal, we will qualify for matching funds from Ashoka Canada (up to $2,500). That means if we raise the full $5,000 through this campaign, we could have a total of $7,500 to work with, allowing us to fund 10 schools instead of 7.

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will still fund as many schools as we can, depending on the amount of money we raise.

What You Get

We have some very exciting perks for you and we encourage you to give generously.

  • FOR YOUTH: If you donate $15/$20, you will be able to get a ticket for a Metro Vancouver student to go to a youth empowerment workshop that will be hosted by us together with Ashoka Canada. The workshop will guide youth on how to start their own social change and sustainability projects and how to crowdfund for support.
  • FOR ADULTS: If you donate $40, you will get 60 free minutes that you can use to get around Vancouver in Car2Go’s Smart Cars. New members of Car2Go will even get their registration fee waived! (This perk is valued at $58.) You will get this perk almost immediately so you can use the free minutes right away.
  • FOR CHAMPIONS: When you donate at the $150 level, we will come facilitate a one hour workshop or give a talk at an appropriate event, venue, school, or business in the Lower Mainland.
  • FOR SUPERHEROES: If you donate $750, you will pay for 250 sets of plates, forks, knives for one school. That’s a full set! You will get a special thank you and recognition . You will be kept up to date on the school’s Green Events Program progress!

The Impact

The Green Events Program is a simple yet effective way to help schools in your neighbourhood become more sustainable. It instills the value of being environmentally conscious not just at sustainability-focused events, but at all events in the school and community.


Your contributions will allow us to empower youth ambassadors and organizers who want to create change, but our impact extends to all the students and staff who will use reusable plates and cutlery. Making it happen is the first step towards making it a norm.


I was thrilled when Tomas approached me with his idea of the Green Events Program. An earlier visit to the Vancouver Landfill had really impacted me, making me realize just how much waste is thrown “out of sight and out of mind”, off the curb to some mystical land with no visible consequences. The mindset about waste needs to change. Fortunately, there are a lot of creative people who are just as passionate as we are, and I believe that we can reach out with this venture to empower changemakers everywhere. ~ Jacqueline Shen

Other Ways You Can Help

As important as it is for us to get funds, it’s equally important to have schools that support us. If you're a teacher, administrator or a student who would like to see the program started at your school, please message us.

It’s also important for us to get in contact with people and businesses that have knowledge in the area of sustainable events. We ask that you share our campaign, tell friends and family, and email us at involved@greeneventsprogram.com if you have any ideas or questions you’d like to share with us!

Any media inquiries should be directed to media@greeneventsprogram.com

Making it happen is the first step towards making it a norm.


I was thrilled when Tomas approached me with his idea of the Green Events Program. An earlier visit to the Vancouver Landfill had really impacted me, making me realize just how much waste is thrown “out of sight and out of mind”, off the curb to some mystical land with no visible consequences. The mindset about waste needs to change. Fortunately, there are a lot of creative people who are just as passionate as we are, and I believe that we can reach out with this venture to empower changemakers everywhere. ~ Jacqueline Shen




Other Ways You Can Help
As important as it is for us to get funds, it’s equally important to have schools that support us. If you're a teacher, administrator or a student who would like to see the program started at your school, please message us.

It’s also important for us to get in contact with people and businesses that have knowledge in the area of sustainable events. We ask that you share our campaign, tell friends and family, and email us at involved@greeneventsprogram.com if you have any ideas or questions you’d like to share with us!

story:
Help break the cycle of poverty and environmental degradation by educating the indigenous Mayan children of Comalapa, Guatemala.

 
I am writing this just a few weeks after the completion of the construction of a sustainable home for an indigenous Mayan family in Comalapa, Guatemala. A total of 96 people, including members of the Earthship Biotecture Crew, Long Way Home Team, local Guatemalans, and 65 volunteers from countries including Austraila, New Zealand, Brazil, Italy, France, Germany, Denmark, England, The Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, South Africa, Mexico, Canada, and the United States, worked together in unison to build a 'Simple Survival Pod' Earthship for Long Way Home's Guatemalan Foreman, Romeo Apen and his family. In three weeks time, the home was complete and ready for its finishing touches so that Apens could move into their new home. Not only will Romeo's home collect and filter its own rainwater and run on solar energy, it will also use and reuse water a total of four times, which is used to grow food in an indoor greenhouse.
 
 
The experience can only be described with words such as "amazing", "incredible", "magical", and "heart-warming," and the project clearly demonstrated the power that is possible when people come together for a unifying cause. 
 
All of this began by a small group of individuals working together with Earthship Biotecture and Long Way Home to help raise donations for a worthy and charitable cause: Bottle Buildings and Bamboo Bicycles in Guatemala. Through this campaign with indiegogo , a total of $4,200USD was raised in one month to help secure the necessary funds to complete the construction of the home for Romeo and his family. The support and interest we received for this campaign from family, friends, and many other interested parties, was nothing short of awe-inspiring.
 

Today, the cause continues with The Long Way Home and the children of Guatemala...

 
 
 
After spending three weeks in Comalapa, I began to realize how the work Long Way Home does is vitally important to Compala, Guatemala. Long Way Home Team are addressing very real issues that not only affect Guatemala and other Latin America countries, but countries around the world, there is an over-abundance of waste and trash that goes completely unchecked. This later ends up in our streets, gardens, playgrounds or, even worse, our lakes, streams, and groundwater where many people in countries like Guatemala get their drinking water.
 
The problem is compounded in places like Guatemala where there is almost no infrastructure for recycling or even basic waste disposal. Most of the garbage goes directly into the street or, as previously mentioned, into a lake or stream. 
 
So what do we do about what seems to be an ever-increasing problem with no end? 

Although there are no perfect solutions at the moment, Long Way Home Team are making serious head way on some of the problems that not only affect Guatemalans, but affect us all.  

Thus far, Long Way Home has collected and used 262 tons of garbage for building projects in Comalapa, Guatemala. Their primary project is a sustainable school which, in addition to the standard curriculum, currently teaches 46 indigenous children Kaqchikel (the traditional local Mayan dialect), traditional Mayan culture, English and environmental stewardship. The school will teach 350 students when the school is complete. 

Additionally, they have paid upwards of $110,000USD in salary to local Guatemalan workers employed for sustainable projects in Comalapa. These community members are being trained to build sustainable homes and they can use these skills to start their own alternative building business. 

Because of my great admiration for what the Long Way Home is doing, I have decided to stay in Comalapa and do what I can to help. 

 

Now...I need your help! :)

 

Who is The Long Way Home?

Long Way Home was founded in 2004 when Mateo Paneitz finished his Peace Corps service and realized his work in the small town of San Juan Comalapa, Guatemala was not done. He brought together a group of dedicated activists who were interested in helping this community change their future. Mateo’s goal was to address two primary issues: the lack of appropriate waste management strategies; and the lack of educational and employment opportunities for local, indigenous youth. His team came up with a unique solution that would tackle both issues simultaneously: build a primary and vocational facility out of waste materials!

Background

The Técnico Maya school needs funding, and the dedicated staff and faculty at the school have donated time and money to provide a multicultural education at a low cost to students, only charging a nominal fee and providing scholarships for those who cannot afford to pay. All students are required to bring plastic bottles filled with trash each week as part of their "tuition."
  

The Impact

Sustainability

The Vocational School will provide a venue for young Comalapans to learn such trades as masonry, carpentry and bicycle repair. The workshops in the school will serve as hands-on classrooms, and will be viable businesses where the students will work as apprentices to professionals in each field. The income generated by the workshops will pay the teachers’ salaries, helping the school near its goal of financial sustainability. The school plans include an area where students can learn alternative energy production. Once the school is successfully producing alternative fuels, the sale of fuel will provide additional funding for the institution.

Interns and volunteers from around the world who come to work at the Técnico Maya Vocational School will also contribute to the financial sustainability of the project. The fee that each volunteer pays will directly fund educational programs at the school and supplement teacher salaries.

Environmental Contribution

Using environmentally friendly construction methods such as trash bottles, rammed earth, and earth bag, the school is a practical demonstration of how to reuse discarded materials. The locals who participate in the school’s construction have hands-on experience with these money-saving construction techniques and will hopefully apply their new knowledge within the community.

Environmental education will be a main focus of the school’s new curriculum. From organic permaculture to environmentally friendly construction methods, young Comalapans will be learning responsible stewardship of the Earth through their coursework. The addition of alternative fuel production education should make a long-term impact on the surrounding communities as well.

Economic Contribution

The most immediate way that the construction of the vocational school will contribute to the economy of Comalapa is through providing jobs for teachers. Not only will the current Técnico Maya teachers have a more consistent source of income, but the newly added vocational curriculum will require the addition of several new teachers from within the community. The long-term economic effects of the vocational school will be felt when a group of skilled young Comalapans, uniquely trained to be environmental entrepreneurs, enter the Guatemalan job market.

What I and The Long Way Home Need  

For this campaign, all that I am asking for is $1,000USD. A breakdown of funds is below:

  • $300USD goes towards my monthly volunteer and housing fee, which goes directly to Long Home to help pay for their operational costs. 
  • The $200USD will be used for personal food and other everyday miscellaneous necessities. 
  • I am also raising an additional $500USD for Long Way Home, which brings a total of $800USD going towards helping pay for teachers' salaries, school materials for the children, and the sustainable school building project.

What happens if we don't reach our goal? Then what?

If we don't reach our goal, I will not be able to stay with The Long Way Home, and The Long Way Home will not get the helpful funds they need to continue their mission of educating and employing the youth, promoting community and cooperation through environmental stewardship, and eradicating poverty and pollution in Comalapa, Guatemala.

Other Ways You Can Help... 

If you can't donate money, no problem!
You can help tremendously by spreading the word about our fundraiser with your friends and family and in your social networks! Every little bit helps! Share through Facebook, Twitter and e-mail! Thanks for your time, support and donations! Together, we can make a difference! :)

 “Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed, citizens can change the world. Indeed, it is the only thing that ever has.” - Margaret Mead

 

En español...:)

 

Ayuda a romper el ciclo de pobreza y degradación ambiental mediante la educación de los niños indigenous Mayas de Comalapa, Guatemala.

Estoy escribiendo esto tan sólo unas semanas después de la finalización de la construcción de una vivienda sostenible para una familia indígena maya en Comalapa, Guatemala. Un total de 96 personas, incluidos los miembros de la Earthship Biotecture, Long Way Home, Guatemaltecos locales y 65 voluntarios de países como Austraila, Nueva Zelanda, Brasil, Italia, Francia, Alemania, Dinamarca, Inglaterra, Holanda, Noruega, Suecia, Sudáfrica, México, Canadá y Estados Unidos, trabajó junto al unísono para construir un Earthship 'Pod simple Survival "para Guatemala Capataz Long Way Home, el Apen Romeo y su familia. Dentro de tres semanas, la casa estaba completa y lista para sus toques finales a fin de que Apens podía moverse en su nuevo hogar. No sólo va a casa de Romeo recoger y filtrar el agua de lluvia y su propia funcionar con energía solar, sino que también va a utilizar y reutilizar el agua de un total de cuatro veces, que se utiliza para producir alimentos en un invernadero de interior.

 

 

La experiencia sólo puede ser descrito con palabras como "increíble", "increíble", "mágico" y "conmovedores", y el proyecto demuestra claramente el poder que es posible cuando las personas se unen por una causa unificadora.
 
Todo esto comenzó con un pequeño grupo de individuos trabajando juntos con Earthship Biotecture y Long Way Home para ayudar a recaudar donaciones para una causa noble y caritativo: Bottle Buildings and Bamboo Bicycles in Guatemala. A través de esta campaña con indiegogo, un total de $ 4,200 USD se elevó en un mes para ayudar a asegurar los fondos necesarios para completar la construcción de la casa de Romeo y su familia. El apoyo y el interés que hemos recibido para esta campaña de la familia, amigos, y muchas otras partes interesadas, fue nada menos que impresionante.

Hoy en día, la causa continúa con The Long Way Home y los niños de Guatemala ...

 

 

Después de pasar tres semanas en Comalapa, comencé a comprender cómo funcionan Long Way Home hace es de vital importancia para Compala, Guatemala. Equipo de Long Way Home están abordando problemas muy reales que no sólo afectan a Guatemala y otros países de América Latina, pero los países de todo el mundo, hay una abundancia excesiva de residuos y basura que va completamente sin control. Esta tarde termina en nuestras calles, jardines, parques infantiles o, peor aún, nuestros lagos, ríos y aguas subterráneas, donde muchas personas en países como Guatemala obtienen su agua potable.
 
El problema se agrava en países como Guatemala, donde casi no hay infraestructura para su reciclaje o eliminación de residuos, incluso de base. La mayor parte de la basura va directamente a la calle o, como se ha mencionado anteriormente, en un lago o arroyo.
 
Entonces, ¿qué vamos a hacer con lo que parece ser un problema cada vez mayor que no tiene fin?
Aunque no existen soluciones perfectas en este momento, el equipo de Long Way Home está dando paso grave en la cabeza de algunos de los problemas que no sólo afectan a los guatemaltecos, pero nos afectan a todos.

Hasta el momento, Long Way Home ha recogido y utilizado 262 toneladas de basura para la construcción de proyectos en Comalapa, Guatemala. Su proyecto principal es una escuela sostenible que, además del plan de estudios estándar, actualmente imparte 46 niños indígenas kaqchikeles (el dialecto maya tradicional local), de la cultura maya tradicional, inglés y administración ambiental. La escuela enseñará 350 estudiantes cuando la escuela está completa.

Además, se han pagado más de $ 110,000 USD en salarios a los trabajadores guatemaltecos empleados locales para proyectos sostenibles en Comalapa. Estos miembros de la comunidad están siendo entrenados para construir viviendas sostenibles y que pueden utilizar estas habilidades para crear su propia empresa de construcción alternativa.

Debido a mi gran admiración por lo que el largo camino a casa está haciendo, he decidido quedarse en Comalapa y hacer lo que pueda para ayudar.

 

Ahora ... Necesito su ayuda! :)

 

 

 

Quién es 'Long Way Home'?

Long Way Home fue fundada en 2004, cuando Mateo Paneitz terminó su servicio Peace Corps y se dio cuenta de su trabajo en la pequeña ciudad de San Juan Comalapa, Guatemala no se hizo. Él reunió a un grupo de activistas dedicados que estaban interesados en ayudar a esta comunidad cambiar su futuro. Mateo objetivo era abordar dos cuestiones principales: la falta de estrategias adecuadas de gestión de residuos, y la falta de oportunidades educativas y de empleo para los jóvenes locales, indigenous. Su equipo se le ocurrió una solución única que abordar ambas cuestiones al mismo tiempo: construir un centro de primaria y profesional de los materiales de desecho!

Fondo

El escuela Técnico Maya necesidades de financiación, y el personal dedicado y los profesores de la escuela han donado tiempo y dinero para proporcionar una educación multicultural a un bajo costo para los estudiantes, sólo cobrar una tarifa nominal y el otorgamiento de becas para aquellos que no pueden permitirse el lujo de pagar. Todos los estudiantes están obligados a llevar botellas de plástico llenas de basura cada semana como parte de su "cuota".
  

El impacto

Sostenibilidad

La Escuela Profesional proporcionará un lugar para comalapenses jóvenes a aprender oficios como albañilería, carpintería y reparación de bicicletas. Los talleres de la escuela servirá como práctica en las aulas, y serán las empresas viables donde los estudiantes trabajan como aprendices a los profesionales en cada campo. Los ingresos generados por los talleres pagar los salarios de los maestros, ayudando a la escuela cerca de su objetivo de sostenibilidad financiera. Los planes de la escuela incluyen un área donde los estudiantes pueden aprender la producción de energía alternativa. Una vez que la escuela con éxito la producción de combustibles alternativos, la venta de combustible proporcionará fondos adicionales para la institución.

Los pasantes y voluntarios de todo el mundo que vienen a trabajar en la Escuela Técnico Profesional Maya también contribuirá a la sostenibilidad financiera del proyecto. La cuota que cada voluntario paga directamente a financiar programas educativos en la escuela y complementar los salarios de los maestros.

Contribución Ambiental

El uso de métodos de construcción respetuosos del medio ambiente, tales como botellas de basura, tierra apisonada, y una bolsa de tierra, la escuela es una demostración práctica de cómo reutilizar materiales desechados. Los locales que participan en la construcción de la escuela tienen experiencia práctica con estas técnicas de construcción de ahorro de dinero y se espera que se aplican sus nuevos conocimientos dentro de la comunidad.

La educación ambiental será el enfoque principal del nuevo currículo de la escuela. Desde permacultura orgánica a los métodos de construcción ecológicos, comalapenses jóvenes aprenderán administración responsable de la Tierra a través de sus cursos. La incorporación de la educación alternativa de producción de combustible debe tener un impacto a largo plazo en las comunidades circundantes.

Contribución económica

La forma más inmediata que la construcción de la escuela de formación profesional contribuirá a la economía de Comalapa es mediante la provisión de puestos de trabajo para los maestros. No sólo los actuales maestros de Técnico mayas tienen una fuente más constante de ingresos, pero el plan de estudios que acaba de agregar profesional requerirá la adición de varios nuevos maestros dentro de la comunidad. Los efectos económicos a largo plazo de la escuela de formación profesional se hará sentir cuando un grupo de jóvenes cualificados comalapenses, singularmente capacitados para ser empresarios del medio ambiente, en el mercado laboral guatemalteco.

 

Lo que yo y Long Way Home necesidad

Para esta campaña, todo lo que estoy pidiendo es de $ 1.000 USD. Un desglose de los fondos es el siguiente:

  • $ 300 USD se dirige hacia mi voluntario mensual y la tarifa de la vivienda, que va directamente a casa el tiempo para ayudar a pagar sus gastos de funcionamiento.
  • $ 200USD se utiliza para la alimentación personal y otras necesidades cotidianas misceláneos.
  • También estoy levantando un adicional de $ 500USD para Long Way Home, que reúne un total de $ 800USD va a ayudar a pagar los salarios de maestros, materiales escolares para los niños, y el proyecto de construcción de escuelas sostenible.

Qué pasa si no llegamos a la meta? Entonces, qué?

Si no llegamos a nuestro objetivo, no voy a poder estar con The Long Way Home y The Long Way Home no obtendrá los fondos útiles que necesitan para continuar con su misión de educar y el empleo de los jóvenes, la promoción de la comunidad y la cooperación a través de la administración ambiental, y la erradicación de la pobreza y la contaminación en Comalapa, Guatemala.

Otras maneras que usted puede ayudar ...

Si no puede donar dinero, no hay problema!
Usted puede ayudar enormemente a difundir la palabra acerca de nuestra recaudación de fondos con sus amigos y familiares y en las redes sociales! Todo ayuda! Compartir a través de Facebook, Twitter y correo electrónico! Gracias por su tiempo, apoyo y donaciones! Juntos podemos hacer la diferencia! :)

 

"Nunca dudes que un pequeño grupo de ciudadanos comprometidos, pueden cambiar el mundo. De hecho, es lo único que lo ha logrado " - Margaret Mead
story_txt:
Help break the cycle of poverty and environmental degradation by educating the indigenous Mayan children of Comalapa, Guatemala.
 
I am writing this just a few weeks after the completion of the construction of a sustainable home for an indigenous Mayan family in Comalapa, Guatemala. A total of 96 people, including members of the Earthship Biotecture Crew, Long Way Home Team, local Guatemalans, and 65 volunteers from countries including Austraila, New Zealand, Brazil, Italy, France, Germany, Denmark, England, The Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, South Africa, Mexico, Canada, and the United States, worked together in unison to build a 'Simple Survival Pod' Earthship for Long Way Home's Guatemalan Foreman, Romeo Apen and his family. In three weeks time, the home was complete and ready for its finishing touches so that Apens could move into their new home. Not only will Romeo's home collect and filter its own rainwater and run on solar energy, it will also use and reuse water a total of four times, which is used to grow food in an indoor greenhouse.
 

 
The experience can only be described with words such as "amazing", "incredible", "magical", and "heart-warming," and the project clearly demonstrated the power that is possible when people come together for a unifying cause. 
 
All of this began by a small group of individuals working together with Earthship Biotecture and Long Way Home to help raise donations for a worthy and charitable cause: Bottle Buildings and Bamboo Bicycles in Guatemala. Through this campaign with indiegogo , a total of $4,200USD was raised in one month to help secure the necessary funds to complete the construction of the home for Romeo and his family. The support and interest we received for this campaign from family, friends, and many other interested parties, was nothing short of awe-inspiring.
 
Today, the cause continues with The Long Way Home and the children of Guatemala...
 

 
 
After spending three weeks in Comalapa, I began to realize how the work Long Way Home does is vitally important to Compala, Guatemala. Long Way Home Team are addressing very real issues that not only affect Guatemala and other Latin America countries, but countries around the world, there is an over-abundance of waste and trash that goes completely unchecked. This later ends up in our streets, gardens, playgrounds or, even worse, our lakes, streams, and groundwater where many people in countries like Guatemala get their drinking water.
 
The problem is compounded in places like Guatemala where there is almost no infrastructure for recycling or even basic waste disposal. Most of the garbage goes directly into the street or, as previously mentioned, into a lake or stream. 
 
So what do we do about what seems to be an ever-increasing problem with no end? 
Although there are no perfect solutions at the moment, Long Way Home Team are making serious head way on some of the problems that not only affect Guatemalans, but affect us all.  
Thus far, Long Way Home has collected and used 262 tons of garbage for building projects in Comalapa, Guatemala. Their primary project is a sustainable school which, in addition to the standard curriculum, currently teaches 46 indigenous children Kaqchikel (the traditional local Mayan dialect), traditional Mayan culture, English and environmental stewardship. The school will teach 350 students when the school is complete. 
Additionally, they have paid upwards of $110,000USD in salary to local Guatemalan workers employed for sustainable projects in Comalapa. These community members are being trained to build sustainable homes and they can use these skills to start their own alternative building business. 
Because of my great admiration for what the Long Way Home is doing, I have decided to stay in Comalapa and do what I can to help. 
 
Now...I need your help! :)
 

Who is The Long Way Home?
Long Way Home was founded in 2004 when Mateo Paneitz finished his Peace Corps service and realized his work in the small town of San Juan Comalapa, Guatemala was not done. He brought together a group of dedicated activists who were interested in helping this community change their future. Mateo’s goal was to address two primary issues: the lack of appropriate waste management strategies; and the lack of educational and employment opportunities for local, indigenous youth. His team came up with a unique solution that would tackle both issues simultaneously: build a primary and vocational facility out of waste materials!
Background
The Técnico Maya school needs funding, and the dedicated staff and faculty at the school have donated time and money to provide a multicultural education at a low cost to students, only charging a nominal fee and providing scholarships for those who cannot afford to pay. All students are required to bring plastic bottles filled with trash each week as part of their "tuition."
  


The Impact
Sustainability
The Vocational School will provide a venue for young Comalapans to learn such trades as masonry, carpentry and bicycle repair. The workshops in the school will serve as hands-on classrooms, and will be viable businesses where the students will work as apprentices to professionals in each field. The income generated by the workshops will pay the teachers’ salaries, helping the school near its goal of financial sustainability. The school plans include an area where students can learn alternative energy production. Once the school is successfully producing alternative fuels, the sale of fuel will provide additional funding for the institution.
Interns and volunteers from around the world who come to work at the Técnico Maya Vocational School will also contribute to the financial sustainability of the project. The fee that each volunteer pays will directly fund educational programs at the school and supplement teacher salaries.

Environmental Contribution
Using environmentally friendly construction methods such as trash bottles, rammed earth, and earth bag, the school is a practical demonstration of how to reuse discarded materials. The locals who participate in the school’s construction have hands-on experience with these money-saving construction techniques and will hopefully apply their new knowledge within the community.
Environmental education will be a main focus of the school’s new curriculum. From organic permaculture to environmentally friendly construction methods, young Comalapans will be learning responsible stewardship of the Earth through their coursework. The addition of alternative fuel production education should make a long-term impact on the surrounding communities as well.
Economic Contribution
The most immediate way that the construction of the vocational school will contribute to the economy of Comalapa is through providing jobs for teachers. Not only will the current Técnico Maya teachers have a more consistent source of income, but the newly added vocational curriculum will require the addition of several new teachers from within the community. The long-term economic effects of the vocational school will be felt when a group of skilled young Comalapans, uniquely trained to be environmental entrepreneurs, enter the Guatemalan job market.



What I and The Long Way Home Need  
For this campaign, all that I am asking for is $1,000USD. A breakdown of funds is below:

$300USD goes towards my monthly volunteer and housing fee, which goes directly to Long Home to help pay for their operational costs. 
The $200USD will be used for personal food and other everyday miscellaneous necessities. 
I am also raising an additional $500USD for Long Way Home, which brings a total of $800USD going towards helping pay for teachers' salaries, school materials for the children, and the sustainable school building project.

What happens if we don't reach our goal? Then what?
If we don't reach our goal, I will not be able to stay with The Long Way Home, and The Long Way Home will not get the helpful funds they need to continue their mission of educating and employing the youth, promoting community and cooperation through environmental stewardship, and eradicating poverty and pollution in Comalapa, Guatemala.
Other Ways You Can Help... 



If you can't donate money, no problem!You can help tremendously by spreading the word about our fundraiser with your friends and family and in your social networks! Every little bit helps! Share through Facebook, Twitter and e-mail! Thanks for your time, support and donations! Together, we can make a difference! :)

 “Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed, citizens can change the world. Indeed, it is the only thing that ever has.” - Margaret Mead
 
En español...:)
 
Ayuda a romper el ciclo de pobreza y degradación ambiental mediante la educación de los niños indigenous Mayas de Comalapa, Guatemala.
Estoy escribiendo esto tan sólo unas semanas después de la finalización de la construcción de una vivienda sostenible para una familia indígena maya en Comalapa, Guatemala. Un total de 96 personas, incluidos los miembros de la Earthship Biotecture, Long Way Home, Guatemaltecos locales y 65 voluntarios de países como Austraila, Nueva Zelanda, Brasil, Italia, Francia, Alemania, Dinamarca, Inglaterra, Holanda, Noruega, Suecia, Sudáfrica, México, Canadá y Estados Unidos, trabajó junto al unísono para construir un Earthship 'Pod simple Survival "para Guatemala Capataz Long Way Home, el Apen Romeo y su familia. Dentro de tres semanas, la casa estaba completa y lista para sus toques finales a fin de que Apens podía moverse en su nuevo hogar. No sólo va a casa de Romeo recoger y filtrar el agua de lluvia y su propia funcionar con energía solar, sino que también va a utilizar y reutilizar el agua de un total de cuatro veces, que se utiliza para producir alimentos en un invernadero de interior.
 

 
La experiencia sólo puede ser descrito con palabras como "increíble", "increíble", "mágico" y "conmovedores", y el proyecto demuestra claramente el poder que es posible cuando las personas se unen por una causa unificadora. Todo esto comenzó con un pequeño grupo de individuos trabajando juntos con Earthship Biotecture y Long Way Home para ayudar a recaudar donaciones para una causa noble y caritativo: Bottle Buildings and Bamboo Bicycles in Guatemala. A través de esta campaña con indiegogo, un total de $ 4,200 USD se elevó en un mes para ayudar a asegurar los fondos necesarios para completar la construcción de la casa de Romeo y su familia. El apoyo y el interés que hemos recibido para esta campaña de la familia, amigos, y muchas otras partes interesadas, fue nada menos que impresionante.
Hoy en día, la causa continúa con The Long Way Home y los niños de Guatemala ...
 

 
Después de pasar tres semanas en Comalapa, comencé a comprender cómo funcionan Long Way Home hace es de vital importancia para Compala, Guatemala. Equipo de Long Way Home están abordando problemas muy reales que no sólo afectan a Guatemala y otros países de América Latina, pero los países de todo el mundo, hay una abundancia excesiva de residuos y basura que va completamente sin control. Esta tarde termina en nuestras calles, jardines, parques infantiles o, peor aún, nuestros lagos, ríos y aguas subterráneas, donde muchas personas en países como Guatemala obtienen su agua potable. El problema se agrava en países como Guatemala, donde casi no hay infraestructura para su reciclaje o eliminación de residuos, incluso de base. La mayor parte de la basura va directamente a la calle o, como se ha mencionado anteriormente, en un lago o arroyo. Entonces, ¿qué vamos a hacer con lo que parece ser un problema cada vez mayor que no tiene fin?Aunque no existen soluciones perfectas en este momento, el equipo de Long Way Home está dando paso grave en la cabeza de algunos de los problemas que no sólo afectan a los guatemaltecos, pero nos afectan a todos.
Hasta el momento, Long Way Home ha recogido y utilizado 262 toneladas de basura para la construcción de proyectos en Comalapa, Guatemala. Su proyecto principal es una escuela sostenible que, además del plan de estudios estándar, actualmente imparte 46 niños indígenas kaqchikeles (el dialecto maya tradicional local), de la cultura maya tradicional, inglés y administración ambiental. La escuela enseñará 350 estudiantes cuando la escuela está completa.
Además, se han pagado más de $ 110,000 USD en salarios a los trabajadores guatemaltecos empleados locales para proyectos sostenibles en Comalapa. Estos miembros de la comunidad están siendo entrenados para construir viviendas sostenibles y que pueden utilizar estas habilidades para crear su propia empresa de construcción alternativa.
Debido a mi gran admiración por lo que el largo camino a casa está haciendo, he decidido quedarse en Comalapa y hacer lo que pueda para ayudar.
 
Ahora ... Necesito su ayuda! :)
 

 
 
Quién es 'Long Way Home'?
Long Way Home fue fundada en 2004, cuando Mateo Paneitz terminó su servicio Peace Corps y se dio cuenta de su trabajo en la pequeña ciudad de San Juan Comalapa, Guatemala no se hizo. Él reunió a un grupo de activistas dedicados que estaban interesados en ayudar a esta comunidad cambiar su futuro. Mateo objetivo era abordar dos cuestiones principales: la falta de estrategias adecuadas de gestión de residuos, y la falta de oportunidades educativas y de empleo para los jóvenes locales, indigenous. Su equipo se le ocurrió una solución única que abordar ambas cuestiones al mismo tiempo: construir un centro de primaria y profesional de los materiales de desecho!
Fondo

El escuela Técnico Maya necesidades de financiación, y el personal dedicado y los profesores de la escuela han donado tiempo y dinero para proporcionar una educación multicultural a un bajo costo para los estudiantes, sólo cobrar una tarifa nominal y el otorgamiento de becas para aquellos que no pueden permitirse el lujo de pagar. Todos los estudiantes están obligados a llevar botellas de plástico llenas de basura cada semana como parte de su "cuota".
  


El impacto
Sostenibilidad
La Escuela Profesional proporcionará un lugar para comalapenses jóvenes a aprender oficios como albañilería, carpintería y reparación de bicicletas. Los talleres de la escuela servirá como práctica en las aulas, y serán las empresas viables donde los estudiantes trabajan como aprendices a los profesionales en cada campo. Los ingresos generados por los talleres pagar los salarios de los maestros, ayudando a la escuela cerca de su objetivo de sostenibilidad financiera. Los planes de la escuela incluyen un área donde los estudiantes pueden aprender la producción de energía alternativa. Una vez que la escuela con éxito la producción de combustibles alternativos, la venta de combustible proporcionará fondos adicionales para la institución.
Los pasantes y voluntarios de todo el mundo que vienen a trabajar en la Escuela Técnico Profesional Maya también contribuirá a la sostenibilidad financiera del proyecto. La cuota que cada voluntario paga directamente a financiar programas educativos en la escuela y complementar los salarios de los maestros.

Contribución Ambiental
El uso de métodos de construcción respetuosos del medio ambiente, tales como botellas de basura, tierra apisonada, y una bolsa de tierra, la escuela es una demostración práctica de cómo reutilizar materiales desechados. Los locales que participan en la construcción de la escuela tienen experiencia práctica con estas técnicas de construcción de ahorro de dinero y se espera que se aplican sus nuevos conocimientos dentro de la comunidad.
La educación ambiental será el enfoque principal del nuevo currículo de la escuela. Desde permacultura orgánica a los métodos de construcción ecológicos, comalapenses jóvenes aprenderán administración responsable de la Tierra a través de sus cursos. La incorporación de la educación alternativa de producción de combustible debe tener un impacto a largo plazo en las comunidades circundantes.
Contribución económica
La forma más inmediata que la construcción de la escuela de formación profesional contribuirá a la economía de Comalapa es mediante la provisión de puestos de trabajo para los maestros. No sólo los actuales maestros de Técnico mayas tienen una fuente más constante de ingresos, pero el plan de estudios que acaba de agregar profesional requerirá la adición de varios nuevos maestros dentro de la comunidad. Los efectos económicos a largo plazo de la escuela de formación profesional se hará sentir cuando un grupo de jóvenes cualificados comalapenses, singularmente capacitados para ser empresarios del medio ambiente, en el mercado laboral guatemalteco.
 
Lo que yo y Long Way Home necesidad
Para esta campaña, todo lo que estoy pidiendo es de $ 1.000 USD. Un desglose de los fondos es el siguiente:

$ 300 USD se dirige hacia mi voluntario mensual y la tarifa de la vivienda, que va directamente a casa el tiempo para ayudar a pagar sus gastos de funcionamiento.
$ 200USD se utiliza para la alimentación personal y otras necesidades cotidianas misceláneos.
También estoy levantando un adicional de $ 500USD para Long Way Home, que reúne un total de $ 800USD va a ayudar a pagar los salarios de maestros, materiales escolares para los niños, y el proyecto de construcción de escuelas sostenible.

Qué pasa si no llegamos a la meta? Entonces, qué?
Si no llegamos a nuestro objetivo, no voy a poder estar con The Long Way Home y The Long Way Home no obtendrá los fondos útiles que necesitan para continuar con su misión de educar y el empleo de los jóvenes, la promoción de la comunidad y la cooperación a través de la administración ambiental, y la erradicación de la pobreza y la contaminación en Comalapa, Guatemala.
Otras maneras que usted puede ayudar ...
Si no puede donar dinero, no hay problema!Usted puede ayudar enormemente a difundir la palabra acerca de nuestra recaudación de fondos con sus amigos y familiares y en las redes sociales! Todo ayuda! Compartir a través de Facebook, Twitter y correo electrónico! Gracias por su tiempo, apoyo y donaciones! Juntos podemos hacer la diferencia! :)

 
"Nunca dudes que un pequeño grupo de ciudadanos comprometidos, pueden cambiar el mundo. De hecho, es lo único que lo ha logrado " - Margaret Mead

story:
Court résumé en français disponible ici !

Uma breve descrição em português está disponível aqui !

Accountability is the keystone of change

If the seriousness of Climate Change is now being acknowledged by most, reversing the trend is not an attainable goal if only dealt with on individual levels. The purpose of Greenplease is to take the Green pulse of communities and establish strong local and global platforms where people can organize active social campaigns to (mindfully but uncomprominsingly) pressure Corporations and City Councils to take on the challenge of holding up their businesses while making them green. 
  • The influence Corporations have on everyone’s consumer habits, and consequently on the planet, is colossal. Above all, they must become advocates of sustainable living and live up to the trust we put in them when choosing their goods.
  • City Councils are the only gouvernement platforms still operated on a human scale and yet, they’re powerful enough to drive change. It’s where green movements can really be initiated and supported.

Turfs are interactive hubs for building 2-way communication bridges between city administrations and their citizens, and between corporations and their patrons. My Turfs are for individuals, Big Turfs for corporations and City Turfs for cities.  

Greenplease’s Tools are easy to use and fast to put in action. They are about:

  • accountability (Boycotts)
  • support (Buycotts)
  • commitment (Bans)
  • advocacy (Saturday Greenplease Gatherings).

The Turfs & Tools combination is a unique and powerful opportunity for people to take simple actions that, put together, can lead to incredible feats of leverage and persuasion. And, despite the numerous “green social networks” on the Web already, nothing of the like is yet available. With critical environmental issues now globally being among our top priorities, the timing for such a platform is perfect. 

All the architecture, functionalities and user experience are now ready to be web-executed and put online.

Note: all the web designs in the video are preliminary mockups. Final designs are still to be created.

A more detailed overview on functionalities and features available here !

 

With your help we’ll be able to :

  • Set up a temporary office – We are currently all volunteers. To get Greenplease up and running we need to shift from a part-time volunteer status to a full-time workforce for a 3-month period.
  • Hire additional web-programmers and graphic designers – All the web designs shown in this Indiegogo video are preliminary mockups. We need to hire professional graphic designers to work on unique designs and icons that will become Greenplease trademarks.
  • Take care of all hosting and maintenance costs for the first 12 months

 

PLEASE DO NOT WORRY: Greenplease is going ahead !

If the campaign doesn't reach its target, we will still continue to work on the execution, and use the funds accordingly. It will just take a little more time ! 

 

The Wearable Perks !

The greatest perk you can offer yourself is the personal satisfaction that comes along when getting involved in a movement set out to make our world a better place !

That being said, we obviously want to underline your involvement in the endeavor with nice wearable perks ! 

  • 1-inch Buttons - Our first batch of 1000 buttons have a special inscription on their rims : “ I’M ONE OF THE FIRST 1000 GREENPLEASERS”. We still have a little over 500 of those left…Don’t miss out !
  • "Switch on to Green" Stickers - If you'd like more stickers to spread the word around, please contact us and we'll gladly send you some at cost price !    
  • "Make it Greenplease" T-Shirts - The T-shirts you see here were individually hand-pressed for us. On the T-Shirts we’ll make for you we’ll add a short self-explanatory slogan: “Let’s make it Greenplease”. Please claim many, and we'll be able to offer both women's and men's style !
  • Distinctive Green Turf Headers - Fast-forward yourself 3 years in the future and imagine that Greenplease is "THE" green social platform everyone is using. Wouldn't a distinctive green header on your TURF profile be the envy of all your peers ?
  • Original "Vintage" Greenplease T-Shirt - Get your hands on this last original Greenplease T-Shirt, bearing the first logo mockup. Hurry up: there is only one ! Have a look at it !

The Team

    Xavier Bonacorsi - Founder

A background of travelling, (street & campus) studies, and hands in the dirt projects made me develop great respect and appreciation for life, in all its forms.Greenplease was brought forth by this important life guideline, and by the desire to crush this state of inaction in which we have all fallen into, mostly out of a feeling of helplessness.I truly believe in the power of numbers. When huddled around an idea, people can achieve anything.

 

   Friedhelm Filler - Co-founder, Solution Engineer

An early talent for math, people and business startups allowed me to see the world extensively at a very early age.
 
We have taken from the earth, as if we owned it and there was no tomorrow. Seeing a lot of this unnecessary excessivness made me want my dent in the Universe to be a green one. And a big one !
 

 

   Peter Myers - Co-founder

After taking part in many of the “usual” societal systems that have been developed in the western world during the past century, I realized that staying on this course can only lead to irreparable consequences.

For the past 10 years, I’ve been involved in local responsible lifestyles and business mindsets. My rule is to live within and use sustainable systems, big and small…

 

Code of conduct

Greenplease will be fueled and managed by its community. Its administrators will never have personal conclusions or comments posted. While Greenplease is a place for criticism, assertions and claims, a constructive and respectful attitude is nonetheless mandatory. Angry blames or rants & raves are not to be articulated.

 

PLEASE ---> SPREAD THE WORD !

For a movement to get momentum and soar, it needs to be broadcasted far and wide. If you want to contribute with your time, spread the word: petition your friends to join us, blog about Greenplease, post our colors on forums & blogs, Twitter, Facebook, use the Indiegogo share tools...

If you'd like to get more involved in any way, do not hesitate to contact us at info(at)greenplease.co

www.greenplease.co
