"Switch on to Green" Stickers - If you'd like more stickers to spread the word around, please contact us and we'll gladly send you some at cost price !    



"Make it Greenplease" T-Shirts - The T-shirts you see here were individually hand-pressed for us. On the T-Shirts we’ll make for you we’ll add a short self-explanatory slogan: “Let’s make it Greenplease”. Please claim many, and we'll be able to offer both women's and men's style !



Distinctive Green Turf Headers - Fast-forward yourself 3 years in the future and imagine that Greenplease is "THE" green social platform everyone is using. Wouldn't a distinctive green header on your TURF profile be the envy of all your peers ?



Original "Vintage" Greenplease T-Shirt - Get your hands on this last original Greenplease T-Shirt, bearing the first logo mockup. Hurry up: there is only one ! Have a look at it !


The Team


    Xavier Bonacorsi - Founder

A background of travelling, (street & campus) studies, and hands in the dirt projects made me develop great respect and appreciation for life, in all its forms.Greenplease was brought forth by this important life guideline, and by the desire to crush this state of inaction in which we have all fallen into, mostly out of a feeling of helplessness.I truly believe in the power of numbers. When huddled around an idea, people can achieve anything.
 

   Friedhelm Filler - Co-founder, Solution Engineer

An early talent for math, people and business startups allowed me to see the world extensively at a very early age.
 
We have taken from the earth, as if we owned it and there was no tomorrow. Seeing a lot of this unnecessary excessivness made me want my dent in the Universe to be a green one. And a big one !
 
 

   Peter Myers - Co-founder

After taking part in many of the “usual” societal systems that have been developed in the western world during the past century, I realized that staying on this course can only lead to irreparable consequences.
For the past 10 years, I’ve been involved in local responsible lifestyles and business mindsets. My rule is to live within and use sustainable systems, big and small…

 
Code of conduct
Greenplease will be fueled and managed by its community. Its administrators will never have personal conclusions or comments posted. While Greenplease is a place for criticism, assertions and claims, a constructive and respectful attitude is nonetheless mandatory. Angry blames or rants & raves are not to be articulated.



 
PLEASE ---> SPREAD THE WORD !
For a movement to get momentum and soar, it needs to be broadcasted far and wide. If you want to contribute with your time, spread the word: petition your friends to join us, blog about Greenplease, post our colors on forums & blogs, Twitter, Facebook, use the Indiegogo share tools...
If you'd like to get more involved in any way, do not hesitate to contact us at info(at)greenplease.co
www.greenplease.co

story:
Where are we From

Upcycle has been born out of love for this beautiful, abundant world and a strong desire to do something to care for the health of ourselves and the planet. We work at festivals transmitting ideas of care, respect and love for the environment through providing the Eco-Rangers and our Free Shop.

Upcycle is a festival project that supplies team of Eco-Rangers to environmentally conscious UK festivals. This team works with creativity and passion to engage the festival goers in the on-site recycling policy. Upcycle is in its third year and is at an extremely exciting stage. In the first year we travelled on bicycle from festival to festival, the second year we had a van and were lucky to receive some funding from YTFN to facilitate the project. 

This year we are excited to expand our reach aiming for seven festivals in total. We will provide up to one hundred volunteers and will aim to keep recycling rates beyond 70% at all our events.

Contributions to Upcycle will go a long way. We are small and direct, money does not get lost on admin and office rent. We spend our funds on food for volunteers, essential waste management equipment like bags and poles and vital transport costs.

Breaking down the Money

We need to raise £3000 for this summer’s tour to be a success. Below is a table of how we plan to spend the money. We’ll be transparent with our funds giving you updates via our website and facebook when we make major spends. 

Cost 

 / Item / Info

1250

 - Transport - From festival to festival in our converted Fiat Ducato

750

 - Food - This will have to stretch to provide volunteers with food and energy for the summer. 

500

 - Equipment - large bags, gloves, jackets etc.

500

 - Artists costs / resources / tools / transport

 

 

Upcycle is run by volunteers. We are not asking for any money to go towards staffing costs. All your money will go directly into the running of this project, into the food, energy and resources that we need to make this happen. We really appreciate any funding that you can give, honestly the money helps us live our dream.

We want to use crowd funding to raise our money so that we have a crowd of supporters. Please see the gifts offered down the side bar in exchange for your funding. Here are a few more things we can offer you, as a gift, in exchange for your gifts:

We’re well connected in the UK festival scene so we can help you plan a festival project or put you in touch with the right people.

Volunteering positions at some of the Uk’s most cutting edge festivals.

Support with your projects; funding applications, volunteers, website creation etc.

Workshop space in Bristol where we’re experiment in creating festival decoration (subject to season)

  

Our aims and impact

We have three main aims with Upcycle. 

Firstly we hope to reduce the environmental impact of small festivals in the UK. We will be visiting at least seven festivals this coming summer and will work our socks off to ensure their waste is well dealt with, that they achieve the maximum possible recycling rates and that the environment is preserved as much as possible.

Secondly our teams of volunteers gain a huge amount from the experience of volunteering with us. We look to push all volunteers to take on positions of responsibility, to move out of their ‘comfort zone’ and to learn and grow through working with Upcycle. This personal growth and expansion of our volunteers is particularly important and, we believe, unique to Upcycle.

This summer we are also hoping to include a number of artists and actors in our teams of Eco-Rangers. Part of our funding will go to support them in bringing their projects, set pieces, theatrical creations to festival sites. We are also planning some theatrical festival antics for our time between festivals and funding will go towards realising this dream.

Thirdly through our work we aim to build up a community of interest in our project and in our kind of work. We love festival making and we love those who want to make it environmentally friendly. The UK’s festival culture is extremely well developed, lets push it that final step to ensure we really have a festival culture that is cutting edge, sustainable and promising for the future.

We have seen rises in our two main festival’s recycling rates from 50% to 80% in the last two years. We hope to exceed this rate this coming summer with the provision of new equipment and new volunteer schedules. Please help us achieve our aim.

This summer we are also hoping to enhance and build on our international connections. Through the internet we're aleady exchanging and sharing ideas with various upcycling groups in the US and with your funding we hope to improve and cement these connections.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute with money there are plenty of ways you can help Upcycle be a success this summer. Perhaps you know somebody who might be interested, might like to contribute, please forward on this funding bid to them.

You can also spread the word about Upcycle over facebook, twitter (@upcycleuk) or via our website. A major part of the project is building a community of exciting, energetic and inspiration people who are ready to work to heal our world. Some have lots of money, some have none. We love you all the same. 

Please also consider volunteering as an eco-ranger. Particularly if you have given a donation to the summer tour we would love for your to come with us and see how we spend the money. For how to apply please see our website and we will endeavor to include you in our team.

Thanks for your time and any assistance you might be able to give us. We really appreciate your love and support.

Love always, 

The Upcycle Team x

www.up-cycle.org.uk

story:
My Story

I am a student of psychology and fine arts but my passion lies in permaculture. On a study abroad semester in Israel, I learned about this concept for the first time. Permaculture is based on three ethics:

            Care of the Earth

            Care of People

            Fair Share (of the earth, goods, and knowledge).

After studying permaculture, I returned to school in Cambridge, MA where I worked for an organization called CitySprouts (www.citysprouts.org). It was a wonderful experience and allowed me to continue working in the dirt with passionate and earth conscious individuals while living in a large city. Now, I am graduating from school in Paris, France and am looking towards the future-a future full of permaculture and its three ethics. I have come up with a goal that will, hopefully, allow the idea of permaculture to spread to people in cities and small communities that are looking for a creative and innovative method for communal and sustainable living. And I need your help to realize this goal! 


Goal

2 years of travel to share the story of Permaculture and the individuals who have created communities around the world to better the planet, lives and community spirit. I will be keeping a blog as I travel with the hopes of also publishing stories as a freelance writer in newspapers and permaculture publications as I move from community to community. At the end, I will be compiling all of the information I have received into a book. It will focus on the inception of these five communities, those who founded them, and their commitment to permaculture. It will include images, interviews, stories, maps, and a great deal about permaculture.


The Impact

This project will provide an understanding of the basis of permaculture. It is a concept that should be understood throughout the world as we move towards a healthier (for the earth, for people and for trade) lifestyle. This concept is known to many small communities across the world but needs the extra push to bring it to the attention of the world as a whole. I hope to help permaculture along while also sharing information about the diverse and wonderful communities that have already adopted its concepts. 


It will also bring to light cultures and communities that may often be overlooked. From communities in Israel who do not subscribe to hatred and violence to communities that promote medicinal healing and shamanistic practices, there are many places in the world that are reviewed briefly in the history books yet do not provide a comprehensive understanding of culture. While I do not believe it is possible to compile a complete history of a culture from a four to six month stay in a given society, I do hope to create interest in the cultures of the permaculture communities that I will be visiting.


What I Need

I am looking for sponsorship for airfare between the different countries. This includes four flights (including one round-trip fare to Kansas City, Missouri to Lima, Peru where I will be taking a break between Lima, Peru and Israel to review notes and complete research. This round trip will also save money, as the flight from Sydney, Australia to Lima, Peru is twice as expensive as that between Kansas City and Lima). The flights are broken down as follows (fares based on extensive research of inexpensive but trustworthy airlines):

            Paris, France to Cape Town, Western Cape, South Africa                          $880

            Cape Town, Western Cape, South Africa to Chennai, India                        $660

            Chennai, India to Sydney, Australia                                                             $682

            Kansas City, Missouri, USA to Lima, Peru (round-trip ticket)                       $1250

                        (I will be paying for trip from Australia to Kansas City, Missouri, USA)

            Kansas City, Missouri, USA to Tel Aviv, Israel                                             $1647

                                                Total Airfare                                   $5119

 

In addition to paying for transportation on the ground, I will be covering my own visa expenses as well as vaccination and medical expenses including one year of health insurance. I am hoping, however, that the second year of health insurance will be provided through your generous donations. I will be purchasing health insurance for travelers through World Nomads for $913 per year.

 

The addition of $913 of health insurance to the airfare total, completes the request at


$6032 (total: airfare+1 year of health insurance).


Your donations are greatly appreciated and I hope that the completion of this project will touch not only those who are currently interested in permaculture and sustainable design, but those who have not yet come to understand these concepts and the wonderful good they can do for individual communities and our world as a whole.

 

*Any additional money will be donated to CitySprouts, an organization that is not founded on the principles of permaculture but an organization that provides a wonderful service to the youth of Cambridge, MA. They work to provide 12 gardens that are used as teaching tools to further public education for the grade schools in Cambridge. I was fortunate enough to work with them for a year and they have inspired me to seek out communities around the world that provide gardens and education to children and adults alike. 


Who is on the itinerary

Robertson, Western Cape, South Africa â€“ Long Valley Permaculture

Small community of families and farm animals that work together with the hope that they will be able to show the world the potential for semi-commercial permaculture.

Chennai, India â€“ Auroville

The Ecovillage of Ecovillages, the community of Auroville describes itself as a â€œâ€¦a universal city in the making in south-India.â€ It seeks to provide education, support, sustainable design and understanding of community through permaculture and has done an amazing job. Here, people have come together to study innovative new technologies in the environmental realm while preserving a sense of spirituality. It is home (permanent and temporary) to around 2,160 people at a time and has touched the lives of people who wish to bring permaculture to their home town or an Ecovillage of their own in numbers over 50,000.   

Sydney, Australia â€“ Milkwood Permaculture

A Permaculture farm with two locations: one, a few hours outside of Sydney, the other, located in Sydney itself. The organizers of this farm offer study courses in permaculture as well as beekeeping and mushroom growing. They believe that permaculture is not meant just to implement, but is meant to teach as well.

Iquitos, Peru â€“ Paititi Institute for the Preservation of the Amazon Rainforest and Indigenous Culture (Centers for Shamanistic Permaculture)

Paititi Institute combines permaculture, Peruvian Shamanistic culture and herbal medicinal practices to create a community unlike any of the other communities on the itinerary. They have established a working society that brings together rich history and modern ideas and they continually share their design with those interested in learning about permaculture, medicine, the Amazon and native Peruvian culture.

Southern Arava, Israel â€“ Kibbutz Lotan Center for Ecology

An Ecovillage located on a thriving and beautiful Kibbutz in the Southern Aravah valley in Israel, Lotanâ€™s Center for Ecology offers the study of permaculture in an international community. Not only does this community live and teach permaculture, but they also explore peace and social justice issues unique to Israel from both a Jewish and non-sectarian perspective. They often use permaculture, agriculture, and sustainable design to breakdown barriers and provide means of communication between the different groups and sides of the conflict in Israel.

 

*Because of size of communities, the smaller permaculture centers (those in South Africa, Australia and Peru, for example), may have limited volunteer space, causing trips to these communities to be postponed or canceled. In case of cancelation, another permaculture community in the same country, same region and with a similar story will be chosen. If there is no other option and that city must be taken off the itinerary, the money raised will be donated either to a start up permaculture community or CitySprouts. This will be discussed on the projectâ€™s blog and supporters will have a say as to where the money will be donated.


Other Ways You Can Help

Get to know permaculture. There are many resources online that provide descriptions of permaculture and suggestions for implementation in your everyday life. This is not a concept that is used just for community Ecovillage life. You can use it too!

And, if you really want to experience permaculture, check out http://permacultureglobal.com/. It is a list of many, many permaculture projects across the world that you can volunteer for. Get in there and help me discover true community, deeply rooted culture and the peace and love permaculture provides.




I understand that this is a lot to ask and I appreciate you taking the time to read through my project proposal and for making the choice to either learn just a little bit about permaculture or learn a little bit about permaculture while donating a bit of money to my project.


To all of you, I am sending peace, love and permaculture,


Erin Katz

story:
In this film we wish to show the discovered beauty of sustainability more than the destruction caused by unsustainable practices, however many of our questions have come as a result of struggles in one way or another.


UPDATE:  Because of unfortunate weather in Chile (global warming), the slopes will not be ready by August, so that part of the trip is not a go and I think we'll be missing Silas.   Instead of Chile, I'll be hiking a 18,000 ft. volcano in Mexico called Pico de Orizaba, which overlooks Puebla, where I have spent time in Indigenous Villages. 



Our Story

 Increasingly popular, modern skiing and snowboarding culture are coming to be defined by 'bigger, better and more Extreme': more adrenaline, bigger table tops, better gear, and more extreme parks, flips and parties.  In a race to grow fueled by the industry, skiing is becoming increasingly man made and expensive. Ski towns and ski resorts are forced to compete and grow as well. Though exciting, this lifestyle and the large ski town developments leave a trail of unseen consequences around the world. Sadly, this transformation is making skiing one of the least sustainable outdoor activities we partake in. Many wonder if this is necessary.

 

 Vermont 'Extreme' Skiers Skyler Perkins and Silas Chickering-Ayers seek to better understand what is at the heart of sustainability and see skiing as an effective medium for their exploration. Their travels land them in the snowy peaks of the Patagonia Mountains where they explore the Valle Chacabuco conservation park. Leaving ski lifts, lodges and terrain parks behind, the two set out to experience skiing in it's purest form.

 

 For further understanding of human's role in the cycles of nature, the travelers also live in a small indigenous village in the jungles of Mexico facing increasing outside influence. Throughout the journey they discover why the town is considered a "pueblo Magico" and gain insight to the reasons and ways this beautiful culture has survived autonomously up until now.

 

Along the journey they share enlightening conversations with Doug Tompkins (founder of North Face and owner of Conservacion Patagonica) as well as Professors, skiers, authors and Mexico’s wise Nahua indians.

 

 The Impact

 Through this film, we are exploring ‘sustainability’ on a deeper level -- one that moves beyond sustainability as a political tool, a marketing scheme, or the latest academic trend. Instead, the skiers search for a new ‘sustainability’ that is reflected in a ‘state of being’, an integrous way of life that respects the environment, the community and ultimately our humanity -- and one that inherently preserves our future. We hope to show that skiing does not have to destroy our environment but can, instead be a way to further connect with the natural world.

 

 The film will touch lightly on the negative effects and unintended consequences of development across national and cultural boundaries and show efforts to fight against hydro-dams, mono-crop forest plantations, dried rivers, and increased disease for Indigenous Villages. We hope to share our journey and learnings in a way that is meaningful for skiers, those who care about the environment, those who care about protecting peoples and cultures; those confused by our modern day notions of sustainability, and for anyone and everyone walking carefully and enjoying stories.

 

 What We Need & What You Get

 

 The great majority of costs will be travel costs. Expenses for Mexico were self incurred but in order to reach chile we will need money. Additional funding will cover costs of transportation to Chile, and paying for a mountain guide. We will be camping and paying for food. We will be supported by ski and outerwear companies, including WAGNER, Flylow, and RAMP. 

 

 Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love your participation in any way possible, be it through direct funding, or sharing with people who you think would value this film. One part we enjoy most about this process is having conversations and expanding our community.
story_txt:
In this film we wish to show the discovered beauty of sustainability more than the destruction caused by unsustainable practices, however many of our questions have come as a result of struggles in one way or another.
UPDATE:  Because of unfortunate weather in Chile (global warming), the slopes will not be ready by August, so that part of the trip is not a go and I think we'll be missing Silas.   Instead of Chile, I'll be hiking a 18,000 ft. volcano in Mexico called Pico de Orizaba, which overlooks Puebla, where I have spent time in Indigenous Villages.  
Our Story
 Increasingly popular, modern skiing and snowboarding culture are coming to be defined by 'bigger, better and more Extreme': more adrenaline, bigger table tops, better gear, and more extreme parks, flips and parties.  In a race to grow fueled by the industry, skiing is becoming increasingly man made and expensive. Ski towns and ski resorts are forced to compete and grow as well. Though exciting, this lifestyle and the large ski town developments leave a trail of unseen consequences around the world. Sadly, this transformation is making skiing one of the least sustainable outdoor activities we partake in. Many wonder if this is necessary.
 
 Vermont 'Extreme' Skiers Skyler Perkins and Silas Chickering-Ayers seek to better understand what is at the heart of sustainability and see skiing as an effective medium for their exploration. Their travels land them in the snowy peaks of the Patagonia Mountains where they explore the Valle Chacabuco conservation park. Leaving ski lifts, lodges and terrain parks behind, the two set out to experience skiing in it's purest form.

Along the journey they share enlightening conversations with Doug Tompkins (founder of North Face and owner of Conservacion Patagonica) as well as Professors, skiers, authors and Mexico’s wise Nahua indians.

story:
Help us Paint MORE Rain Barrels for our Traveling Exhibit by The Collinwood Painted Rain Barrel Project.

12 hand painted 55 gallon rain barrels by local artists will be on exhibit at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History March 1st-30th with special events on 3/22: World Water Day.

They travel to the Great Lakes Science Center for April, with special events on Earth Day. 

State cuts in cultural funding has kept museums from more support. This is a creative idea to help residents embrace water conservation and draw in more reluctant participants. The exhibit will travel NEOhio nature centers and parks for at least a year, and we’d like to offer workshops to all of our hosts.

7 of our artists are paid, but 5 more are waiting; not having received all of the grants we applied for, we'll borrow past artists painted barrels from our workshops, to be replaced as we receive funding (these artists want to install and reuse their own rain water in the Spring).

Here on the North Coast of the US, in Cleveland Ohio, we are a block away from Lake Erie: One of the largest freshwater sources in the world.

Surface rainwater sweeps motor vehicle, lawn chemicals and pet waste that combine with storm water runoff into sewers, and overflow, untreated, into the Lake. This slurry, along with excess industrial farm fertilizer and winter road salt are causing toxic algae blooms, dead zones, and endangering the health of this freshwater source.

Rain Barrels help keep surface water onsite at homes, OUT of the sewer! Rain Barrels are practical but NOT pretty.

In fact they are: Quite Gnarly.

We want them to be Beautiful and COOL to OWN and USE.

Our exhibit will expose many thousands of museum and park visitors to the potential for BEAUTY, FREE WATER and that WE ALL can help keep our Lake and Waterways CLEANER!

The photos in the slideshow are from my own pilot painted rain barrel that sparked this project. Neighborhood workshops are included as we raise funds and our community benefits. The ‘We are Sustainable’ image is from Cleveland Mayor Frank Jackson’s Office of Sustainability, who used my barrel in their Summit poster project.

We’re Partially Funded by:

Green City/Blue Lake Institute, Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District, Cleveland Water Pollution Control, Cleveland Lakefront Parks Conservancy.

Every dollar will help, even if we don’t make our goal. 

If we go over our goal, we’ll hire more artists to paint barrels, to auction to help fund more workshops. 

When artists work, we invest in our communities: win/win/win.

If you can’t contribute – please SHARE this with your Social Media followers more than once, Thanks!!

Donors will receive FUN & AWESOME PREMIUM GIFTS!

If you want your donation to be tax deductible go to www.paintedrainbarrel.org

Thank you for your support!

Linda Zolten Wood

story:
The FJMC Shomrei Ha’aretz “Guardians of the Land” program is an environmental initiative that provides programming and materials to congregations and their families. Part of this effort is devoted to encouraging our friends to support Israel’s environmental efforts.

This year one of FJMC’s leaders, Mark Druy, will be participating in a bike ride from Jersulaem to Eilat in November 2014 on behalf of the Arava Institute & Hazon in support of this premier environmental facility and its partner Hazon.

Mark and his Minutemenschen team are passionate about giving back.  Our support of their ride helps the Arava Institute and Hazon solve serious environmental issues facing Israel and its neighbors.

You can help ensure the success of this amazing effort.

This Indiegogo campaign is a wonderful way for FJMC members, their friends, neighbors and others to spread the word and support both Israel and Mark’s efforts.

For every donation toward the goal of $ 6,000 dollars for the Arava Institute/Hazon Israel Ride there will be a matching contribution to the FJMC Foundation for Jewish Life.

Arava Institute/
Hazon Israel Ride
Jerusalem to Eilat
Nov 4, 2014 to Nov 11, 2014

story:
Thank you to all the funders and the testimonials!
We fell short of the minimum target, but you can find updates here: CieloBuio

Testimonials

Dr. Malcolm Smith, Astronomer, former AURA Observatories Director in Chile and Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory Director

'This important new system concept is an efficient, practical and low-cost contribution to the effort now getting under way in many parts of the world to improve the use of light - by directing it just to where it is needed.   This will contribute to reducing costly and unnecessary waste, as well as reducing damage to the environment and to human health.'


Dr. Travis Longcore, Professorof Spatial Sciences at University of Southern California, Science Director of The Urban Wildlands Group, editor of the book Ecological Consequences of Artificial Night Lighting

'Light pollution and its effects on humans and other species alike can be reduced in five ways -- turning off unneeded lights, reducing light intensity, limiting duration, using an appropriate spectrum of light, and directing the light only where it is necessary.  Directing light appropriately for single fixtures may be straightforward, but it is much more complex for large surfaces emitting light.  Falchi offers a novel solution to the challenge of properly directly light from surfaces, with the promise of reducing the adverse effects of such sources on the night sky and the nocturnal environment. '


Prof. Paul Bogard, author of the best seller 'The End of Night':

'Wonderful news for anyone who loves a starry night!  Now, for the first time, we have a way to control the polluting light from luminous signs. The question has always been how to allow luminous signs in the night without casting glare, polluting the night, and wiping away the stars. The intense light from these signs is too often sent straight into the sky, into our eyes, into our bedrooms. This new product offers an answer to please both owners of signs and those who care about preserving our nights, an answer to please us all.'


Pedro Sanhueza Pérez, Director OPCC - Oficina de Protección de la Calidad del Cielo del Norte de Chile (Institute for the protection of sky quality in Northern Chile)

'The impact of billboards in light pollution is growing enormously due to the new  LED big screens being installed around the world. They were originally designed to work with day light, but now it is common to use them at night time, provoking a significant negative impact on the quality on the night. For this reason, the new revolutionary system proposed by Dr. Fabio Falchi, which redirects the light from luminous signs, reducing the upper hemisphere emission, is quite significant. So, wonderful news for the night environment.'


Pierantonio Cinzano, Ph.D., President of ISTIL - Light Pollution Science and Technology Intitute; author of the first book on light pollution 'inquinamento luminoso e protezione del cielo notturno', 1996'

It is fundamental that progress and development of lighting being directed toward lowering environmental impact and toward a better control of light. Dr. Falchi's research to get a new type of luminous sign can be a decisive step forward in this sector. In fact, up to now the only way to limit light pollution from luminous signs was to reduce their light, by diminishing their number, dimensions and luminosity.'


Cipriano Marín, Coordinator of the Starlight Initiative & Secretary General of the UNESCO Center of the Canary Islands.

'Curbing light pollution need real and smart solutions. The luminous signs and billboards contribute significantly to increase light pollution, but their adverse effects may be easily avoided. The ground-breaking project led by Dr. Falchi is a significant step towards the common commitment to reverse this trend. A milestone which will save energy, better protect the environment, improve the quality of life and recover the starlight. The solutions are in our hands.'


Dr. Tyler Nordgren, astronomer at University of Redlands, former board member International Dark-Sky Association, author of Stars Above, Earth Below: A Guide to Astronomy in the National Parks., is a new testimonial of the campaign.

Every year more billboards are installed along America's interstate freeway system and every year more of those are converted to electronic signs. The growing light from these signs is already impacting previously pristine skies over America's National Parks. This technology has the power to protect these last remaining dark-sky sanctuaries from lights that will only increase in number and brightness with time.

Javier Díaz Castro, Ms Electrical & Industrial Engineer,  Chief OTPC (Oficina Técnica para la Protección de la Calidad del Cielo - Technical Office for the Sky Quality Protection) in Instituto de Astrofísica de Canarias.

'This new optical system is very effective to dramatically reduce the contribution to light pollution by backlit signs (light boxes) and LED screens. These luminaries are a big portion in the overall contribution of light pollution (up to 50% in places where lighting is used with reduced light pollution).
I encouraged you so that this project comes to fruition to improve our environment and our health'.

Light Pollution?

Light pollution is one of the most pervasive forms of pollution on the planet. More than 60% of the world’s population live under polluted skies, and in developed countries the total is nearly 100%!

In the last 100 years we have gradually enveloped ourselves in a luminous fog that has diminished the night. All life on Earth has evolved over billions of years with the alternating pattern of light during day and dark during the night. But we upset this natural rhythm in the twinkling of an eye.

Light pollution destroys the chance to admire the greatest nature wonder of all: our own universe. Our children grow up without the possibility of taking inspiration from a starry sky: inspiration that accompanied humanity from the beginning of time and has profound roots in religion, philosophy, literature, and science.

I worked on light pollution for more than 20 years, as a researcher at ISTIL - Light Pollution Science and Technology Institute (http://www.istil.eu) and as president of CieloBuio, Association for the protection of the night sky (http://www.cielobuio.org). At ISTIL we realized the first world atlas of light pollution (http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/328/3/689.short).

CieloBuio was able, with our hard work, to help protect most of Italy with laws against light pollution. Laws that inspired foreign countries such as Slovenja, Chile, Spain, Czeck Republic to follow the example. More than 50 millions people benefit of these laws.

Luminous signs are one of the most polluting sources of light. We found a way to almost null their impact to the sky and to diminish their glaring effects. We need your help to protect and develop this idea toward a functioning product.


We lose the starry sky

Everyone, until the advent of light pollution could admire the Milky Way, our own galaxy, crossing the sky from horizon to horizon, like in this all-sky photo taken from a remote site in Namibian desert. It is a breath taking experience we cannot anymore enjoy.

Now we can see only artificial lights, everywhere but the remotest sites of all. Even in the National Parks of South West USA it is almost impossible to have the nocturnal landscape not ruined by light domes at the horizon.

Alps are polluted by cities that may be hundred of kilometres away.

Our are the first generations that grown up without the possibility of being inspired by the starry sky. This is a huge cultural loss.


The Impact on Environmeent and our Health

'What if we woke up one morning to realize that all conservation planning of the last 30 years told only half the story - the daytime story?'- Catherine Rich and Travis Longcore in Ecological Consequences of Artificial Night Lighting

Light pollution also has profound negative consequences on the environment. A majority of animal species are nocturnal, and as such, they regulate all their activities in the natural light available, from the lowest levels of a cloudy night with no moon to the brightest nights around full moon. Man has upset all this in the last decades.

Moths and other insects are fatally attracted by artificial lights, destroying the natural food chain.

Fireflies cannot mate in our ever glowing night environment.

Sea turtle babies follow the artificial lights and miss the sea, going to die on the following day.

These are only few examples of light pollution consequences on environment.

Exposing our body to light during the night is not a wise thing. Our health too is affected by the disruption of our circadian rhythms. Melatonin production is lowered or stopped even with our modern times 'normal' nocturnal light levels of artificial light.


How to stop light pollution?

While most types of lighting can now be less polluting—street lighting can be done with fully shielded luminaires, parking lots too, and even stadium lighting can be made in lower polluting versions—one source of light pollution remains as polluting as ever: luminous advertising signs. Both static and dynamic types pollute in every direction, unless you shut off them.

Until now.

We have found a way to lower light pollution and glare form luminous signs without compromising their visibility from where usually the observer is: on the ground. Those who live near luminous signs will no longer have his or her bedroom lighted by these lights, while those who are walking on the street will see shop signs as usual.

How does it work?

The product will be a plastic film with optical properties that will allow light from signs to go only where needed—not into the sky, into the night environment or into bedrooms.

We have already performed optical software simulations showing that the signs will be as bright as usual toward the observers, but will be almost black as seen from above.

A luminous sign as is now, it shines in all directions:


While a luminous sign equipped with the anti-light pollution film shines only where needed:



We need your help

The next step will be the protection of the technology and the production of prototypes. For this your support is fundamental. With the subsequent step we aim to start the production of the film to make it available to the sign market.

With your contribution you'll help to eliminate undesired light from advertising luminous signs. The light pollution from signs will be a bad memory of the past.

Even if you cannot contribute with money, you'll be able to help by making this campaign known between your contacts, being them journalists, bloggers or interested people. Make this known in the social networks. Indiegogo has tools to share the campaign!

Your action will help to choose between this:

Or this:

The starry sky, the night environment and your health will THANK YOU!

bedroom lighted by these lights, while those who are walking on the street will
see shop signs as usual.
How does it
work?
The product
will be a plastic film with optical properties that will allow light from signs
to go only where needed—not into the sky, into the night environment or into bedrooms.
We have already performed optical software
simulations showing that the signs will be as bright as usual toward the
observers, but will be almost black as seen from above.A luminous
sign as is now, it shines in all directions:
While a luminous
sign equipped with the anti-light pollution film shines only where needed:
We need your help
The next
step will be the protection of the technology and the production of prototypes.
For this your support is fundamental. With the subsequent step we aim to start
the production of the film to make it available to the sign market. 
With your
contribution you'll help to eliminate undesired light from advertising luminous
signs. The light pollution from signs will be a bad memory of the past.
Even if you cannot contribute with money, you'll be able to help by making this campaign known between your contacts, being them journalists, bloggers or interested people. Make this known in the social networks. Indiegogo has tools to share the campaign!Your action will help to choose between this:Or this:
The starry
sky, the night environment and your health will THANK YOU!

story: Red is a hard working college boy.  He has two full time jobs while he is home for the summer.   Red has been walking several miles everyday, as the bikes he has have broken down, and he has no other way.  Although Red kept saying he doesn't beg,  All the money he makes goes to tuition.  This funding is hooked directly to Reds Bank card account.  Lets help this fine young man get to his jobs!

story:
THE BIG IDEA


Studying at the Royal Ontario Museum, we are a group of Environmental Visual Communication students from Fleming College, working to accelerate the conversation around Ontario’s renewable energy commitment. With your help, our goal is to use our visual storytelling expertise to communicate the urgency for a shift to renewable energy. 

At the center of this campaign is an event taking place on November 23rd at Steam Whistle Brewing in Toronto. The objective of our event? Inspire Ontario policy makers to pledge to adopt 100% renewable energy resolutions for 2050.

On the evening of the event, we are gathering corporate leaders, business owners, renewable energy leaders, and concerned citizens like you to show decision makers in Ontario that we are able to do this.

The storage technology for renewable energy is improving and the cost of it is declining. The transition to 100% renewable energy is already happening in Ontario’s own Oxford County. We can show policy makers that the practices in Oxford County are scalable to cities big and small across the province.

We need to take Ontario’s energy future into our own hands.

To do this, we must raise $5,000 $7,000 to fund our event on November 23rd.

What We Need & What You Get

Our team needs to cover costs for:

  • Venue
  • Speakers’ travel
  • Audiovisual infrastructure
  • Catering expenses

You don't have to attend the event to enjoy the perks of donating!

Our exciting list of perks can be found in the column to the right, such as original artwork by the Woodland Sisters, 100by2050 posters, and behind the scenes tours of the Royal Ontario Museum. Also, everyone who donates will be recognized in a tribute of gratitude at the event!

Perks

 Thanks to the generous help from our partners, we have some great perks for you!


The Impact

This is bigger than one night. It’s time to put our money where our mouth is. It’s happening – yes, climate change is happening now. We know it, we see it, and we feel it. In the warming oceans and the forest fires and the smoggy air we breathe. And we have the chance now to make a change – to make strides in getting back that fresh air, in taking back our right to a healthy environment.

With your help, we can accelerate the conversation on Canada’s renewable energy plan. Join us, be a part of the impact, break ground with us as we lead the rest of this country by example. We need to inspire our policy makers to champion a direction towards clean energy.


Risks & Challenges

The greatest challenge we face is proving to our audience that 100% renewable energy by 2050 is possible. With strong leadership from Oxford County Warden David Mayberry and Dr. Jose Etcheverry, we can demonstrate that this is possible. With the right policy we can reach a 100% by 2050 goal. 

The other challenge would be not having enough Ontario leaders in attendance at the event. This is where you come in - see below to find out how you can help us get more policy makers in the audience!


Other Ways You Can Help

Let your family and friends know that 100% renewable is possible and spread the word about this event! 

Make a call, write an email or tweet “We are able to go 100% renewable energy by the year 2050” to your local politicians, asking them to come to our event and make the pledge to go 100% renewable now.

Sponsors

A huge thank you for your generous support!

story:
The Vision

We see a future where each community can provide its own energy, a future where we don’t have to rely on someone else to provide what we need to thrive.  A future that starts with you.

The purpose of this plant is to create a precedence of biodiesel-producing facilities that not only create many local jobs, but strive to keep the product as well as the revenues local.

The issue that America faces right now is that a large portion of biodiesel production gets shipped overseas where someone else gluts themselves on the benefit of our labors.

You think we’re just creating hype, don’t you?  Well, if that’s truly what you think, check out this website. 

Can we move on now?  …Thank you.


So how do I contribute on Indiegogo?

That's simple! Just mouse over the right hand column for your desired contribution amount. The box will highlight itself then all you have to do is click it and check out!


What’s so great about biodiesel?

Don’t you wish there was a way to take what we put in our landfills and create non-toxic, clean-burning fuel that costs less than the dinosaur-infused muck at the pumps?  Well, so do we.  For some time now.  It turns out that there is an awesome opportunity to do just that.  We present for your amazement (pause for effect): Biodiesel!

“What is that?” you ask?  Well, my fossil-burning friend, that is your future.

Biodiesel is created by recycling used cooking greases that would have ended up in the ground to pollute and dirtify our groundwater for centuries to come.  The grease is converted into premium fuel that emits almost no emissions.  

Yep, we turn trash into blue skies, green grass, and, subsequently, happy squirrels.  

You’re welcome, environment.  We won’t even mention all the yummy-smelling exhaust from everyone’s trucks and buses.  Hey!  With all the good smells in the air, our local restaurants will gain even higher traffic numbers, pumping even more money into the economy and even more recyclable grease into the refinery!  Biodiesel, you do it all, don’t you?

Biodiesel has been around for 20 years and it has become one of the best renewable fuels around.




Why do we need you?

This is where you come in.  We need your help somethin’ fierce.

As you may have guessed, biodiesel refineries don’t grow on trees (no, they’re born and raised by diesel dwarves).

A biodiesel plant in southern Utah has been fully constructed, but sits vacant because of some minimal, but necessary repairs to meet building codes.  Our intention is to rebuild this outdated plant into a state-of-the-art facility able to produce premium-quality, clean-burning biodiesel from recycled cooking greases right here in Southern Utah! 

What happens if we don’t reach our goal?  Well, you’ll soon learn that we don’t give up that easily.  We’ll begin another campaign and another and another until we DO reach our goal.  So your contribution will ultimately lead to a viral video of squirrels dancing in commemoration of the day when all became right in the world!  You’re welcome, internet.


What do you get outta this? 

(the perks!)

Yes, that’s right. You get rewarded for your kind, selfless philanthropy to the diesel arts. The below list exhausts (Get it?  Exhausts?) all the perks you get for being a ground-floor contributor.

These perks are sick! 

Take your pick!

  • Premium Biodiesel

    • Take your pick between B20 or B99. 

    • B20 is the designation for a blend of 20% premium biodiesel and 80% regular diesel. This is the blend most commonly warrantied by vehicle manufacturers. (Even all those premium cars like Mercedes, Audi, and BMW!)  We’ll blend it for you so all you have to do is fill-er up and enjoy!

  • Your name listed as a supporter on our facebook & website (if you want)

  • Personalized Thank You email

  • Personal Thank You postcard mailed to your home or office

  • "I Support Biodiesel" stickers

  • Custom Designed t-Shirt

  • Eco-Tec Biofuels Hat

  • Personal Thank You "Swag Bag"

    • One Personal Thank You

    • One Custom Designed Shirt

    • One Custom Designed Hat

    • "I Support Biodiesel" sticker

  • VIP invite to the grand opening party (food, drinks, and live entertainment)

  • 50 minute couples massage at the Red Mountain Resort

  • 2 night stay at the 7 Wives Bed & Breakfast

  • Private 3 hour Hot Air Balloon Ride over beautiful southern UTAH!! (for 2 people)

  • Private 90 Mile helicopter tour over beautiful Zion's National Park in Southern Utah!

  • Private 100 mile Helicopter tour over beautiful Southern Utah! You'll see Zion's National Park, St. George, UT, and Snow Canyon State Park all from a bird's eye view!

  • 3 night stay at Zion Canyon Bed and Breakfast in "The Master" room with car rental and 3 day Zion's Park pass

  • 3 night stay in a private cabin at "The Lodge" in beautiful Bryce Canyon National Park with a guided private Horseback tour into the park and a 3 day park pass, fuel card, and a premium car rental from St. George, UT

  • Your name (or business name) on a custom commemorative plaque displayed in our office lobby for life.

    • 1 inch thick CNC Engraved wall plaque to show the world how amazing you are and how much you really care. It will also serve as a constant reminder to us of how generous you were in helping this project to get started.

  • Custom Limited Edition Skimboard - Custom made FOR YOU! That includes artwork chosen by YOU and customized to have what you want on it. 

    • We've teamed up with a local board manufacturer to bring you this seriously sick perk!

What could mess this whole thing up?

Every great venture has its risks and challenges, and we can think of none more challenging than making the world a better place for ourselves and all the woodland creatures.

We’ll run up against:

  • Unforeseeable expenditures and delays
  • Bitter and overworked inspectors
  • Greedy, bureaucratic politicians only looking out for their own agenda
  • Unmotivated [insert job title here]'s
  • Spiders
  • A host of other scary things we don’t want to bring up for fear of relapsing from all of our current progress toward being functional human beings

The above list is non-exhaustive (get it yet?), but gives a good overall landscape of the types of things that may create obstacles between us and every squirrel’s dream.


About Us (yes, we’re still talking about ourselves)

I bet you're cynically asking through your screen right now, "Why should I hand you my hard-earned money?  What makes you think YOU can do this?" 

Well, did we tell you that our co-founder, Robert Anderson, was integral in building the now-vacant refinery?  Not only that, but Robert has much experience in diesel mechanics and has built his own diesel engines and trucks for many years. Not to mention, his extreme fondness for anything diesel makes him the perfect man for the job of building a sustainable source of literal fuel for his never-ending projects.  

Our other co-founder, Grant Woodbury (aka Woody), has a proven track record of successful Entrepreneurial Ventures.  Woody brings a fresh, kind, firm, and warm professionalism that makes this pair driven and unstoppable (as well as more appealing to all things adorable) in our quest to world cooperation. Woody is a so Cal surfer with a passion for business and a serious love for the outdoors and extreme sports! He believes that "Wisdom is simply the proper application knowledge." That means the most excellent of leaders have wisdom because they apply knowledge to benefit others, not themselves. His passion for the success of small business is what drives his desire to find a better way to help others through business. For by giving to others all they desire you will receive even more in return.

The expertise and experience of these two came together to create Anderwood Ventures. Anderwood is focused on building profitable, community-centered and environmentally-friendly businesses.


What do we need from you?

In a word, money.       

In another word, publicity.

If you feel that fulfilling your own needs are more important than leaving the world a better place, we won’t judge you (very much).  However, you can redeem yourself by sharing the heck out of this campaign.  Feel free to use Indiegogo’s sharing tools, Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, Instagram, or any other favorite social media platform to get the word out!  

Share it with friends, family, and acquaintances!  Share it with the nice policeman who pulls you over for excessive speeding.  Share it with the nice judge at your court hearing for your aforementioned crime (try to tell the judge before you get sentenced so maybe your sentence will be reduced because she’ll see that you really want to change and become a contributing member of society and model citizen.  You’re welcome, convicted criminal).

The more people this message reaches, the cleaner the environment, and the more cute, fuzzy animals you save.

In yet another word, thanks.  Cuz you’re our hero.


So let’s take a look at the Biodiesel process. (yep, we’re still here)

Although the diesel dwarves work hard we have to work a little harder to bring this amazing renewable fuel to reality. The process is fairly simple and you can see it below. 

  1. Waste greases are deposited into a collection container… 
  2. Company trucks collect the grease and bring it back to the plant… 
  3. Grease is processed into usable feedstocks… 
  4. The feedstock is refined into Premium Quality Biodiesel… 
  5. Then we blend it with petroleum diesel to a B20 (okay so it’s really whatever blend you want)… 
  6. And then we truck it to our customers! (Oh and our trucks will run 100% Biodiesel too)

it really is that simple!


Now how do I contribute on Indiegogo?

That's simple! Just mouse over the right hand column for your desired contribution amount. The box will highlight itself then all you have to do is click it and check out!

story:
Für Deutsche Fassung hier klicken!/Click here for German version!

Help researching South American moths

Hello, my name is Patrick Strutzenberger, I am an evolutionary biologist working in collaboration with the University of Vienna (Austria). I have devoted most of my career to researching South American moths.

What will be funded?

The "product" resulting from this campaign is a publication in a scientific journal. This publication will describe results gained from analyzing the evolution of a group of moths called Psaliodes. The plan is to submit the manuscript to the journal in November/December of this year for a publication sometime in the first half of 2018.

Why study moths?

In comparison to butterflies moths are flying under the public radar. This is also true in science, moths are dangerously under-studied. However, moths are much more diverse than butterflies and at least as beautiful as butterflies are. For the topics that are to be studied here moths are actually far more interesting, their high diversity allows to study their evolution in detail. A lot of data is required to reconstruct evolutionary processes. This amount of data can only be provided through the study of highly diverse groups of animals. The study of these moths is therefore essential to resolve why there are so many species in the tropics. Tropical ecosystems exhibit unimaginable complexity, conservation of these ecosystems is dependent on detailed knowledge on what factors are responsible for their complexity in the first place. We are just now beginning to understand these factors and their effects.

Where do they live?

The South American Andes are one of the most bio-diverse regions on the planet. Most groups of land animals and plants have some of their highest species numbers worldwide in the Andes. The cloud forests of the northern Andes are known to harbor an exceptionally high number of moth species. In a tiny area of only two square kilometers in Ecuador researchers have found over 1400 species just from one single family of moths. Most of those species are not even named yet and there are countless more species yet to be discovered.

What exactly will be studied?

Over the past 15 years researchers have collected a large number of moths in the South American Andes. In these studies people were focused on determining how many moths are present and how they are distributed. The moths collected during this studies are now available for further research. Instead of simply asking the questions "who?" and "where?" the purpose of this campaign is to ask "how?".

  • How come that this region harbors that many species?
  • When did these species arise?
  • Did species evolve at a constant rate or in bursts?
  • How are they related to other moths?

I am going to use DNA sequences to delve into detail of one group of moths. The genus Psaliodes is one the most commonly found moths in this area and is part of the family of inchworm moths (Geometridae). The moths have already been sorted, photographically documented and DNA sequences have been acquired in a laboratory at the University of Vienna.

I will use state of the art algorithms to calculate a phylogenetic tree. This tree will tell us how the moths are related to each other. The length of the branches on this tree tells us how distant the species are from each other. Relating those distances to geological time allows us to calculate when and how fast the moths evolved.

What I Need

The optimal funding level for this campaign is 4000 Euros. With this amount of funding I will be able to analyze the data to the fullest extent possible and make the best possible contribution to the knowledge of earth's biodiversity.

Primary items your contribution will fund:

  • The core of this project is analyzing the data and writing a publication. This is very time consuming. I need financial support that permits me to devote time to this project.
  • Maintenance and improvement of computer hardware required to analyze the data, especially the purchase of urgently required hard drives to store the large amount of data generated during analyses.
  • Covering the rent for a Linux server to be used for data analysis.
  • Cover cost for software licenses.

Cost breakdown:

 

If the campaign does NOT meet its goal I will focus funding on essential items only. That means that all focus will be on submitting the publication. In this case the analyses will be less in-depth and the data cannot be used to its full potential. This will ensure that the data will still get published and is available to everybody. Other researchers are then able to use the data for further research.

If the campaign exceeds its goal all funds will be used to either extend the scope of the present project or alternatively will be used to improve infrastructure or go directly to fund the next project. Here are some examples for items that could be funded when this campaign exceeds its goal:

  • Cover open-access publication fees for the planned publication. Those fees are usually between 1500 and 3000 Euros, depending on the journal. This will increase the visibility of this research and make it accessible to everyone, even those who don't have access to costly journal subscriptions.
  • Support subsequent efforts to describe and name so far unnamed species
  • Contracting additional team members for specific tasks and therefore increase the quality of the publication and reduce the time required.
  • Creation of a website to spread the word about South American moths.
  • Contribute to the next project! If this campaign exceeds its goal by a large margin all supporters will be asked to vote on which group of moths to tackle next.

I can guarantee that every Euro being raised will directly contribute to the research on South American moths. The possibilities are endless.

Risks & Challenges

The campaigner and project leader is very experienced in this field of science and has published numerous publications in scientific journals. See here for a list of my publications in the same field of science.The most risky parts of doing research in the tropics have already been completed. The moths have already been collected and DNA sequences are ready for analysis. The most challenging part that remains is getting the publication out. Scientific journals use a process called "peer-review" to assess the quality of manuscripts prior to publication. During this process the journal will send the manuscript to other scientist for review. This assures that only scientifically sound studies will get published. It is hard to estimate how long this process will take, it might take anywhere from a few weeks to a few months. It is therefore hard to predict when exactly this research will be published. However, judging from experience I estimate that the publication should be out in the first half of 2018.

What do you get?

Apart from supporting important scientific research you can choose from a selection of awesome perks all of them featuring pictures of beautiful moths. Regardless of the contributed amount every supporter will be sent an electronic version (pdf file) of the resulting publication as soon as it is published.

If you get a perk containing a print you will be asked to select which moth you want on your print at the end of the campaign. If you get more than one perk containing a print you can choose a different one for each print.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this page with your friends
  • Follow the campaign on Twitter
  • Subscribe to the MothResearch Youtube channel

Pictures of other moths from the Andes. These are also examples for pictures that will be used for the calendar, greeting cards, postcards and prints.

 

 

Helfen Sie Südamerikanische Nachtfalter zu erforschen

Willkommen, mein Name ist Patrick Strutzenberger. Ich bin Evolutionsbiologe und arbeite derzeit mit Wissenschaftlern der Universität Wien zusammen. Schon seit meiner Diplomarbeit interessiere ich mich für die Erforschung südamerikanischer Nachtfalter.

Was soll finanziert werden?

Das „Produkt“ dieser Kampagne ist eine wissenschaftliche Publikation in einer Fachzeitschrift. Darin sollen Ergebnisse aus der Untersuchung zur Evolution der Nachtfaltergattung Psaliodes veröffentlicht werden. Ich plane das Manuskript im November/Dezember dieses Jahres bei einer Zeitschrift einzureichen, so dass es in der ersten Jahreshälfte 2018 veröffentlicht werden kann.

Warum Nachtfalter?

Nachtfalter stehen in der öffentlichen Wahrnehmung sehr oft im Schatten der Tagfalter. Auch in der Wissenschaft sind Nachtfalter vergleichsweise weniger untersucht, obwohl sie mindestens genauso hübsch sind wie Tagfalter. Hinsichtlich der Fragestellungen, die hier untersucht werden sollen sind Nachtfalter sogar viel interessanter als Tagfalter. Um Evolutionsprozesse im Detail zu untersuchen, wird eine große Menge an Daten benötigt, die nur aus sehr artenreichen Tiergruppen gewonnen werden können. Um zu verstehen warum es in den Tropen so viele Arten gibt ist die Forschung an diesen Nachtfaltern unverzichtbar. Tropische Ökosysteme weisen eine unvorstellbar hohe Komplexität auf. Der Schutz dieser Ökosysteme ist nur dann möglich, wenn man die Faktoren die zu dieser Komplexität geführt haben, kennt. Erst vor kurzem hat man begonnen diese Faktoren und deren Effekte zu verstehen.

Wo leben diese Nachtfalter?

Die südamerikanischen Anden sind eine der artenreichsten Regionen auf unserem Planeten mit einer der höchsten Artenzahlen an Tieren und Pflanzen weltweit. Die Nebelwälder der nördlichen Anden sind bekannt dafür, dass sie eine besonders hohe Zahl an Nachfalterarten beherbergen. In einem winzigen, nur etwa zwei Quadratkilometer großen Gebiet in Ecuador, haben Wissenschaftler über 1400 Arten aus nur einer einzigen Familie von Nachtfaltern gefunden. Die meisten dieser Arten haben nicht einmal einen Namen und viele weitere sind noch gar nicht entdeckt worden.

Was genau soll untersucht werden?

In den letzten 15 Jahren wurden im Rahmen mehrerer Studien eine große Anzahl an Nachtfaltern in den Anden gesammelt. Es wurde untersucht wie viele Arten in den Bergregenwäldern in Süd-Ecuador vorkommen und wie sie verbreitet sind. Die Tiere die in diesen Projekten gesammelt wurden, stehen mir nun für weitere Forschung zur Verfügung. Anstatt der Beantwortung der Fragen "Wer?" und "Wo?", dient diese Kampagne dazu die weitaus spannendere Frage des "Wie?" zu beantworten.

  • Warum gibt es in dieser Region so viele Arten?
  • Wann sind diese Arten entstanden?
  • Sind diese Arten über die Zeit gleichmäßig verteilt oder unterschiedlich schnell entstanden?
  • Wie sind diese Falter mit anderen Faltern verwandt?

In diesem Projekt, dass ich hier finanzieren möchte, werde ich zur Beantwortung dieser Fragen DNA Sequenzen verwenden. Die Gattung Psaliodes ist eine der häufigsten in der Region und gehört zur Familie der Spanner (Geometridae). Die Tiere sind bereits sortiert und fotografiert und zusätzlich wurden DNA Sequenzen in einem Labor an der Universität Wien gewonnen.

Ich werde diese DNA Sequenzen verwenden, um mit den aktuellsten Methoden einen Stammbaum zu berechnen. Dieser Stammbaum zeigt das Verwandtschaftsverhältnis der Nachtfalter und die Länge der Äste zeigt, wie stark sich die Arten voneinander unterscheiden. Wenn man diese Unterschiede zur vergangenen geologischen Zeit in Bezug setzt, kann man berechnen, wann und wie schnell die Evolution dieser Falter erfolgt ist.

Was wird benötigt?

Das optimale Finanzierungsniveau ist 4000 Euro. Mit dieser Summe kann ich das ganze Potential der Daten ausschöpfen und damit den bestmöglichen Beitrag zur Biodiversitätsforschung veröffentlichen.

Was soll finanziert werden:

  • Der Hauptteil dieser Kampagne besteht darin Daten zu analysieren und ein Manuskript zu verfassen. Um mich diesem zeitintensivem Projekt widmen zu können benötige ich finanzielle Unterstützung.
  • Instandhaltung und Verbesserung von Computerhardware, insbesondere die Anschaffung von dringend benötigten Festplatten für die bei den Analysen generierten Daten.
  • Miete für einen Server der zur Datenauswertung benutzt wird.
  • Eventuelle Kosten für Softwarelizenzen.

Wenn die Kampagne das Ziel NICHT erreicht werde ich den Umfang auf die essentiellen Punkte reduzieren. Das bedeutet, dass der Schwerpunkt auf der zügigen Fertigstellung der Publikation liegen wird. In diesem Fall werden die Analysen weniger in die Tiefe gehen als bei einer vollen Finanzierung möglich wäre. Somit kann trotzdem sichergestellt werden, dass die vorliegenden Daten veröffentlicht werden und für andere zur Verfügung stehen.

Wenn die Kampagne das Ziel übertrifft wird die finanzierte Summe entweder verwendet um das derzeitige Projekt zu erweitern oder um Infrastruktur (z.b. Computerhardware) zu verbessern. Darüber hinaus gehen alle zusätzlich eingenommenen Unterstützungen direkt in mein nächstes Projekt. 

Einige Beispiele:

  • Abdeckung von Kosten für eine "open-access" Publikation. Diese Kosten liegen je nach Zeitschrift meist zwischen 1500 und 3000 Euro. Damit wäre sichergestellt, dass die Ergebnisse aus dieser Studie die maximale Verbreitung erreichen, besonders für alle Interessierten die keinen Zugang zu teuren Abos wissenschaftlicher Zeitschriften haben.
  • Unterstützung der anschließenden Beschreibung von bisher namenlosen Arten.
  • Bezahlung von weiteren Projektmitarbeitern die zusätzliche Aufgaben übernehmen können und damit diese Studie noch ausführlicher machen.
  • Unterstützung für das nächste Projekt! Wenn diese Kampagne das Ziel deutlich überschreiten sollte werden alle Unterstützer befragt welches Projekt als nächstes finanziert werden soll.

Ich kann versprechen, dass jeder Euro mit dem dieses Vorhaben unterstützt wird direkt in die Forschung an südamerikanischen Nachtfaltern fließt.

Risiken und Herausforderungen

Ich (Kampagnenführer und Projektleiter) bin in diesem Fachgebiet sehr erfahren und habe zahlreiche Publikationen in wissenschaftlichen Zeitschriften veröffentlicht. Klicken Sie hier für eine Liste meiner Publikationen in diesem Fachgebiet. Der riskanteste Teil dieses Projekts ist bereits abgeschlossen. Die Nachfalter wurden bereits gesammelt und die DNA Sequenzen sind zur Analyse bereit. Die größte verbleibende Herausforderung ist es, diese Studie zu veröffentlichen. Wissenschaftliche Zeitschriften verwenden das sogenannte "peer-review" Verfahren um die Qualität der Beiträge zu bewerten. Dabei wird das Manuskript an andere Wissenschaftler geschickt, die jeweils ein Gutachten erstellen. Dieser Prozess kann im besten Fall in wenigen Wochen abgeschlossen sein, wobei es auch mehrere Monate dauern kann. Es ist daher schwierig vorherzusehen wann die Studie veröffentlicht wird. Meiner Erfahrung nach würde ich davon ausgehen das die Studie in der ersten Jahreshälfte 2018 veröffentlicht werden wird.

Was bekommen Sie?

Sie können aus einer Vielzahl von Dankeschöns (Perks) wählen die alle mit Bildern von wunderschönen Nachtfaltern versehen sind. Zusätzlich bekommt unabhängig von der Höhe des Beitrags jede/r Unterstützer/in eine elektronische Version der Publikation zugesandt sobald diese erschienen ist.

Wenn Sie ein Dankeschön auswählen das einen Druck enthält dann werde ich Sie am Ende der Kampagne nach Ihrem bevorzugten Bild fragen. Wenn Sie mehr als einen Druck auswählen dann können Sie für jeden Druck ein anderes Bild wählen.

Andere Wege um zu helfen

  • Teilen Sie diese Seite mit Ihren Freunden
  • Folgen Sie der Kampagne auf Twitter
  • Abonnieren Sie den zur Kampagne gehörenden Youtube Kanal

story_txt:
Für Deutsche Fassung hier klicken!/Click here for German version! 
Help researching South American moths
Hello, my name is Patrick Strutzenberger, I am an evolutionary biologist working in collaboration with the University of Vienna (Austria). I have devoted most of my career to researching South American moths.
What will be funded?
The "product" resulting from this campaign is a publication in a scientific journal. This publication will describe results gained from analyzing the evolution of a group of moths called Psaliodes. The plan is to submit the manuscript to the journal in November/December of this year for a publication sometime in the first half of 2018.
Why study moths?
In comparison to butterflies moths are flying under the public radar. This is also true in science, moths are dangerously under-studied. However, moths are much more diverse than butterflies and at least as beautiful as butterflies are. For the topics that are to be studied here moths are actually far more interesting, their high diversity allows to study their evolution in detail. A lot of data is required to reconstruct evolutionary processes. This amount of data can only be provided through the study of highly diverse groups of animals. The study of these moths is therefore essential to resolve why there are so many species in the tropics. Tropical ecosystems exhibit unimaginable complexity, conservation of these ecosystems is dependent on detailed knowledge on what factors are responsible for their complexity in the first place. We are just now beginning to understand these factors and their effects.
Where do they live?
The South American Andes are one of the most bio-diverse regions on the planet. Most groups of land animals and plants have some of their highest species numbers worldwide in the Andes. The cloud forests of the northern Andes are known to harbor an exceptionally high number of moth species. In a tiny area of only two square kilometers in Ecuador researchers have found over 1400 species just from one single family of moths. Most of those species are not even named yet and there are countless more species yet to be discovered.

What exactly will be studied?
Over the past 15 years researchers have collected a large number of moths in the South American Andes. In these studies people were focused on determining how many moths are present and how they are distributed. The moths collected during this studies are now available for further research. Instead of simply asking the questions "who?" and "where?" the purpose of this campaign is to ask "how?".

How come that this region harbors that many species?
When did these species arise?
Did species evolve at a constant rate or in bursts?
How are they related to other moths?

I am going to use DNA sequences to delve into detail of one group of moths. The genus Psaliodes is one the most commonly found moths in this area and is part of the family of inchworm moths (Geometridae). The moths have already been sorted, photographically documented and DNA sequences have been acquired in a laboratory at the University of Vienna.

I will use state of the art algorithms to calculate a phylogenetic tree. This tree will tell us how the moths are related to each other. The length of the branches on this tree tells us how distant the species are from each other. Relating those distances to geological time allows us to calculate when and how fast the moths evolved.

What I Need
The optimal funding level for this campaign is 4000 Euros. With this amount of funding I will be able to analyze the data to the fullest extent possible and make the best possible contribution to the knowledge of earth's biodiversity.
Primary items your contribution will fund:

The core of this project is analyzing the data and writing a publication. This is very time consuming. I need financial support that permits me to devote time to this project.
Maintenance and improvement of computer hardware required to analyze the data, especially the purchase of urgently required hard drives to store the large amount of data generated during analyses.
Covering the rent for a Linux server to be used for data analysis.
Cover cost for software licenses.

Cost breakdown:

 
If the campaign does NOT meet its goal I will focus funding on essential items only. That means that all focus will be on submitting the publication. In this case the analyses will be less in-depth and the data cannot be used to its full potential. This will ensure that the data will still get published and is available to everybody. Other researchers are then able to use the data for further research.
If the campaign exceeds its goal all funds will be used to either extend the scope of the present project or alternatively will be used to improve infrastructure or go directly to fund the next project. Here are some examples for items that could be funded when this campaign exceeds its goal:

Cover open-access publication fees for the planned publication. Those fees are usually between 1500 and 3000 Euros, depending on the journal. This will increase the visibility of this research and make it accessible to everyone, even those who don't have access to costly journal subscriptions.
Support subsequent efforts to describe and name so far unnamed species
Contracting additional team members for specific tasks and therefore increase the quality of the publication and reduce the time required.
Creation of a website to spread the word about South American moths.
Contribute to the next project! If this campaign exceeds its goal by a large margin all supporters will be asked to vote on which group of moths to tackle next.

I can guarantee that every Euro being raised will directly contribute to the research on South American moths. The possibilities are endless.
Risks & Challenges
The campaigner and project leader is very experienced in this field of science and has published numerous publications in scientific journals. See here for a list of my publications in the same field of science.The most risky parts of doing research in the tropics have already been completed. The moths have already been collected and DNA sequences are ready for analysis. The most challenging part that remains is getting the publication out. Scientific journals use a process called "peer-review" to assess the quality of manuscripts prior to publication. During this process the journal will send the manuscript to other scientist for review. This assures that only scientifically sound studies will get published. It is hard to estimate how long this process will take, it might take anywhere from a few weeks to a few months. It is therefore hard to predict when exactly this research will be published. However, judging from experience I estimate that the publication should be out in the first half of 2018.
What do you get?
Apart from supporting important scientific research you can choose from a selection of awesome perks all of them featuring pictures of beautiful moths. Regardless of the contributed amount every supporter will be sent an electronic version (pdf file) of the resulting publication as soon as it is published.
If you get a perk containing a print you will be asked to select which moth you want on your print at the end of the campaign. If you get more than one perk containing a print you can choose a different one for each print.
Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this page with your friends
Follow the campaign on Twitter

Subscribe to the MothResearch Youtube channel
