story:
What’s this all about?

The Inspiration
We are a group of five Portland High School students seeking to determine the ways in which culture, education, and values inform sustainability behaviors. Our members include Jeremy Ravenelle, Kowsar Ahmed, Maria Mirijanyan, Victoria Webber, and Meghan Kelly. Through our experience with projects in Environmental Club, such as recycling in our school cafeteria, we know how difficult it is to change people’s behaviors. We also know that these behaviors are affecting the world around us and that the impacts of climate change are growing in our world.

Gathering Information
To help us determine the root of some of these behaviors, we will use a survey distributed to people in Stockholm, Sweden, Archangelsk, Russia, and Portland, Maine with a separate focus on the immigrant population.  To fully understand the data we receive from the survey and the cultures which we study, it is important that we travel to Archangelsk and Stockholm.  This will allow us to collect qualitative data directly, in the form of personal observations and interviews. Field work will also enable the development of a peer-to-peer exchange between all three communities, which will help the data gathered through our research to generate local, sustainable action.

Future Impacts
Once the data and observations are collected, the information will be used in classes at our school such as statistics, environmental science and psychology.  We hope this project will have positive impacts on our school as students embark on action projects that incorporate lessons learned from this research.  It will also provide information for future projects at the high schools in Archangelsk and Stockholm, and provide a catalyst for global change through our peer to peer exchange.

Where Will the Money Go?

The money that we hope to receive will go toward our travel expenses to both Sweden and Russia. If we are unable to reach our goal fewer people will be able to go. However, it is crucial to our project to have at least two people collect qualitative data. Below is a breakdown of funding for one student.

Budget for Sustainable Communities Research

Travel: (For 1 student) Airfare (Round trip)-

Boston, Massachusetts to Stockholm, Sweden (Arlanda) $749*

Bus fare (Round trip)- Stockholm Arlanda Airport to city of Stockholm $24

Airfare (Round trip)- Stockholm Arlanda to Moscow, Russia $170 Train fare (Round trip)- Moscow Airport to Yaroslavsky Station, Moscow $20

Train fare (Round trip)- Moscow to Archangelsk, Russia $160

Food while traveling $100

Total: $1223*

Total for 4 students and advisor $6115*

*Based on estimated airfare for flights that have fluctuated in price.

Our Past Projects
In the past we have been able to accomplish smaller projects in our school. In the spring of 2012 Maria and Meghan conducted a project to reduce energy consumption by turning off hallway lights. At the same time, Jeremy decided to research energy consumption by school desktop computers. He concluded that many are left on constantly so he proposed to teachers and faculty that they turn them off when not in use. He had data to back up his proposal and was able to demonstrate to teachers the benefit of turning off their computer. Both of these projects proved to have epic impacts as they helped Portland High School reduce its electricity consumption by 29% between the fall of 2012 and fall of 2013.

We Want You!
Our group is ready to embark on this new project and we would love to have you on our team through your support and any funding that you are able to offer. Even if you are unable to donate, we are still in need of your help. We would love for you to get the word out in any way you can (please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!). More information can be found at http://www.gscproject.com/. Thank you so much, and welcome to the team!
story_txt:
What’s this all about?The InspirationWe are a group of five Portland High School students seeking to determine the ways in which culture, education, and values inform sustainability behaviors. Our members include Jeremy Ravenelle, Kowsar Ahmed, Maria Mirijanyan, Victoria Webber, and Meghan Kelly. Through our experience with projects in Environmental Club, such as recycling in our school cafeteria, we know how difficult it is to change people’s behaviors. We also know that these behaviors are affecting the world around us and that the impacts of climate change are growing in our world. Gathering InformationTo help us determine the root of some of these behaviors, we will use a survey distributed to people in Stockholm, Sweden, Archangelsk, Russia, and Portland, Maine with a separate focus on the immigrant population.  To fully understand the data we receive from the survey and the cultures which we study, it is important that we travel to Archangelsk and Stockholm.  This will allow us to collect qualitative data directly, in the form of personal observations and interviews. Field work will also enable the development of a peer-to-peer exchange between all three communities, which will help the data gathered through our research to generate local, sustainable action. Future ImpactsOnce the data and observations are collected, the information will be used in classes at our school such as statistics, environmental science and psychology.  We hope this project will have positive impacts on our school as students embark on action projects that incorporate lessons learned from this research.  It will also provide information for future projects at the high schools in Archangelsk and Stockholm, and provide a catalyst for global change through our peer to peer exchange.



Where Will the Money Go?
The money that we hope to receive will go toward our travel expenses to both Sweden and Russia. If we are unable to reach our goal fewer people will be able to go. However, it is crucial to our project to have at least two people collect qualitative data. Below is a breakdown of funding for one student.
Budget for Sustainable Communities Research

Travel: (For 1 student) Airfare (Round trip)- 

Boston, Massachusetts to Stockholm, Sweden (Arlanda) $749*
Bus fare (Round trip)- Stockholm Arlanda Airport to city of Stockholm $24

Airfare (Round trip)- Stockholm Arlanda to Moscow, Russia $170 Train fare (Round trip)- Moscow Airport to Yaroslavsky Station, Moscow $20

Train fare (Round trip)- Moscow to Archangelsk, Russia $160
Food while traveling $100
Total: $1223*
Total for 4 students and advisor $6115*
*Based on estimated airfare for flights that have fluctuated in price.



Our Past ProjectsIn the past we have been able to accomplish smaller projects in our school. In the spring of 2012 Maria and Meghan conducted a project to reduce energy consumption by turning off hallway lights. At the same time, Jeremy decided to research energy consumption by school desktop computers. He concluded that many are left on constantly so he proposed to teachers and faculty that they turn them off when not in use. He had data to back up his proposal and was able to demonstrate to teachers the benefit of turning off their computer. Both of these projects proved to have epic impacts as they helped Portland High School reduce its electricity consumption by 29% between the fall of 2012 and fall of 2013.We Want You!Our group is ready to embark on this new project and we would love to have you on our team through your support and any funding that you are able to offer. Even if you are unable to donate, we are still in need of your help. We would love for you to get the word out in any way you can (please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!). More information can be found at http://www.gscproject.com/. Thank you so much, and welcome to the team!

story:
Short Summary

VRNACULARS (www.vrnaculars.com) is a Virtual & Augmented Reality content studio. We believe this technology can be highly impactful to make the world a better place. The most important and difficult challenge facing us today is the Sustainable Productivity challenge. Without large scale behavioral changes, we are unlikely to succeed in curtailing global warming, the ill effects of which are widely known. 

To drive change of this magnitude, we need to form new habits, and we need to start with our youth. Just like we teach our children to brush our teeth everyday, we need to teach them to stop wasting food, to shift their diets, and to make environmentally friendly lifestyle choices like walking, biking or car pooling. However, we need to teach these habits in a way that they find engaging and exciting. Our project (www.sustainableproductivity.org) achieves exactly that. By leveraging the new technologies of VR & AR, we can impress on our youth a sense of urgency and get them excited and passionate about making the behavioral changes that are needed, at the scale that is required. 

If widely adopted, the solutions we propose in this project, across the three initiatives we are focused on (reducing food waste, shifting diets, and making environmentally-friendly lifestyle choices), could result in ~80-100 Million tons of GHG emissions reduction in the US annually!

What We Need & What You Get

To make this project happen, we need to raise $10K. The funding will be going specifically into three areas:

1. Creating or completing the content for the exhibits

2. Location, equipment and event organization related expenses

3. Promotion and marketing campaigns to create awareness

In return for funding this project, you will receive various rewards based on the level of your contributions, including social media shout outs, augmented reality t-shirts, recognition in the credits of the content we develop etc. Most importantly, you will be proud of having enabled a better future for our children and our planet.

The Impact

Greenhouse gas emissions have been growing rapidly causing several detrimental effects. Sixteen of the warmest years on record have occurred since 2001. 92% of the world's population lives in areas where air pollution exceeds safe limits. By 2025, half of the world's population will be living in water stressed areas. This is the planet that are our children are going to inherit unless we cut greenhouse gas emissions by over 50%.

To make a meaningful dent in global GHG emissions, we must enable behavioral changes on a massive scale, which means we need to start with our children and our youth. This project leverages new technologies like Virtual & Augmented Reality to engage, educate and energize youth to get actively involved in enabling behavioral change, and to lead by example. We are focused on the three drivers of emissions that each of us can directly impact via behavioral changes. These are:

1. Reducing food waste,

2. Shifting diets (reducing meat consumption)

3. Making eco-friendly lifestyle choices (e.g., water use, transportation etc.)

If widely adopted, the solutions we propose in this project, across the three initiatives we are focused on (reducing food waste, shifting diets, and making environmentally-friendly lifestyle choices), could result in ~80-100 Million tons of GHG emissions reduction in the US annually!

VRNACULARS has a track record with creating such immersive and interactive content. We have been trusted by leading global companies like Flex, Equinix, Kore IoT Solutions, TVS, and Anthem Biosciences to develop VR & AR content and applications for them. We have designed and successfully conducted similar exhibitions for Enterprise clients, including a VR exhibition at the Consumer Electronics Show (the largest trade show in the world), and at trade shows in India and Brazil.  We are also working with the Media X Program at the University of the Pacific. They have produced several VR pieces, including a VR film on John Muir that has been recognized at several interactive media festivals. 

Risks & Challenges

We do not foresee any risks in creating the Virtual and Augmented Reality content for the exhibits. The greatest risk here lies in mobilizing people to get involved, to actively participate, and to spread the word about the exhibition. True impact will only come with scale, and to achieve scale we must have high levels of awareness, participation and evangelization. 

To overcome this risk, we plan to partner with several other groups that are committed to these causes including organizations like Imperfect Produce, LA Kitchen, the University of the Pacific and other universities, Corporate Social Responsibility groups at various Enterprise, local governments and media organizations. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to the campaign, you can still help us by actively promoting the campaign. Please help us spread the word! You can also help us by volunteering. Please reach out to us at ecoexhibition@vrnaculars.com for more information.

story:
Let me introduce myself!

Welcome to the crowdfunding campaign for my Cycle 2 Recycle 2020 adventure! My name is Myra and I'm a 35-year old Dutchie living in Italy. I decided to set up Cycle 2 Recycle out of pure optimism, idealism, and out of the need and willingness to take action and make a difference for our beloved planet.

My main goal (for now), is to create more awareness about the immense plastic problem everywhere in the world and to inspire people to use less disposable plastics.

 

That's really great, but how do you plan on creating this awareness?

I'm glad you asked! In the summer of 2019 I went on a very first Cycle 2 Recycle adventure, with a heavy, big, pink cargo bike. I cycled 2000km through 6 different countries (Italy, Switzerland, France, Germany, Austria, Liechtenstein), and picked up a whopping 43kg of plastic waste! (that's the equivalent of 4300 empty 500ml bottles).
While I was on the road, many many people stopped me to ask what I was doing and why. I held several presentations for (multicultural) groups of children, and got interviewed by various different magazines and newspapers.

I found that with the visibility of the bicycle (many people were super curious because they had never seen such a bike), the fact that I went "out there" among the people, and because I was doing something considered physically difficult, very challenging, and perhaps a tiny bit "crazy", my initiative had a bigger and different effect compared to online campaigns. It's the direct contact with people in their everyday lives that adds a big value to the message, because they get to see with their own eyes how much plastic I picked up in their very own neighborhoods.

 

So, what's next?

I love a good challenge, and after cycling 2000km last summer I realized it wasn't enough. It probably will never be enough when it comes to picking up plastic, so for the summer of 2020 I decided to go bigger, further, longer, and greener:

  • 11 different European countries (Italy, France, Spain, Andorra, Belgium, Netherlands, Germany, Luxembourg, Czech Republic, Austria, Slovenia)
  • 5000-6000km approximately
  • The cargo bike will be 25cm longer than the previous one
  • The cargo bike will be green instead of pink

 

Tell me, why should I support your cause?

Do you also feel how you never really know where your charity money exactly ends up when donating to big(ger) organizations? Well, with Cycle 2 Recycle there's simply no such risk. It's just me, an optimistic and idealistic individual who wants to contribute in her own, original way to raising more awareness about a very important environmental issue.

Your donation will go straight to the preparations for my 2020 adventure, like small adjustments to the cargo bike, the creation of the front container out of plastic bottles that I found during my trial rounds, and it will get me through the first weeks of the challenge.

Also, and this is not insignificant: if I reach my goal here on indiegogo, this crowdfunding campaign can remain active much longer than the usual 60 days. Being able to receive donations for an extended period of time will be a huge game-changer for me and my future projects.

One of those future projects is the foundation of a recycling center. At this recycle center I will be able to recycle the plastic I pick up with the cargo bike, hold presentations and workshops especially for children (because they are the future), and it will allow me to connect with the community & educate them on the importance of decreasing our consumption of disposable plastics.

 

Awesome! Do you offer some cool perks for those who decide to sponsor you?

Besides plastics, one of the other very polluting industries out there is the clothing industry. Because I don't want to contribute to this huge problem, I decided to offer only a couple of perks, made from organic, eco-friendly materials.

Backers will be able to obtain a Cycle 2 Recycle t-shirt and/or a Cycle 2 Recycle canvas tote bag, both made from organic materials.

 

Are there other ways I can help?

Sure! If you cannot make a (small) donation right now, that's ok: my main goal is & will always remain to raise more awareness about the plastic problem and inspire people to change their habits. So the most important way you can help me is to share my ideas and projects with your friends, family, and colleagues. How can you share?

You can use the sharing tools here on Indiegogo, go to my website www.cycle2recycle.org, or start following me:

Facebook --> https://www.facebook.com/Cycle2Recycle.Official
Instagram --> https://www.instagram.com/cycle.2.recycle
Twitter --> https://twitter.com/cycle2_recycle

You can also contact me at info@cycle2recycle.org

story:
The Expedition Outline

We are a team of 6 first year bioscience students from the University of Exeter travelling to the South-East coast of Madagascar to perform biodiversity studies on the fauna found there. We will be heading out from 9th August - 18th September.

Madagascar has been isolated from mainland Africa for over 88 million years; resulting in both high species richness and a significant proportion of endemic species.

Our study site, Loholoka, is a coastal humid forest located 600km from the capital, Antananarivo. Currently, the site has no conservation status and so the area is not protected.

Our aim is to create the first comprehensive biodiversity record of the Loholoka forest. Our project addresses an important gap in biological knowledge and will allow the establishment of long term conservation of the biodiversity of Loholoka.



Collaboration

We will be collaborating with students from the University of Antananarivo's Botany and Animal Biology Departments, Government Authorities and working closely with Development and Biodiversity Conservation Action for Madagascar (DBCAM) a small Madagascan research NGO who take a grass roots focus when working with local communities.

Through our in-country contacts we are hoping to encourage more student led projects in Madagascar. In addtion these strong collborations will ensure our findings can be used appropriately in Madagascar once we have returned to the UK. 

Why It Matters 

The world is in a biodiveristy crisis which it is estimated that the current species extinction rate is between 1,000 and 10,000 times higher than it would naturally be.


In Loholoka the story is no different a number of threats to biodiversity have been flagged, Namely illegal logging and charcoal production. With your help our research would play a significant role in determining the biodiversity status of the area and the fragility of the species present. Without these vital surveys endangered species may go unproected furthermore new species maybe lost before they are identified. From 1999 to 2010, scientists discovered 615 new species in Madagascar, including 41 mammals and 61 reptiles. 


How You Can Support Us 

This project is costing us £20000 and so far we have received funding from the Royal Geographical Society and The John Muir Trust. Alongside our personal contributions, we need your help to raise the final £5000! 

Your contribution will go towards our in-county costs, ranging from: 4WD vehicles (the terrain is tough!), local guides, scientific equipment hire, food and allowing us to document everything through the use of film and photography.


Perks

We have a variety of perks on offer when you make your contribution. Don't forget, what ever amount you donate, you can take a pick from any of the perks within your price range.

We are lucky enough to have a Wildlife Photographer of the Year runner up on our team, so you can expect some fantastic photos!


Other Ways You Can Help

The more support we get the better so get involved and spread the word! 

You can find us here:

Website: Fxpeditions Loholoka

Facebook: Expedition Loholoka

Twitter: @Loholoka


Thanks from all the team and we will be forever grateful!

story:
Short Summary

  • Hi from Khatijah, Bernard and Matthias - we are from Eco Warriors Malaysia, a tribe on facebook which exists since 2008. We have supported more than 100 eco events over the years without budget or collecting money. However now we feel we need to take our young members into the forest to give them first hand experience of mother nature. Additionally we want to support the great work of MYCAT's Wildlife Crime Hotline (019.356.4194), operational 24-7 throughout Peninsular Malaysia with 100 RM per participant and Ecoteer (http://www.ecoteer.com) with 30 RM per participant for organizing our itinerary and helping us with the event logistics. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise 130 RM per participant so that we can support the above mentioned organisations and keep the participation costs low for our students and youngsters at only 140 RM (GBP30) self contribution so they can afford to attend. The raised money will go to MYCAT and Ecoteer. We hope in total we can raise around 1400 usd which will be a bit more than our target 5000 RM. If we have money left over after paying fees then more money will go to those two amazing organisations. 

The Impact

You will both support young people going out to connect with the forest to become eco leaders as well as supporting these two wonderful organisations MYCAT and Ecoteer. Obviously we will be excited as well - it is always great to get a vote of confidence for the work we have done for the last 7 years without any financial gains and many in-kind contributions. 

Risks & Challenges

The only risk would be that we have to cancel the event due to unforeseen circumstances or not enough people wanting to join, but we would then reschedule and we have had a lot of interest already even though we have not formally announced anything yet.

The Eco Leadership Programme

Day 1

Arrival at Merapoh with welcome brief

Day 2

Jungle trekking on the borders of Taman Negara, the most important Malayan Tiger habitat. You will be trekking in the Sungai Yu Tiger Corridor and looking out for signs of poachers and animals.

We will set up camp with a local indigenous nomadic tribe called the Batek.  They will teach us how to cook using Bamboo.  What can be better for a group of future Eco Leaders than to be surrounded by mother nature herself and with tribes people who call this forest their home.

Day 3

No doubt you will wake early to listen to the sounds of the jungle, listen to the dawn chorus of gibbons and birds.  Magic. We will head back along the track with the Batek women before having lunch in Merapoh.  After your jungle experience you will go through eco leadership training that will help you to protect this amazing forest and its denizens. Here is a review of a recent visit http://pericopsis.org/trees/forum/topic.php?t=7...


Day 4

In the morning you will join the Ecoteer team with the Batek people in their village to help start a weekly rubbish disposal programme.  The Batek people are not provided with any rubbish disposal system and you will join in with the first big village clean up, the money raised via this campaign will go towards funding a weekly rubbish disposal service including recycling and composting run by Ecoteer. 

After you have given back to the community we will have a debrief of the programme and discuss what YOU can do back home for mother nature.


This is an Eco Leadership programme that not only benefits the participants but financially and socially benefits the indigenous Batek Tribe and of course the Tigers and their forest friends.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please join Eco Warriors Malaysia on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/ecowarriorsmala...

We have supported more than 100 eco events over the years without budget or collecting money. However now we feel we need to take our young members into the forest to give them first hand experience of mother nature. Additionally we want to support the great work of MYCAT's Wildlife Crime Hotline (019.356.4194), operational 24-7 throughout Peninsular Malaysia with 100 RM per participant and Ecoteer (http://www.ecoteer.com) with 30 RM per participant for organizing our itinerary and helping us with the event logistics.    What We Need & What You Get We need to raise 130 RM per participant so that we can support the above mentioned organisations and keep the participation costs low for our students and youngsters at only 140 RM (GBP30) self contribution so they can afford to attend. The raised money will go to MYCAT and Ecoteer. We hope in total we can raise around 1400 usd which will be a bit more than our target 5000 RM. If we have money left over after paying fees then more money will go to those two amazing organisations. 
    The Impact You will both support young people going out to connect with the forest to become eco leaders as well as supporting these two wonderful organisations MYCAT and Ecoteer. Obviously we will be excited as well - it is always great to get a vote of confidence for the work we have done for the last 7 years without any financial gains and many in-kind contributions. 
    Risks & Challenges The only risk would be that we have to cancel the event due to unforeseen circumstances or not enough people wanting to join, but we would then reschedule and we have had a lot of interest already even though we have not formally announced anything yet.
The Eco Leadership Programme

Day 1
Arrival at Merapoh with welcome brief

Day 2
Jungle trekking on the borders of Taman Negara, the most important Malayan Tiger habitat. You will be trekking in the Sungai Yu Tiger Corridor and looking out for signs of poachers and animals.
We will set up camp with a local indigenous nomadic tribe called the Batek.  They will teach us how to cook using Bamboo.  What can be better for a group of future Eco Leaders than to be surrounded by mother nature herself and with tribes people who call this forest their home.
Day 3
No doubt you will wake early to listen to the sounds of the jungle, listen to the dawn chorus of gibbons and birds.  Magic. We will head back along the track with the Batek women before having lunch in Merapoh.  After your jungle experience you will go through eco leadership training that will help you to protect this amazing forest and its denizens. Here is a review of a recent visit http://pericopsis.org/trees/forum/topic.php?t=7...


Day 4
In the morning you will join the Ecoteer team with the Batek people in their village to help start a weekly rubbish disposal programme.  The Batek people are not provided with any rubbish disposal system and you will join in with the first big village clean up, the money raised via this campaign will go towards funding a weekly rubbish disposal service including recycling and composting run by Ecoteer. 
After you have given back to the community we will have a debrief of the programme and discuss what YOU can do back home for mother nature.

This is an Eco Leadership programme that not only benefits the participants but financially and socially benefits the indigenous Batek Tribe and of course the Tigers and their forest friends.




Other Ways You Can Help Please join Eco Warriors Malaysia on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/ecowarriorsmala...

story:
Marchons contre les hydrocarbures en Gaspésie  ! / Come Walk Against Fossil Fuels In Gaspesie!

IN ENGLISH BELOW

Du 29 mai à la mi-juillet 2016, des centaines de personnes se joindront à une marche d’environ 20 km par jour pour s’opposer au transport et à l’exploitation des hydrocarbures en Gaspésie. Nous avons réalisé une marche semblable en 2014 sur plus de 700 km entre Cacouna et Kanehsatà:ke pour s’opposer à l’oléoduc Énergie Est de TransCanada, cette fois nous rechausserons nos souliers pour protéger la Gaspésie.

Le long du trajet, nos objectifs sont d’attirer l’attention médiatique sur ces enjeux écologiques, de dénoncer l'attitude coloniale des compagnies et des gouvernements en territoire Mi'gmaq non-cédé, d’encourager la mobilisation pour protéger l’environnement et de rencontrer les communautés touchées en organisant des spectacles engagés et des discussions.

Comparativement à d’autres types d’actions, une longue marche permet de tisser des liens entre les différents groupes distribués sur le territoire, de saluer les actions d’activistes locaux et de créer de profondes amitiés. Marcher crée aussi un attachement aux paysages, à la Terre, semant ainsi les graines d’actions futures. 


10 raisons pour soutenir la marche

  1. PROJET BELLEDUNE : La compagnie Chaleur Terminals caresse le projet de faire circuler plus de 200 wagons de pétrole par jour, en provenance des sables bitumineux de l’Alberta, par la Gaspésie jusqu’à Belledune au Nouveau-Brunswick. La population et les cours d’eau sont menacés par le risque d’un déraillement comme celui de Lac-Mégantic. Ce projet contribue à encourager l’extraction de pétrole dessables bitumineux en Alberta qui en plus d’empoisonner l’environnement albertain et la population est une menace majeure pour le climat.

  2. Les trois communautés Mi’kmaq de Gaspésie n’ont été ni consultées ni accommodées pour ce projet de transport de pétrole par train et s’opposent à cette violation de leur traité. Plusieurs maires de municipalités s’opposent au projet de Chaleur Terminals, dont ceux d’Amqui et Rimouski.

  3. Gastem poursuit le village de Ristigouche-Sud-Est,qui compte 168 habitants, pour une somme de 1,5 millions dollars parce qu’il a osé adopter un règlement pour protéger son eau potable des forages pétroliers.

  4. Pour être rentable, l’exploitation pétrolière et gazière en Gaspésie nécessitera des milliers de puits et l’utilisation de la fracturation. Bien que les pétrolières disent ne pas utiliser cette technique pour l’instant, la fracturation pourrait multiplier leur production par un facteur 100. On peut donc s’attendre à des pressions de leur part pour que la fracturation soit autorisée.

  5. La fracturation hydraulique consiste à injecter des substances toxiques (ex.: chlorure de potassium, benzène, toluène) et environ 8 millions de litres d’eau par puits pour fracturer la roche en profondeur. Des recherches ont démontré un lien entre la présence de puits de fracturation hydraulique et une augmentation du nombre de fausses couches ainsi que de malformations congénitales chez les nouveaux-nés. La fracturation a également causé des tremblements de terre.

  6. PROJET HALDIMAND : La compagnie Pétrolia a déjà foré quatre puits dans le secteur Haldimand près de Gaspé. Ceux-ci représentent une menace à l’eau potable. Bien que Haldimand-4 se trouve à moins de 150 mètres d’un cours d’eau qui se jette dans une rivière à saumons, en novembre et décembre 2015 Pétrolia a injecté 70,000 litres de fluides avec 15% d'acide chlorydrique dans son puits pour le nettoyer. PROJET GALT : Junex a foré des puits près de Gaspé et de Bonaventure dans la Baie des chaleurs.

  7. PROJET BOURQUE : Junex  et Tugliq planifient d’exploiter plusieurs puits près de Murdochville et de construire un oléoduc pour transporter du gaz naturel jusqu’au port de Sandy Beach à Gaspé. Le gaz serait liquéfié au port et transporté par bateau vers la Côte Nord.

  8. La cimenterie qui est en construction à Port-Daniel, sans avoir eu recours à un BAPE, émettra annuellement 1,75 millions de tonnes de gaz à effet de serre (GES). Elle utilisera comme source d’énergie du coke provenant des sables bitumineux en Alberta ce qui équivaut à subventioner cette industrie destructrice.

  9. PROJET ÉNERGIE EST : Si TransCanada construit l’oléoduc Energie Est pour transporter 1,1 millions de barils par jour le long du fleuve Saint-Laurent, alors une fuite de cet oléoduc aurait un impact écologique important sur le nord de la Gaspésie.

  10. Notre marche a besoin de votre aide pour voir le jour !


Pourquoi le financement ?

Il est très important pour nous que la marche soit accessible à toutes et tous. Nous voulons que les marcheuses et marcheurs puissent dormir et manger sans frais pendant la marche. Pour cela, nous travaillons en ce moment même avec les communautés tout au long de la route pour limiter le plus possible les dépenses.

Mais nous avons quand même besoin de vous ! Nous aurons beaucoup de bouches à nourrir, de l’information et une trousse de mobilisation à diffuser, du matériel à acheter, des artistes locaux à encourager et bien plus encore.

Si nous atteignons le but fixé avec un surplus, les fonds seront utilisés pour financer d’autres actions contre les hydrocarbures. D'ailleurs, nous avons fait un surplus en 2014 et avons organisé avec cet argent un camp contre l'inversion de l'oléoduc 9B de Enbridge. Nous vous demandons de contribuer à la marche à la hauteur de vos moyens. Chaque dollar aidera à faire de cette marche une réalité!


Le 'Québec', le 'Canada' et les Premières nations

sont mobilisés.

Rejoignez le mouvement!

Aidez-nous à faire de la marche une réalité!


Venez marcher avec nous, que ce soit un mois ou une après-midi!

Parlez de la marche autour de vous!

Et surtout… MERCI.


Restez à l’écoute pour des mises à jour tout au long

de la campagne Indiegogo!

Écrivez-nous à: projetgaspesie@gmail.com

Visitez notre site web: http://marchedespeuples.org

Visitez notre page facebook : https://www.facebook.com/peuplespourlaterremere/

Pour nous aider avec l’organisation joignez-vous à notre groupe facebook :  https://www.facebook.com/groups/marche.des.peuples/

*** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** *** ***


Come Walk Against Fossil Fuels In Gaspesie!

From May 29th to mid-July 2016, hundreds of people will join a march of 20 km per day in order to oppose the transportation and extraction of fossil fuels in Gaspesie. We accomplished a similar 700 km march in 2014 between Cacouna and Kanehsatà:ke to oppose TransCanada’s Energy East pipeline project. This time we will hit the road to protect the Gaspesie.

  On the route, our objectives are to attract media attention to these ecological issues, to denounce the colonial attitude of companies and governments on unceded Mi'kmaq territory, to encourage mobilization to protect the environment, and to meet the affected communities by organizing protest shows and discussions.

  Compared with other types of actions, a long march makes it possible to link different groups dispersed on the territory, to acknowledge the work of local activists and to create strong friendships. Walking also creates an attachment to the scenery, to the Earth. It plants the seeds of future actions.

10 Reasons to Support the March

  1. PROJECT BELLEDUNE: The Chaleur Terminals company is planning to bring more than 200 wagons of oil per day, from the tar sands in Alberta, through the Matapedia valley in Gaspesie up to Belledune in New-Brunswick. Populations and water are put at risk of a possible derailment like the one of Lac Megantic. This project helps the extraction of oil from tar sands in Alberta which on top of poisoning the environment and people in Alberta, is a major threat for the climate.

  2. The three Mi’gmaq communities in Gaspesie have not been either consulted or accommodated for this project of transporting oil by train. Therefore, they oppose this violation of their treaty. Mayors of many municipalities,such as in Amqui and Rimouski,  are also opposed to the Chaleur Terminals inc. project.

  3. Gastem is suing the village of Ristigouche-South-East, that counts 168 inhabitants, for 1.5 million dollars because they dare pass a bylaw to protect their drinking water.

  4. In order to be profitable, oil and gas extraction in Gaspesie will require thousands of wells and the use of hydraulic fracturing, aka fracking. Even though the companies say they are not using this technique for the time being, fracking could multiply production by a factor 100. So we can expect pressure from them to authorize fracking.

  5. Fracking consists in injecting toxic substances (e.g., potassium chloride, benzene, toluene) and about 8 million liters of water per well to break the rock deep down. Research has shown a link between hydraulic fracking and an increase in still born births as well as birth defects in newborns. Fracking has also caused earthquakes.

  6. HALDIMAND PROJECT: Petrolia has already drilled four wells in the Haldimand area near Gaspe. They represent a threat to drinking water. Even though Haldimand-4 is at less than 150 m from a creek flowing into a salmon river, in November and December 2015 Petrolia injected 70,000 liters of fluid with 15% of hydrochloric acid in its well to clean it. GALT PROJECT: Junex has drilled wells near Gaspe and Bonaventure in the Bay of Chaleurs.

  7. BOURQUE PROJECT: Junex and Tugliq plan to exploit many wells near Murdochville, to build a pipeline to carry natural gas to Sandy Beach harbor near Gaspe. The gas would be liquefied at the harbor and then transported by boat toward the North Shore of the St-Lawrence.

  8. The cement factory that is being built in Port-Daniel, without proper environmental evaluation, will emit 1.75 million tons of greenhouse gases annually. It will use, as energy source, coke from the tar sands of Alberta, which is equivalent to subsidising this destructive industry.

  9. ENERGY EAST PROJECT: If TransCanada builds the Energy East pipeline to carry 1.1 million barrels of oil per day along the St-Lawrence river, then a leak would have a terrible ecological impact on the north shore of Gaspesie.

  10. Our march needs your help to happen !


Why Fund This Project?

It is very important to us that the march be accessible to all. We want the walkers to sleep and eat for free during the march. For this reason, we are working right now with the communities along the route to limit our expenses as much as possible.

 However, we still need you ! We have many mouths to feed, information and mobilisation documents to disseminate, material to buy, local artists to support and much more.

If we reach our goal with a surplus, the rest will be used to finance other actions against fossil fuels. Indeed, this is what happened in 2014 and we organized with this surplus a camp against the inversion of the flow in Enbridge's pipeline 9B. We ask you to contribute according to your means. Each dollar will help this march to happen!

'Canada', 'Quebec' and First Nations are mobilized.

Join the movement!

Help to make the march happen.


Come walk with us, whether it’s for an afternoon or for a month!

Talk about the march around you!

And… THANK YOU.


Stay tuned for updates of the Indiegogo campaign!


Write to us at: projetgaspesie@gmail.com

Visit our web site:  http://tinyurl.com/MarchForMotherEarth

Visit our facebook page : http://tinyurl.com/gaspesieproject

To help us organize join our facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/marche.des.peuples

*** *** *** *** *** ***

story:
Project Overview

Walnut Way Conservation Corp. is a 501c3 nonprofit located in Milwaukee’s Lindsay Heights neighborhood — a vibrant, African-American community nestled on the city’s near-Northside. 

The Lindsay Heights community has a rich history and a bright future — and our mission is to sustain this economically diverse and abundant community through civic engagement, environmental stewardship, and creating venues for prosperity. We’ve implemented numerous economic development, environmental, and redevelopment projects in service of that mission — one being our robust urban agriculture program. 

Our Urban Agricultural Program

Walnut Way’s urban agriculture program is rooted — pun intended! — in innovation. Our residents have transformed vacant lots into production gardens and orchards. We utilize a hoop house, rainwater storage, composting, solar power, and bee apiaries. Demonstrating the ability to grow healthy food is essential to our community’s health and wellness goals, and maintaining a clean and beautiful agricultural campus is essential to environmental stewardship. 

Food grown on campus is shared with neighbors and sold at local markets, restaurants, and grocery stores. They’re also transformed into products by our Growing Youth Leadership interns. The campus is a rich environment for learning and sharing with neighbors, employees, and visitors from all over the world.

Our urban agriculture program is outgrowing our current facility and infrastructure — which is a great problem to have! We’re incredibly proud of the program we’ve built — and we need your help to continue to grow. That’s where the Walnut Workshed Project comes in. 

How You Can Help: The Walnut Workshed Project

Our goal is to build an innovative facility — what we’re calling the Walnut Workshed — that will support our current farming capacity and allow us to expand our impact in the future. With the help of our friends and partners at Outpost Natural Foods, we’ll repurpose a used shipping container into a refrigeration and food processing facility in tandem with a two-car garage. 

The Workshed will help further the mission of our community in several key ways:

  • Less food waste due to refrigeration abilities
  • Accessibility and protection for tools, and additional storage
  • A space for our Growing Youth Leadership interns to gather, have workshops, and work in an enclosed space during rainstorms and inclement weather
  • Increased capacity to provide fresh, chemical-free produce to the community

Any donation towards our $30K goal will grow our vision of an environmentally just community. The Workshed Project offers us a chance to be deliberate and connect all the dots of our work — health and wellness, economic prosperity, and environmental stewardship. We’d love to have you along for the journey!

 

More About Walnut Way

We were founded over 20 years ago by Lindsay Heights residents — and from the very start, two key elements have guided our work: the importance of place, and that the way we work together matters. With our residents, young people, business owners, nonprofits, and a wide range of stakeholders, we carved out a vision of what our community could be, and we’ve been working toward and refining that plan ever since through a community-wide Quality of Life plan.

Since our purposeful beginnings, we’ve restored dilapidated homes to quality housing, built a vibrant community resource center, transformed vacant lots into gardens and orchards, strengthened neighborhood safety, developed the Innovation and Wellness Commons for economic development, built pathways to meaningful employment through our Blue Skies Landscaping Program, created innovative wellness programs for men and women, and engaged residents of all ages in neighborhood revitalization activities. Head here to learn more about us: https://www.walnutway.org/about/ 

Our Team

Marissa Cudworth: Environmental Stewardship Public Ally, Project Planning & Development

Jeremy Davis: Environmental Specialist, Oversight of Project Planning & Construction

Amber Ascher: Environmental Stewardship Operations Coordinator

Amanda Maqueia: Communications Specialist Volunteer

Kurt Baehmann: Partner & Sustainability Manager, Outpost Natural Foods Co-op
story_txt:
Project OverviewWalnut Way Conservation Corp. is a 501c3 nonprofit located in Milwaukee’s Lindsay Heights neighborhood — a vibrant, African-American community nestled on the city’s near-Northside. The Lindsay Heights community has a rich history and a bright future — and our mission is to sustain this economically diverse and abundant community through civic engagement, environmental stewardship, and creating venues for prosperity. We’ve implemented numerous economic development, environmental, and redevelopment projects in service of that mission — one being our robust urban agriculture program. Our Urban Agricultural ProgramWalnut Way’s urban agriculture program is rooted — pun intended! — in innovation. Our residents have transformed vacant lots into production gardens and orchards. We utilize a hoop house, rainwater storage, composting, solar power, and bee apiaries. Demonstrating the ability to grow healthy food is essential to our community’s health and wellness goals, and maintaining a clean and beautiful agricultural campus is essential to environmental stewardship. Food grown on campus is shared with neighbors and sold at local markets, restaurants, and grocery stores. They’re also transformed into products by our Growing Youth Leadership interns. The campus is a rich environment for learning and sharing with neighbors, employees, and visitors from all over the world.Our urban agriculture program is outgrowing our current facility and infrastructure — which is a great problem to have! We’re incredibly proud of the program we’ve built — and we need your help to continue to grow. That’s where the Walnut Workshed Project comes in. How You Can Help: The Walnut Workshed ProjectOur goal is to build an innovative facility — what we’re calling the Walnut Workshed — that will support our current farming capacity and allow us to expand our impact in the future. With the help of our friends and partners at Outpost Natural Foods, we’ll repurpose a used shipping container into a refrigeration and food processing facility in tandem with a two-car garage. The Workshed will help further the mission of our community in several key ways:
Less food waste due to refrigeration abilities
Accessibility and protection for tools, and additional storage
A space for our Growing Youth Leadership interns to gather, have workshops, and work in an enclosed space during rainstorms and inclement weather
Increased capacity to provide fresh, chemical-free produce to the community
Any donation towards our $30K goal will grow our vision of an environmentally just community. The Workshed Project offers us a chance to be deliberate and connect all the dots of our work — health and wellness, economic prosperity, and environmental stewardship. We’d love to have you along for the journey! More About Walnut WayWe were founded over 20 years ago by Lindsay Heights residents — and from the very start, two key elements have guided our work: the importance of place, and that the way we work together matters. With our residents, young people, business owners, nonprofits, and a wide range of stakeholders, we carved out a vision of what our community could be, and we’ve been working toward and refining that plan ever since through a community-wide Quality of Life plan.Since our purposeful beginnings, we’ve restored dilapidated homes to quality housing, built a vibrant community resource center, transformed vacant lots into gardens and orchards, strengthened neighborhood safety, developed the Innovation and Wellness Commons for economic development, built pathways to meaningful employment through our Blue Skies Landscaping Program, created innovative wellness programs for men and women, and engaged residents of all ages in neighborhood revitalization activities. Head here to learn more about us: https://www.walnutway.org/about/ Our TeamMarissa Cudworth: Environmental Stewardship Public Ally, Project Planning & DevelopmentJeremy Davis: Environmental Specialist, Oversight of Project Planning & ConstructionAmber Ascher: Environmental Stewardship Operations CoordinatorAmanda Maqueia: Communications Specialist VolunteerKurt Baehmann: Partner & Sustainability Manager, Outpost Natural Foods Co-op

story:
Help me tell this story!

I'm spending the month of February photographing climate change in Iceland. 

Why, you ask?

First off—in a nutshell—it's a lifelong dream: capture images of climate change on one of the colder populated places on the planet. Hit those spots where few people go at times when even fewer are there. Catch a glimpse of life before the firstworld grind that surrounds me today. With a geologically active landscape, calving glaciers, an accessible coastline, rich culture and hospitable locals, Iceland is a perfect place to tell the story of the Earth changing.  

I'll travel along the coast as far as weather will permit, take pictures and talk to people about how climate change as affected Iceland. What is different from 5 years ago? 10 years ago? What kinds of changes do they anticipate in the coming decade?

The bags are heavy, but I've got critical gear for the task at hand:

  • Two full-frame camera bodies, 5 lenses, lots of filters (for shots ranging from extreme macro close-up to extreme wide to serious telephoto)
  • Four strobes, portable light stands, umbrellas, softbox, seamless rolls
  • Countless batteries and chargers. Sound recording unit. GPS unit. GoPro. Solar charger (although light will be a bit scarce).
  • Extreme weather clothing, sleeping bag, backpack, 

With all of this in hand, I will be flexible with my itinerary, and put safety and level-headedness above all. But it will take a little bit more than planning and good luck.

Why This Trip Is Important:

This is one of the last great places, and it's changing by the minute. Climate change in Iceland is causing more frequent volcanic eruptions, faster melting of the country's glaciers, and a rising of the country by up to 1.4in/year. With the country changing as rapidly as it is, the people, animals, and landscape are adapting to new forces. I want to hear their stories, share them. I want to learn how a small island nation is reacting to all of the pollution that the global superpowers are sending their way every day.

What I still need:

Essentially, I need additional funds for getting the shots once I'm there:

  • rental fees for travel camper / accommodations / food
  • fees for guides where necessary, helicopter or private plane rentals if possible for aerial shots
  • gas money!

What I'll Get and What You'll Get

You'll be helping me tell this story, so let me tell you where your money will go! 

  • $10 and up
    pays for: a tasty meal along the way!
    You get in return: a selfie of me toasting you at the meal, and 5 digital Iceland photograph backgrounds for your computer and/or cell phone
  • $75 and up
    pays for:  a tank of gas
    You get in return: 12-pack of 4"x6" Iceland photograph cards, professionally printed on 110# Recycled Card stock
  • $250 and up
    pays for: a night's accommodation (with a much-appreciated shower)
    You get: a selfie of me on-site at the accommodation you made possible, AND a single, bamboo-mounted 8"x10" signed Iceland photograph that you choose from the trip selects 
  • $500 and up
    pays for: a week of camper rental, a guide for the day, or a short heli flight
    You get: - 26 page, 16"x12" professionally printed color book with key photos from the journey, and insights learned along the way
  • $1000 and up
    pays for: multiple helicopter flights / guide days
    You get: your choice of a single 3'x4' fine art print (framing not included) of an Iceland photo you choose from the trip selects, or four 16"x24" fine art prints of photographs you choose from the trip selects. 

What Challenges Do I Anticipate?

Well, this trip is chock full of 'em.

  • It's going to be a little cold in Iceland in February.
  • I don't speak Icelandic, so I'll be relying on the goodwill of the people I meet to help me along the way in English.
I hope to make many friends, and engage in a dialogue that will tell the story, and lead me to interesting photographs. I plan to take many portraits, landscapes, and macro images along the way, as climate change is very much about people in their environment.

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe money's not your thing, or maybe you're hesitant to give money to a guy to hit the road with a camera. But I can use other kinds of help:

  • Tell your friends about my campaign, get the word out in the short time I have left before I leave.
  • Introduce me to people you know in Iceland that would like to be a part of my project, either in facilitating it, or as part of the story, or both!

Let's tell this story!

story:
Real, Practical Solutions

Since 2009, The Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) has held over 94 contests calling for practical solutions to the climate crisis.  Over 2000 entries from all over the world have been received to date, and MIT has selected 500 finalists and 113 winners. Unfortunately, while these important programs have received recognition, there is no direct funding for implementation.

Team Mobilize Now has carefully chosen 25 of the 113 MIT winners to be the recipients of direct funding and to help them rapidly mobilize. Models show that fully implementing those projects would suffice to bring carbon emissions down to a sustainable level.

Members of our current generations are the last line of defense in the fight against climate change. Our Global Climate Action Plan will work on a worldwide scale and has been vetted and backed by MIT's Climate CoLab community.

Join us now! Together we can and WILL not only create climate hope but put in motion practical, scalable, and real solutions.

 

Why Join and Contribute?

Any contribution to Team Mobilize Now makes you a member of an enlightened team that is taking immediate action to support 25 carefully selected MIT Climate CoLab projects that fight the greatest threat ever to humanity.

Please look through our 25 projects and join us by making a contribution.

Here are steps for you to take right now:

  1. Join Team Mobilize Now by making a contribution of any size.
  2. Urge everyone you know to join this campaign.  Share the link.

Why your help is Needed

No single organization has a plan including everything needed to solve the climate change problem. We are committed to work with governments, nonprofits and for-profit companies on a comprehensive solution using the very best ideas, all of which have been winners or finalists in MIT Climate CoLab contests.  

1. SaveOhno uses the science of engagement to create a positive, growing, and enthusiastic tide of change in climate action. SaveOhno.org is a platform with over 7,000 online petitions and 15 nonprofit partners posting actions beyond petition-signing that users can take to build a better world. SaveOhno exemplifies the kind of low-cost, high-impact project Team Mobilize Now can leverage to global impact.

 

2. Climate Change is Elementary was tested in 24 schools in 6 states and is ready for nationwide implementation. It helps kids and parents fill out a Green Action Checklist and pledge to reduce their carbon footprint to zero. When families buy energy-saving and water-saving products, our participating vendors give rebates to their school.

The forthcoming book Green Action Guide will follow the Green Action Checklist showing steps to transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy. $15,000 is needed to finish and publish the book and ebook. After that, the program will be self-supporting with contributions from schools, page sponsorships, and book sales. If you are interested, please select this book as your perk.

See draft book cover design below.

Every two-page spread in the Green Action Guide is one of the actions on the green action checklist. A parent page is on the left and an activity page for the kids is on the right.  

(For a sample of the green action checklist, please scroll down.)

Below is a sample of the checklist that every family in the school fills out and promises to follow.  

 

HOW IS THIS PROJECT DIFFERENT FROM OTHER PROJECTS THAT PROPOSE TO REDUCE CARBON EMISSIONS?

Not enough is being done to reduce carbon emissions that cause global warming. What we propose are additional steps to the steps that were agreed upon at the 2015 Paris Agreement.

Systems thinking -- which was largely invented at MIT -- allowed us to identify a number of projects that, implemented together, could actually solve the climate change problem. We identified 25 projects that -- taken together and fully implemented -- would bring emissions down enough to stabilize global temperatures at a sustainable level. 

Our projects can be paid for by simply diverting funds now going to subsidize fossil fuels. It is simply common sense to do so.

 

 

Our Responsibility

Current generations bear both the consequences of past emissions and responsibility to prevent future emissions. We're the last line of defense in the fight against climate change. Team Mobilize Now's Global Climate Action Plan is a comprehensive, systems-level plan to mitigate climate change on a global scale from the ground up, and it has even been vetted and backed by MIT's Climate CoLab community!

Contribute to Mobilize Now, a worldwide movement that is dedicated to taking responsible action to solve the climate change problem.

 

Our Core Team

 

Our Contributors

Our Project Areas

  1. SaveOhno to recruit citizens of the world and reward their grassroots activities, including petition-signing, boycotts, buycotts, political campaigns, protests, rallies, lobbying, donating, and volunteering.
  2. Schools to create new bio-centric ethos for students, parents, teachers and communities, connecting green schools to green local vendors.
  3. Religious and civic organizations, service clubs, youth groups, professional societies, municipal and county governments, and business organizations to all be asked to do their part to create a green future.
  4. Food production to become more distributed, also, moving indoors in “food deserts” and onto the balconies in cities and into the yards of suburbs.
  5. Vehicles to transition to electric and be charged from ubiquitous and affordable solar, wind and small hydro energy generation at the household and community level, removed from grid dependence, with battery backup for homes and communities.
  6. Communities to adopt biological diversity, with re-introduction of heirloom crops and permaculture in place of grass lawns.
  7. Photosynthesis, absorption, and sequestering of CO2 to be enhanced by planting fast growing crops, trees and industrial hemp to absorb greenhouse gases.
  8. Use of chemicals (pesticides, herbicides, fungicides, fertilizers, and pharmaceuticals) in meat and fish to be greatly reduced.
  9. Advocacy for a “No Foam Zone” to reduce the use of foam containers throughout the world.
  10. Advocacy to ban plastic water bottles and plastic shopping bags.
  11. Divestment and voting to leave resources in the ground to get investors to switch from fossil fuels to renewables.
  12. Community composting to equip every community with a biodigester.
  13. Encourage less meat consumption to reduce greenhouse gases.
  14. Participate in a Futuristic Storytelling Game to heighten awareness of future climate change effects.
  15. Tap into the abundant energy from the oceans to replace energy from fossil fuels.
  16. Develop a transportation plan for a low-carbon city to include electric mass transit and personal vehicles. (Masdar City is one good example for urban areas)
  17. Enhance photosynthetic activity to aid CO2 absorption; bringing back home gardens, and teaching children early the importance of permaculture.
  18. Promote geothermal heating and cooling to encourage the use of DIY systems and emphasize the benefits of clean energy.
  19. Advocacy to promote the production of multi-use packaging to minimize waste that goes in dumps and oceans and to reduce not only the amount but also the type of trash generated.
  20. Advocacy to hold construction and related projects accountable for waste.
  21. Promote politically-feasible carbon pricing solutions to reduce CO2 emissions.
  22. Implement a levy on emissions to encourage maritime cargo shipping to reduce emissions.
  23. Build a platform for collaboration and facilitation of communication among the major players in the industrial sector to accelerate innovation and widespread use of new technologies that will allow industry members to grow sustainably.
  24. Find a way to make money by "mining" the plastic already in mid-ocean gyres and in landfills.
  25. Promote a global digital currency to create an administrative system over the Internet to manage a new stateless world currency that rewards all types of greenhouse emissions reductions and sequestration with digital issuance of the currency.

See more details about the above projects on MIT CoLab pages describing Team Mobilize Now’s Global Climate Action Plan, “Make Climate Change a Top Priority for Action by Every Global Citizen and Organization.”

 

Acknowledgements

At this time, there is no organization – governmental, nonprofit, or for-profit – that demonstrates all of what will be needed to solve the climate change problem. However, some well-known and respected organizations demonstrate elements that – taken together and scaled upward – could meet the enormous challenge posed by climate change.

  • MIT’s Center for Collective Intelligence demonstrates the collaborative spirit that will be needed by organizations if their efforts are to be multiplied in effectiveness and scope through cooperative efforts with other organizations.
  • Citizens' Climate Lobby (CCL) builds upon shared values rather than partisan divides, empowering its supporters to work in keeping with the concerns of their local communities. The organization works toward adoption of fair, effective, and sustainable climate change solutions.
  • According to Ken Berlin, President and CEO of The Climate Reality Project:
    "We at Climate Reality are committed to fighting climate change, but we also recognize that in order to win we need to work in an inclusive, collaborative manner."
  • The National Wildlife Federation is a voice for wildlife, dedicated to protecting wildlife and habitat and inspiring the future generation of conservationists. "We commit to nurturing with resources, attention, and talent a diverse national conservation movement that inspires local, state, and national action and engagement on issues that transcend political boundary."
  • Climate Mama "... is about the facts, about getting the straight scoop, about understanding Climate Change and Global Warming. We want to help you make the connections - to understand how you, your family, your friends and your community are impacting and changing our climate. Then, we want to show you what you can do to make your hectic, harried life more sustainable, for you, for your children AND for the world.” 
  • The Sierra Club represents the reverence for nature that is held by millions of people who decry the environmental destruction that occurs through ignorance or selfishness. "More than ever before, we must stand together," according to Michael Brune, Executive Director.
  • According to 350.org, "We’re Stronger When We Collaborate. Climate change isn’t just an environmental issue, or a social justice issue, or an economic issue — it’s all of those at once. It’s one of the biggest challenges humanity has ever faced, and we’re going to have to work together to solve it.That means bringing people together — not just environmentalists, but students, business owners, faith groups, labor unions, universities and more—and building diverse coalitions that are strong enough to put pressure on governments and stand up to the fossil fuel industry."
  • According to The Story of Stuff, "One of our core beliefs as an organization is that change is possible when people work together. So instead of being paralyzed by anger or overwhelmed by cynicism, let’s harness our collective energy and work together to create a brighter future."
  • Many, many other organizations and individual global citizens can find ways to join with others organizations to bring to the table their unselfish contributions toward solving the climate change problem.

PLEASE MAKE A GENEROUS CONTRIBUTION.

ANY SIZE CONTRIBUTION IS NEEDED AND APPRECIATED.

We want to help you make the connections - to understand how you, your family, your friends and your community are impacting and changing our climate. Then, we want to show you what you can do to make your hectic, harried life more sustainable, for you, for your children AND for the world.” 
The Sierra Club represents the reverence for nature that is held by millions of people who decry the environmental destruction that occurs through ignorance or selfishness. "More than ever before, we must stand together," according to Michael Brune, Executive Director.
According to 350.org, "We’re Stronger When We Collaborate. Climate change isn’t just an environmental issue, or a social justice issue, or an economic issue — it’s all of those at once. It’s one of the biggest challenges humanity has ever faced, and we’re going to have to work together to solve it.That means bringing people together — not just environmentalists, but students, business owners, faith groups, labor unions, universities and more—and building diverse coalitions that are strong enough to put pressure on governments and stand up to the fossil fuel industry."
According to The Story of Stuff, "One of our core beliefs as an organization is that change is possible when people work together. So instead of being paralyzed by anger or overwhelmed by cynicism, let’s harness our collective energy and work together to create a brighter future."
Many, many other organizations and individual global citizens can find ways to join with others organizations to bring to the table their unselfish contributions toward solving the climate change problem.
PLEASE MAKE A GENEROUS CONTRIBUTION.ANY SIZE CONTRIBUTION IS NEEDED AND APPRECIATED.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Change Makers at Sea is a fundraising campaign for the Youth & Elders Project;
fostering intergenerational exchange in the quest for cultural maturity and stewardship of our planet

Plot
From June 10th to 17th, 2012 an intergenerational group of 30 change makers will set sail on a Tall Ship in the Baltic Sea.
Over the course of one week, facilitated by workshops, deep conversations and the movement of the sea, the group will explore the notion of ‘cultural maturity’ in an era of global change and in the quest for a more sustainable way forward for our societies.
This is a voyage of discovery to explore and clarify the unique and diverse value of being human in all stages of life; honoring that only by combining the push for change with the wisdom of maturity can we tackle the challenges of our time.

Help Float the Boat

The Youth & Elders project is gathering a small group of dedicated people that are ready to support each other, each other’s projects and each other’s passion for collectively illuminating a better future. Together we’re reaching out into the world to spark the imagination across communities, generations, cultures and countries.

We are asking for $6892 - which is the equivalent of €5250, the bare minimum it takes to float the ship. For every cent you contribute we get a little bit closer to this aim!

All contributions go to our scholarship fund that will help ensure that this experience is inclusive and that we can reach the diverse group of people needed for this exchange to ripple out into the world.

If you can't support us with money, don’t worry! There are other important ways of supporting us:

  • by helping us reach out to others who might endorse the project
  • by providing us with media coverage
  • by linking your important organisation to ours
  • by contributing your fantastic ideas, vision and drive to see Youth and Elders across the globe come together in a strong alliance for tomorrow


Don’t hesitate. Contact us at info@youthandelders.org

About the Youth & Elders Project:

Website ( www.youthandelders.org )
Facebook ( www.facebook.com/youthandelders )
Twitter ( www.twitter.com/youthandelders  )

Vision

We have a vision of transcending the paradigm of expansion growth, of creatively maturing as a society and joyfully collaborating across the generations to get there.

Mision

Together we will explore the potential of intergenerational collaboration for sustainability, and seek ways in which we can step into our individual and collective brilliance.

Outcome

The conversations we have had so far are already having an impact - like ripples which spread outwards as a boat moves through the sea. We are touching friends and colleagues, and friends we haven't met yet. And they in turn are having conversations that are touching others - and the conversation expands.
As circle meets circle, energies and enthusiasm combine and become the bow wave of the boat’s passage in June and we believe they will contribute to sparkling new insights in the wake of its passage.

To assist in spreading the outcomes and to facilitate the community of explorers forming around the project, we are developing and assembling a suite of communications and narrative tools. Storytellers are joining our circles as well.

  • We are inviting a documentary film maker to join us and film the voyage.
  • The outcomes of this ‘journey of discovery’ will be recorded and shaped into a booklet.
  • Journalists are sharing our journey to increase our visibility.
  • We are hosting SKYPE circles with engaged, knowledgeable people from around the world to explore the different facets of youth and eldership.
  • These inspiring conversations are being harvested to be shared as podcasts and graphic recordings.
  • Our website is both an entry point and an outlet to catalyse the ongoing dialogue.
  • A Youth and Elders Council is being formed based on the sailing trip to inform, advise, inspire, challenge, support, critique, expand, connect and surprise us… all in turn and as needed.
  • This council will help shape a project that becomes an organism of its own, where future explorations take the questions and lessons of the project forward into local communities around the world.


Any excess money after we return to port will be invested in the future of a sustainable Youth & Elders initiative that can reach out in the future.

People

The project team is headed by:

  • Benjamin Kafka, Impuls, Germany (www.impuls.net)
  • Mark Hessellund Beanland, Denmark (www.markbeanland.com)
  • Erik van Lennep, Tepui, US/Ireland (www.tepuidesign.com)


With the unyielding support of:

  • Valentina Catena, Italy: Project Development
  • Anne Madsen, Denmark: Graphic Recording
  • Andrew Bateman, Canada: Video
  • Thomas Elsted, Denmark: Web Development
  • Dea Cisar, Denmark: Podcasts and Audio

About our Boat

The boat, The Lovis, is staffed by a core group of permanent crew, including the skipper. Part of the team-building and the learning experience includes sharing duties on board, including the actual handling of the boat. Don’t worry if you’ve never been sailing before, the ship’s permanent crew is on hand to explain and teach; to quite literally ‘show you the ropes’. And they know her intimately, having rebuilt her themselves, and spending each winter on upkeep and overhauling her.
“The Lovis is a social experiment chamber. She offers personal development opportunities in many directions. In addition to the content focus groups, we want to bring alive the traditional maritime experience of life on the water. The way we operate the ship, reflects the idea of the project. The crew collaborates with the groups, makes suggestions and tries to be a model. (from the 'Lovis' crew)

More information on www.youthandelders.org and www.lovis.de


Your contribution will help seed new projects, new collaborations and new relationships which will be born through the fusion of elder perspectives and skills-mentoring with the fire and idealism of youth in a shared quest for a healthier and thriving world.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Kristen Mandala. Currently, I am in my third year at Dalhousie University studying International Development.

In 2009, I took my first volunteer trip to Kenya with Me to We. Since then my desire to help others in developing communities around the world has grown a hundred-fold. This summer I have been accepted on a six-week volunteer project in Peru through Operation Groundswell; an incredible non-profit organization dedicated to environmentally conscious and ethical travel in developing regions all over the world.  

However, being a full-time student makes the prospect of funding the trip very daunting. Any and all help is incredibly appreciated! The program asks for $1,000 to be fundraised to go towards the tools and materials we will be using on the ground in Peru. With my parents generously covering some of the remaining flights and program fee, I need to come up with the remaining money in order to go on this lifechanging experience!  

What We Need & What You Get

The program fee is $2,795, with flights to and from Peru anywhere between $1,000-1,500 and the additional $1,000 needing to be fundraised. 

This trip is unique as it is adamant about emmersing oneself into the culture you're working in. No voluntourism with a safari and hotel room. We will be living like the locals in Iquitos and embracing all of the cultural wonders Peru has to offer. 

Throughout the summer leading up to the trip I will be working full-time and fundraising in my community as well. The money raised here - even if the goal is not met - will still go towards my fundraising donation, and with my job I will hopefully be able to be apart of this amazing experience.

With your help, I will be able to raise the $1,000 in order to contribute to the development project in the Amazon, as well as an additional $1,000 to pay for some of my program fee and flight costs to get me there!

The Impact

Throughout the trip our group will be working hand-in-hand with Asociacion Kallpa Iquitos, a non-profit organization that helps building environmentally sustainable communities in the region. The organization works with university students from Peru in creating sustainable resources like compost toilets in remote villages, water tanks with filtration systems, etc.

Once there, our group will be able to focus on a project that is of the most importance for the community! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any and all controbutions are incredibly appreciated! Even if it is so much as sharing with a friend or emailing the link - I will be forever grateful!

story:
My Connection to Mindanao

In April 2011, I visited Mindanao, Philippines, as a tourist and met many friendly, local people. Just before Christmas 2011, Northern Mindanao was unexpectedly hit by a devastating typhoon (named Sendong, aka Washi). Thousands drowned and tens of thousands of homes were washed away. Government and relief organizations were slow to act. I contacted those I knew through text messages and was able to channel funds instantly through Western Union for essentials like drinking water, rice, and even coffins to bury their dead. Temporary shelters were eventually set up but many are still living in them now. Water-born disease was rife after the floods. This region will still be recovering for years.

In addition, Mindanao has been a neglected region of the Philippines  because of the longstanding Muslim insurgency in the southwest of the region. The separatist movement has been further inflamed by land grabs by international mining companies, backed by government troops.

My Connection to Kiva

Earlier this year, I did some volunteer work in the IT department of a microfinancing non-profit called Kiva, based in San Francisco. Kiva connects people through lending to alleviate poverty. You can log onto kiva.org, browse a portfolio of entrepreneurs in developing nations, and make a $25 loan to a small business. Kiva works with microfinance institutions on five continents to provide loans to people without access to traditional banking systems. 100% of your loan is sent to microfinance field partners (local banks and non-profits) who administer the loans in their communities.

My Kiva Fellowship

The Kiva Fellows program offers the opportunity to volunteer abroad to help Kiva's local partners channel loans efficiently to local small entrepreuneurs (farmers, cooperatives, family businesses, individuals). I am volunteering in  Northern Mindanao, initially for 4 months, starting early October.

I will be working with 3 of Kiva's microfinancing partners in the region: Gata Daku Multipurpose Cooperative, Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., and Paglaum Multipurpose Cooperative. I will be using my professional skills to develop efficient processes, provide training, and document best practices.  

You can read more about the Kiva Fellows program at http://www.kiva.org/about/

Please Help

I am responsible for finding funding for my own mission - hence this fundraising site. My costs include international airfares, local accommodation and travel expenses, food, visa and medical prerequisites. I estimate the costs for 4 months at around $5000 or so.

Any contributions are welcome. If you cannot make a personal contribution, please share this site with those who might be able to, perhaps even your employers.
