story:
Note:

Hello everyone! Because the provost did not accept my request to miss so much school (4 days at the conference, 2 for travel, and probably 1 to recoop), I have had to defer until the summer program. All money that I raised is in savings until then, and I am working on raising the remainder in the meantime. Again, anything helps and everything is appreciated! I just need a tiny bit more to cover little costs like food and taxi fare, and I am good to go! I cannot reactivate the site, but, if you would like to donate, please contact me, and I can provide you with my address or Pay Pal information. Thank you!

 

Introduction

Hi, family, friends, and supporters!
 
My name is Erin Fagan, and I am a student at Old Dominion University in Norfolk Virginia, where I am studying marine biology/conservation, and environmental studies. I am extremely passionate about environmental conservation, and I am always on the search for opportunities to better myself, both as an activist, and as a human being.
 
I am raising money to fund an experience which I know will prove to be irreplaceable. I am hoping to attend the Women's Environmental Leadership Retreat, in the Bay Area of California. This retreat is swiftly approaching at the end of March, therefore, I must ask for your help.
 

About Me

When I am not in class, I dedicate a significant amount of my time, and more importantly of myself, to environmental activism, through my work as a Campus Coordinator and the Training Coordinator on the Greenpeace Student Board, an educator for the Elizabeth River Project, head of the Marine Biology Student Association's Planning and Outreach Committee, and more. I never let an opportunity pass me by!
 
This year, I helped to plan and execute the Second Annual Student Network Activist Convergence in Washington, D.C., and was asked to speak to various classes, both at my own college and others, about the importance of student involvement and awareness. I have met with Senators, Congressmen, and Delegates, to discuss local environmental issues and to brainstorm solutions, and after being accepted into my college's Diversity Institute, a semester-long anti-oppression and diversity training, I was invited to join the Social Entrepreneurship Council, where I have the honor of working side-by-side with social and environmental leaders in my community to spread awareness, acceptance, and empowerment, through creative solutions.
 

What is the Women's Environmental Leadership Retreat?

The Women's Environmental Leadership Retreat, held from March 21 to March 24, is an experiential workshop which is open to women of all ages who are a part of the environmental movement.

Objectives of the Retreat include exploring the intersections between environmental, social, peace, and other movements, gaining a better understanding of women's roles within the environmental movement, building relationships with influential female leaders and fellow activists, learning how to make a difference and promote a just and sustainable world... and more!


So what do I plan on doing with the skills I will gain at the Retreat? I plan on continuing to develop my leadership skills, helping me to gain confidence in myself, along with the ability to ignite excitement and passion in others, network with other activists, and promote environmental and social awareness and action. I hope to leave the retreat a more effective leader and agent of change, so that I may take my experiences as an activist to the next level.

 

What I Need to Make It Happen

- $600 for airfare from Norfolk, Virginia to San Francisco, CA
- $250 for tuition
- $150 for food and additional travel costs
 
I am hoping to raise these funds by March 8th, so that I can purchase my plane ticket as in advance as possible.

It is nearly impossible for me to express my gratitude in words. Having the opportunity to attend this retreat would be both a culmination of my dedication, but also a starting point where I can truly begin to gain the skills necessary for a career in activism, so that I can dedicate my life to making a difference.


If you are able to help me, I would like you to become a part of my journey! You can see what I mean by looking to the right side of this page.

story:
My name is Tara Magalski and I am a certified Health Coach/Nutritionist based out of NYC. My mission is to collaborate with E.P.I.C., Everyday People Initiating Change, to bring clean water to under developed villages in Africa. So far E.P.I.C has drilled 7 water wells. Our goal is to visit all 7 locations where they have drilled, and implement hygiene/sanitation programs.  The water wells are in Kawe, Weru, Mangalali, a village in Arusha, and two hamlets in Ugele. We will also be scouting locations for the 8th and 9th wells. Now is the perfect time for me to join the team because E.P.I.C is looking to expand the hygiene/sanitation programs to include health and nutrition. I was asked to volunteer to help build out a nutrition program to educate the locals on food to improve and extend their quality of life. I have been involved with this charity since 2006 and have helped E.P.I.C fund raise for each of the 7 wells they have drilled. This is a grassroots organization and 100 per cent of the donations go directly to the cause so I have decided to ask for a bit of financial support. 

We have a film crew joining us to document every step of our trip hoping to raise awareness of the tremendous injustice plaguing the developing world.  Did you know that their are still 1.1 Billion People in the world who do not have access to clean water?   And every day 4,000 children are affected by water related diseases.

By supporting me on my journey to Tanzania, I hope to raise consciousness to the real problems crippling the developing world: disease, lack of access to basic needs, poor nutrition and unnecessary death. This cause is extremely important to me because we are so fortunate to have access to organic foods and clean water when in some villages in Tanzania the locals have to walk 7 miles to collect 1 bucket of DIRTY water or wait one hour to get 1 bucket of water from a puddle.  

Water Facts -There are still 1.1 billion people in the world who do not have access to clean drinking water. 1.8 million children die every year as a result of diseases caused by unclean water and poor sanitation - this amounts to around 5000 deaths a day. More people die each year from unsafe water than from all forms of violence, including war.

E.P.I.C. (Everyday People Initiating Change) is an organization my girlfriends formed to show people of every age, race, creed or social status that we have the ability to change the world for the better every day in whatever way we choose. As everyday people, WE can initiate the change that all the world’s nations are hungering for, and there is no better day to start than TODAY!  I am honored to be on the board of E.P.I.C and I am very excited for my first journey to Africa so I ask you to please donate, big or small, to my trip to Tanzania.

I am using the money donated to:

    * Book the flight to Tanzania plus traveler's insurance

    * Purchase my Visa 

    * Get vaccines necessary

    * Survival Gear/clothing

    * Small gifts (pencils, anti-bacterial soaps, drinking straws, lotions) for locals

    * Offerings to the host families 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Some people may not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean YOU can’t help:

    * Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.

    *Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

    * Check out http://www.epicthemovement.org/

Thank you so very much and GOD BLESS!!!!

WHAT DID YOU DO TODAY?

story:
NEWSFLASH -

The world is facing two major crises

Oh No What Are They?

Peak oil and climate change.

Are we doomed? Is there a hero who can save us?

Yes there is, it’s the members of Transition Towns. 

TRANSITION TOWNS, WHAT ARE THEY?

Transition Towns are community groups with an environmental heart. There are Transition Towns all over the world carrying out amazing initiatives to bring their community together and help the planet at the same time. This is what makes them superheroes. They want to make their communities more resilient and sustainable and to combat climate change and peak oil rather then contribute to it. Rob Hopkins the creator of the Transition Network believed that by regarding both issues in unison using grassroots initiatives real change could be made. There are thousands of Transition Initiatives being carried out on a daily basis, they range from community supported agriculture, community allotments, pedal power cinemas, reskilling festivals, and that’s just to name a few. They implement fun and creative ways to make their communities more resilient and thus lowering any negatives impact on the planet.

THESE CRISES, HOW BAD ARE THEY? 

We know the world is facing an environmental crisis and this is affecting so many of us personally, professionally, financially and mentally. We have seen snow in May, houses and lives ruined to flooding, farm animals dying and this is just on our small island, never mind the catastrophes facing the world around us and the resultant climate change refugees that need to flee their homes and livlihoods. Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere are at a record high and this is causing changes to our weather patterns and climate, much of which is disastrous. Peak oil is another major issue, oil levels are dropping while oil demand is growing. We cannot continue on like this. While some of us panic and shout ‘what can be done?’ many people like transition town members are working on projects that have a positive impact on our local and global communities.

WHAT CAN THIS CAMPAIGN DO?

Our campaign is to create and run ‘Recognising Resilience – The Transition Awards’ an awards ceremony to recognise and reward transition initiatives in Ireland. Transition Towns bring together communities and work on resilient solutions. Many of these solutions and their impacts go unnoticed so we want to set up an awards ceremony to recognise the great work of these initiatives and show our appreciation and mobilise more Transition Initiatives to be carried out. The overall winner of the awards will have a documentary produced about their community and Transition Initiatives. The awards and ceremony will be used to spread the word about these community and environmental heroes. In these times of economic hardship we want to turn recession in to resilience and bring some joy and hope back to the Irish people.   

WHO IS RUNNING THE CAMPAIGN?

This campaign is being run by Elaine Doyle, Olwyn Roche and the facilitators of TINI (Transition Ireland and Northern Ireland). We are all passionate about community, resilience, sustainable development and believe that the power of people through collaboration can make real change in the world. Elaine is an engineer and Olwyn is an architect and while both these women have technical brains, they have green hearts and an entrepreneurial spirit. Both are really excited to run this campaign to raise money to run an awards show that will recognise the heroes of Transition Initiatives that often go unnoticed and to put their stories on film in the ‘Recognising Resilience Documentary’. Irish people are born and bred on stories and we want to bring the stories of the Transition members in Ireland to other Irish people and the world.

MONEY, MONEY, MONEY, WHERE WILL THE DONATIONS GO?

We are looking to raise €10,000. This money will be used to create and run the awards in Dublin, secure prizes for the winners including making a documentary to further promote and highlight their Transition Initiatives and community. As a small treat for you donors out there we have some fun perks. Our perks range from donations of €1 to €10,000. We aim to accommodate all pockets. Our perks vary from happy thoughts being sent out from our team, to handwritten cards, tree planting, an executive producer title on the documentary to having an award named after you for a year at the ‘Recognising Resilience – The Transition Awards’. We picked our perks to make you smile and make the planet smile. We are aiming to raise €10,000, splitting the money between creating and hosting the awards and making the documentary. In the case that we don’t reach our target we will alter the size of the awards and documentary to suit our budget.

OH OH I'VE NO MONEY, CAN I STILL HELP?

We understand that not everyone has finances to donate to this campaign. We ask you to check all your pockets and under your couch for even €1 to donate (you will get a happy thought in return), if you find nothing there we still have a small job for you.  Transition Initiatives are all about stories, great positive stories, something we need as much of the world is consumed with economic crisis and the entire planet is in an environmental crisis. We want you to help us spread these stories, stories about this campaign, about the ‘Recognising Resilience awards’ and about Transition Initiatives and the Transition Network. Even better then spreading stories, we want you to take action, set up your own Transition Initiatives and make a difference to the planet both for your neighbours next door and on the other side of the world. We want you to become a better local and global citizen.

AND FINALLY….

People power and resilience are the real assets we have to make changes at a local and global level for people, economy and the environment, all facets of sustainable development. Transition Initiatives are being carried out all over the world on a daily basis and we want to run the awards to let the superstars of the Irish initiatives have their day and allow them a platform for their amazing and contributory work to be recognised. Each of us is part of a local community and we all play a part as global citizens in the global community. The awards and documentary will not only recognise the great work being carried out by Transition Initiatives in Ireland at present but encourage others to set up their own initiatives and inspire Ireland to become a whole island of Transition Initiatives. From there we want to inspire the world to set up even more Transition Initiatives to become more resilient and therefore happier. We’re looking to put a smile on your face and on the face of the planet. 

 

HELP US TURN RECESSION IN TO RESILIENCE AND CREATE RECONGISING RESILIENCE - THE TRANSITION AWARDS

 

A BIG GREEN THANK YOU!

Elaine & Olwyn

story:
Terra Nova employs the poorest people in Mozambique to create compost from organic waste so small farmers can grow more crops.  We have made 600 tons of compost over three years and distributed it to 1000 small farmers already while employing up to 30 people from the dump. Farm yields have increased. 3700 tons of waste has been diverted from the Beira dump and put back into the soil. We know this works !!!

Terra Nova meets the triple bottom line:

1.Environment: Diverts organic waste and makes it into valuable compost for small farmers who use it to increase the long term quality of their soil and reduce dependence on chemical inputs, while reducing methane gas emissions.

2.Economic: Earns enough money to sustain the business without aid within 30 months.

3.Social Justice: Employs with dignity the people who used to glean the dump barehanded.

Now we need temporary help with cash flow in order to scale up and keep the work going until promised funding from Beira Agricultural Growth Corridor (BAGC), a regional institution, arrives in March 2014. We project that we will break even in March 2015 and, (provided we can secure an annual operating loan), become self-sustaining.  

Who are we?

I'm a Frenchwoman named Roura Flore who moved to Madagascar in 2003 where I became passionate about my idea to employ the very poor, help the environment, and keep local farms strong. I had a technical degree in soil science and agriculture, and a master’s in program coordination from France, but needed to understand business and marketing in Africa - so I earned an MBA in Madagascar.  In 2008 I moved to this port city of Beira in Mozambique with my two small daughters and started Terra Nova. 

Our management team is myself, Gildo Ussene in charge of sales, and Hermenegildo Dovelin charge of production. We three have been together from the beginning and my job is now mostly coordination, marketing strategy and financial management. We employ up to 30 people when in full production at our facility at the dump close to where they live.

The municipality of Beira is also our partner. We have a ten-year, no-cost agreement from them to divert mostly organic trash to our site and they buy our compost for city plantings. They have helped providing buildings and sanitary facilities where we provide safety clothing to our staff. 

The BAGC this week provided funding for us to create a research and demonstration farm to show the benefits of compost.

Why do we need your money now?

Terra Nova need short time cash money to keep employing the poorest people in Mozambique and create compost from trash for local farmers until we get promised funds in March 2014.

 

There are more than 1000 market farmers within 30 kilometers of Beira. They typically farm less than 1/2 a hectare and grow pretty much the same set of vegetables, often in rotation with rice. Multiple traders come out to the farm to buy product by the plot or per kilo. We have very good data about who these farmers are, where they are located, and what they are doing now about fertility. 

They now use nearly raw cow manure and sometimes use synthetic fertilizer on the sandy soil. Most of the nutrients are washed away annually. They have not tried compost and still don’t know its benefits. We decided to show them how compost can increase yield, improve soil texture, save water, reduce weeds and pests, and build humus and structure year after year. 

In two months we delivered 32 tons of compost in 25 kilo bags to farmers
as
a trial offer and we are now delivering to them 32 more tons of compost at 65% below our production costs or about what they pay for cow manure so they could see for themselves how it works. We kept good records about who used it. The results are very promising so far. The farmers can now see how
much their income will increase and can justify paying more for compost over manure. We are confident we have a market for 3000 tons of manure starting in March 2016 at slightly above our production costs. 

However we gave away too much of our inventory and did not sell as much as we hoped to urban gardeners. We don't have enough cash for the next few months to produce enough compost to meet the demand we have generated.

Your money will provide us the extra $3500 per month we need through March to keep us in production until an expected grant from the regional development program kicks in. We know now that we will need an annual operating loan soon so we can cope with the production and seasonal demand cycles. Right now we need your contribution to keep the doors open. 

What have we done so far?

2009  Beginning of the pilot recycling waste project

2009  Formation of the company Terra Nova

2010  Partnership with Beira municipality and Gevalor a French organization that is composting waste in Madagascar and helps to develop this kind of project in Africa

2010  Award from Initiatives of Green Business in Mozambique for the Terra Nova business plan

2010 – 2013 Participation in educational, environmental and commercial fairs and various speeches to governmental institutions and associations about the necessity to recycle waste and to sustainably improve the fertility of agricultural soils.

2011  Recycling of 2500 tons of municipal waste into 350 tons of compost and hiring 30 people

2012  Terra Nova ranked within the 100 best Small and Medium Entreprises (SME) of Mozambique

2012  On farm demonstration that compost from Terra Nova can increase crop yields by 15% to 70%

2013  Marketing campaign to demonstrate these benefits in rural areas and provide compost to 1000 famers

FAQ

Do you have a webpage? – No. Until now this has been an almost entirely local effort. No one we work with use computers and this is the first time we have sought attention from the “outside world”. We would love some help in getting a website set up and some instructions about how to maintain it. 

How can I learn more about Terra Nova? – You can contact me directly or if you are in the US you can contact David Visher who is here helping me with this campaign as a volunteer in the Farmer-to-Farmer program funded by USAID. He will be back home on July 1.

Is the compost safe for crops and people? – Yes. We follow best practice in its production and monitor temperature carefully to assure that pathogens are destroyed. Our team wears protective clothing when working with the materiel. Our product is tested regularly to make sure it is safe for the farmers’ soil. We are working to manage slightly high results in salt and copper. Because the compost is made from urban waste it cannot be certified Organic. Of course there are no Organic farms here.

What is your biggest challenge? – The farmers perceive compost as an alternative to less expensive raw cow manure. It is a challenge to explain that it is an entirely different thing. Normal branding and positioning strategies make little sense to a diverse, illiterate, cash strapped population who have been misled by outsiders many times in the past. Our strategy is to show then it works by giving them nearly free samples, but we undercapitalized that effort. We are also challenged by the high cost of operating capital; it takes three to five months to make compost for farmers who predictably demand it during three peak periods. We need either a cash reserve or an expensive operating loan.

Contact

Flore Roura
Manager
Terra Nova, Lda
00 258 82 82 26 800
terranova.beira@gmail.com

David Visher
Farmer to Farmer
Davis CA 95616
United States
530-758-2429
visher@visher-consulting.net

How do we offer our heartfelt thank you for your support?

We understand that you are not supporting this project in order to get little gifts. But we would like to acknowledge your generosity with a tangible gesture. 

For any donation we will send you a thank you email.

For any donation of 50 to 200 $, we can plant a tree in your name if you want to help the reforestation in Mozambique

For any donation of 200 to 500 $, we can give a bag of compost in your name to a poor farmer and send you a dedicated picture of that very important day !

And for any donation of 500 $ or more we will pay on your behalf one year schooling of a child from the dump ! 

 

---------------------------------------------------------

IN FRENCH !!! EN FRANCAIS !!!

 

J’ai besoin de votre aide d’urgence pour maintenir les emplois et la production de Terra Nova jusqu’à la réception de financements du BAGC (BeiraAgricultural Growth Corridor) promis pour le mois de mars 2014.

 

Depuis plus de 4 ans, je me bats pour apporter une solution durable aux problèmes majeurs que représente l’urbanisation galopante en :

- mettant sur pied le traitement (recyclage) des déchets organiques en constante augmentation

- permettant d’augmenter l’approvisionnement en légumes frais de qualité sur les marchés urbains

- améliorant les conditions de vie des plus démunis.

 

Le recyclage des déchets urbains : 

J’ai créé pour cela l’entreprise Terra Nova qui a été classée parmi les 100 meilleures PME du Mozambique l’année dernière et primée « entreprise verte mozambicaine» en 2010. J’ai réuni une équipe compétente, autonome et solidaire. En plein régime, nous avons eu plus de 30 employés dont la plupart venaient de milieux très défavorisés. Nous avons établi un très fort partenariat avec la ville de Beira et déjà recyclé plus de 3.700 tonnes de déchets urbains.

 

Un produit révolutionaire pour booster l'agriculture locale !

Les tests que nous avons menés en agriculture  ont montré d’excellents résultats : augmentation des rendements des cultures de 15 à 70 %, forte diminution de l’eau d’arrosage et des besoins en pesticides, etc. L’utilisation à grande échelle du compost permettra l’augmentation des revenus des petits maraîchers (cultivant moins qu’un demi-hectare).

Pour faire découvrir ses avantages, nous avons distribué 32 tonnes à plus de 1.000 petits producteurs qui ont été pleinement satisfaits. Leur pouvoir d’achat étant très faible, nous devons ces prochains mois vendre notre produit à prix symbolique pour garantir l’augmentation rapide de leurs revenus et faciliter le ré-achat du compost.

Cette stratégie a été très positive car elle a prouvé que la forte demande en compost permettra de pouvoir vendre la totalité de notre production future. Elle a aussi convaincu plusieurs institutions dont une, le BAGC, s’est déjà engagée à nous financer en mars 2014.

 

De quoi nous avons besoin ?

Malheureusement, nous n’avons pas pu reconstituer notre trésorerie et il nous manque 35.000 $ (26.000 €) pour autofinancer notre activité jusque-là. Par votre contribution solidaire et en relayant ce message à vos différents réseaux (outre les contacts mail pensez à facebook, linked in, viadeo, etc), vous nous permettrez de tenir jusqu’à la réception des financements du BAGC.

Pour faciliter la procédure de don , j’ai lancé cette campagne de levée de fonds. 

J’espère que d’une manière ou d’une autre vous pourrez nous aider et vous en remercie d’avance.

The BAGC this week provided funding for us to create a research and demonstration farm to show the benefits of compost.
Why do we need your money now?

Terra Nova need short time cash money to keep employing the poorest people in Mozambique and create compost from trash for local farmers until we get promised funds in March 2014.
 
There are more than 1000 market farmers within 30 kilometers of Beira. They typically farm less than 1/2 a hectare and grow pretty much the same set of vegetables, often in rotation with rice. Multiple traders come out to the farm to buy product by the plot or per kilo. We have very good data about who these farmers are, where they are located, and what they are doing now about fertility. 
They now use nearly raw cow manure and sometimes use synthetic fertilizer on the sandy soil. Most of the nutrients are washed away annually. They have not tried compost and still don’t know its benefits. We decided to show them how compost can increase yield, improve soil texture, save water, reduce weeds and pests, and build humus and structure year after year. 
In two months we delivered 32 tons of compost in 25 kilo bags to farmers asa trial offer and we are now delivering to them 32 more tons of compost at 65% below our production costs or about what they pay for cow manure so they could see for themselves how it works. We kept good records about who used it. The results are very promising so far. The farmers can now see how much their income will increase and can justify paying more for compost over manure. We are confident we have a market for 3000 tons of manure starting in March 2016 at slightly above our production costs. 
However we gave away too much of our inventory and did not sell as much as we hoped to urban gardeners. We don't have enough cash for the next few months to produce enough compost to meet the demand we have generated.
Your money will provide us the extra $3500 per month we need through March to keep us in production until an expected grant from the regional development program kicks in. We know now that we will need an annual operating loan soon so we can cope with the production and seasonal demand cycles. Right now we need your contribution to keep the doors open. 
What have we done so far?
2009  Beginning of the pilot recycling waste project
2009  Formation of the company Terra Nova
2010  Partnership with Beira municipality and Gevalor a French organization that is composting waste in Madagascar and helps to develop this kind of project in Africa
2010  Award from Initiatives of Green Business in Mozambique for the Terra Nova business plan
2010 – 2013 Participation in educational, environmental and commercial fairs and various speeches to governmental institutions and associations about the necessity to recycle waste and to sustainably improve the fertility of agricultural soils.
2011  Recycling of 2500 tons of municipal waste into 350 tons of compost and hiring 30 people
2012  Terra Nova ranked within the 100 best Small and Medium Entreprises (SME) of Mozambique
2012  On farm demonstration that compost from Terra Nova can increase crop yields by 15% to 70%
2013  Marketing campaign to demonstrate these benefits in rural areas and provide compost to 1000 famers

FAQ
Do you have a webpage? – No. Until now this has been an almost entirely local effort. No one we work with use computers and this is the first time we have sought attention from the “outside world”. We would love some help in getting a website set up and some instructions about how to maintain it. 
How can I learn more about Terra Nova? – You can contact me directly or if you are in the US you can contact David Visher who is here helping me with this campaign as a volunteer in the Farmer-to-Farmer program funded by USAID. He will be back home on July 1.
Is the compost safe for crops and people? – Yes. We follow best practice in its production and monitor temperature carefully to assure that pathogens are destroyed. Our team wears protective clothing when working with the materiel. Our product is tested regularly to make sure it is safe for the farmers’ soil. We are working to manage slightly high results in salt and copper. Because the compost is made from urban waste it cannot be certified Organic. Of course there are no Organic farms here.
What is your biggest challenge? – The farmers perceive compost as an alternative to less expensive raw cow manure. It is a challenge to explain that it is an entirely different thing. Normal branding and positioning strategies make little sense to a diverse, illiterate, cash strapped population who have been misled by outsiders many times in the past. Our strategy is to show then it works by giving them nearly free samples, but we undercapitalized that effort. We are also challenged by the high cost of operating capital; it takes three to five months to make compost for farmers who predictably demand it during three peak periods. We need either a cash reserve or an expensive operating loan.
Contact
Flore RouraManagerTerra Nova, Lda00 258 82 82 26 800terranova.beira@gmail.com
David VisherFarmer to FarmerDavis CA 95616United States530-758-2429visher@visher-consulting.net
How do we offer our heartfelt thank you for your support?
We understand that you are not supporting this project in order to get little gifts. But we would like to acknowledge your generosity with a tangible gesture. 
For any donation we will send you a thank you email.
For any donation of 50 to 200 $, we can plant a tree in your name if you want to help the reforestation in Mozambique
For any donation of 200 to 500 $, we can give a bag of compost in your name to a poor farmer and send you a dedicated picture of that very important day !
And for any donation of 500 $ or more we will pay on your behalf one year schooling of a child from the dump ! 
 
---------------------------------------------------------
IN FRENCH !!! EN FRANCAIS !!!
 
J’ai besoin de votre aide d’urgence pour maintenir les emplois et la production de Terra Nova jusqu’à la réception de financements du BAGC (BeiraAgricultural Growth Corridor) promis pour le mois de mars 2014.
 
Depuis plus de 4 ans, je me bats pour apporter une solution durable aux problèmes majeurs que représente l’urbanisation galopante en :
- mettant sur pied le traitement (recyclage) des déchets organiques en constante augmentation
- permettant d’augmenter l’approvisionnement en légumes frais de qualité sur les marchés urbains
- améliorant les conditions de vie des plus démunis.
 
Le recyclage des déchets urbains : 
J’ai créé pour cela l’entreprise Terra Nova qui a été classée parmi les 100 meilleures PME du Mozambique l’année dernière et primée « entreprise verte mozambicaine» en 2010. J’ai réuni une équipe compétente, autonome et solidaire. En plein régime, nous avons eu plus de 30 employés dont la plupart venaient de milieux très défavorisés. Nous avons établi un très fort partenariat avec la ville de Beira et déjà recyclé plus de 3.700 tonnes de déchets urbains.
 
Un produit révolutionaire pour booster l'agriculture locale !
Les tests que nous avons menés en agriculture  ont montré d’excellents résultats : augmentation des rendements des cultures de 15 à 70 %, forte diminution de l’eau d’arrosage et des besoins en pesticides, etc. L’utilisation à grande échelle du compost permettra l’augmentation des revenus des petits maraîchers (cultivant moins qu’un demi-hectare).
Pour faire découvrir ses avantages, nous avons distribué 32 tonnes à plus de 1.000 petits producteurs qui ont été pleinement satisfaits. Leur pouvoir d’achat étant très faible, nous devons ces prochains mois vendre notre produit à prix symbolique pour garantir l’augmentation rapide de leurs revenus et faciliter le ré-achat du compost.
Cette stratégie a été très positive car elle a prouvé que la forte demande en compost permettra de pouvoir vendre la totalité de notre production future. Elle a aussi convaincu plusieurs institutions dont une, le BAGC, s’est déjà engagée à nous financer en mars 2014.
 
De quoi nous avons besoin ?
Malheureusement, nous n’avons pas pu reconstituer notre trésorerie et il nous manque 35.000 $ (26.000 €) pour autofinancer notre activité jusque-là. Par votre contribution solidaire et en relayant ce message à vos différents réseaux (outre les contacts mail pensez à facebook, linked in, viadeo, etc), vous nous permettrez de tenir jusqu’à la réception des financements du BAGC.
Pour faciliter la procédure de don , j’ai lancé cette campagne de levée de fonds. 
J’espère que d’une manière ou d’une autre vous pourrez nous aider et vous en remercie d’avance.

story:
"Life is either a daring adventure or nothing at all!"

The Love Story

Meet Lee and Outdoors.
The year was 2003, having survived the Y2K outbreak a few years earlier, Lee and Outdoors had lived their whole life without the knowledge of each other's existence. In a magical place call the BWCA, located beyond the city skyline where there existed only nature and the lakes filled the horizon, it was the making of a fateful encounter. It was love at first sight...Actually, love after a week. It was Lee's first experience camping, canoeing, and portaging through her participation in YMCA Camp Menogyn's 8-day canoe trip. The sound of loons, sleeping under the stars, watching the sun set while eating mac and cheese, gliding across the lake, carrying canoes, and breathing in the fresh air; these were all experiences that spark a lifelong love. A love that continues to be irrepacable, indescribable, and fulfilling. 

About Me

My name is Lee Vue, a college graduate from the University of MN-Twin Cities with a BA in Political Science. I am Hmong-American, spicy food addict, photographer, and loves to travel. I'm always seeking a new adventure that will add to my learning, love and passion for the environment and outdoors, and to make a difference in my community (and world).

The 2013 Adventure of a Lifetime

This September, Paddle Forward will embark on and film a three-month long canoe journey down the Mississippi River from the headwaters in Lake Itasca, Minnesota, to New Orleans. As we paddle, we will engage communities in an ongoing dialogue about their relationships to and interactions with this watertrail to give voice to the Mississippi River, its inhabitants, and the many perspectives we encounter along the way. Upon completion of the trip, we will produce a documentary of this journey so that these vital conversations can continue with others beyond the flow of the river.

Why Paddle the Mississippi? 

As the climate debate comes to a head in the United States, it’s easy to get caught up in abstract political jargon and lose sight of the everyday people whose lives revolve around the health of a natural resource. I love paddling rivers that encompass an array of social and environmental issues because they tell a great story. One that needs to be heard.

A personal reason that I want to be part of this paddle is that I want to inspire others that they can follow their passions wholeheartedly. As a Hmong-American woman, I especially want to empower young girls of color that they can change the world one adventure at a time. It's not everyday that we hear stories about a Hmong women doing unbelieveable things especially involving the outdoors. I want to change the status quo -- Dream to become explorers, adventurers, movers and shakers, and expeditioners.

What I Need

For the trip, I will mostly need help to cover the expense of food.

Food for one day:

$11

Food for one week:

$77

Food for one month:

$308

Food for the whole trip:

        $924

While it would be nice if there were no other expenses, there are.  Both myself and my canoe need to come back to Minneapolis in one piece.

Ship a canoe to Minneapolis

  $226

Pay for one person to travel back to the Twin Cities

        $350

                                                                         Total Trip Cost:         $1,500

*** All extra funds raised over the $1,500 campaign goal will go directly to a general fund for other members of Paddle Forward.

What Do You Get If You Help Fund My Campaign?

$15 – Karma points!

$50 – A postcard sent from wherever were are and some karma points.

$100 – A postcard, Paddle ForwardT-shirt, your name featured in the credits of our documentary, and some karma points.

$500 – A postcard, Paddle for Change T-shirt, your name featured in the credits of our documentary, shout-outs to you on Paddle Forward's social media sites, and more karma points! Plus, you'll receive a product/merchandise (handmade/designed/crafted) from elefut (www.facebook.com/elefut).

$1,000 – A postcard, Paddle Forward T-shirt, your name featured in the credits of our documentary, shout-outs to you on Paddle Forward's social media sites, endless amount of karma points, a product/merchandise from elefut, a copy of the documentary, and my eternal gratitude. 

The Impact

Without your support, this trip is not possible.  Not only will I personally grow from this challenging and unique experience, but I will connect with new people to develop a constructive dialogue about our lives in the United States and the world.

Upon returning, we will have the incredible opportunity to construct a national dialogue about the Mississippi River by creating a documentary of our experiences.  This documentary will spark conversations about our national resources, water usage, the meaning of community, and the very nature (pun!) of what it means to be "in nature."  We believe strongly that these are dialogues that our nation must be having more often with one another, and I would be proud to be a part of this legacy.  

Other Ways to Help Support Us

You might not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can't help.  Please spread the word about our campaign by sharing this page on Facebook, Twitter, or any other social platform you prefer. 

Send me a message if you think you have connections or information that may be helpful for us.  Though our group has varying degrees of paddling experience we can always use community support.  We welcome your insights. 

http://www.paddle4ward.com

http://www.facebook.com/paddle4ward

http://www.paddle-forward.tumblr.com

http://www.twitter.com/paddleforward

Thank You!

story:
The Mobile Permaculture Lab -Taking Permaculture on the Road.

The Mobile Permaculture Lab is a project of the permaculture non profit, Permatecture Design.

Our converted permaculture school bus is designed with a temporary solar panel installation, water catchment, aquaponics, and an herb shop. The bus is designed as a mobile permaculture education vehicle, that is headed west to teach mobile permaculture education. The on board seed shop, garden laboratory, and apothecary allow our teachers to stop anywhere and set up workshops! We are taking permaculture on the road, heading west for fall wildcrafting season, and creating herbal products along the way.

We need your help to fund our education program by helping us complete the bus design! Our missing pieces include - veggie oil conversion, competion of solar installation, and the installation of our wood burning stove!

When we return east this spring we will bring back herbs and medicinals, and new knowledge to teach and share. Long term, we intend to utilize the Mobile Permaculture Lab as a teaching tool for children and adults, and as a mobile project support vehicle.

Why We Need Cash Bucks.

We Need Funds For ...

VEGGIE OIL CONVERSION - $1500.00

SOLAR PANEL - $500.00

All funds raised will be put towards veggie oil conversion and solar panel installation completion. We thank you for your donations! As a thank you, you can receive a number of permaculture perks :)

 

Why Mobile Permaculture Education Matters.

The Mobile Permaculture Lab allows us to travel throughout the US teaching permaculture to schools, programs, farms and gardens. Along the way we will be provided the opportunity to both teach permaculture and lead project based workshops, we will have the opportunity to connect local permaculture efforts together, expanding the national permaculture practitioner and teacher web.

Education should be free, and it should make sense. The Mobile Permaculture Lab allows us the opportunity to reskill our population through practical application & permaculture experience.

As we travel, we will be creating seed balls of wildflowers for bees, milkweed for butterflies, and edibles for humans, and throwing them to replant pollinator pathways across America, marking our travels!

The Mobile Permaculture Lab - coming to a town near you!

How Can You Help?

(1) Donate! We appreciate all your support

(2) Tell our story to your friends. Spread the word about molbie permaculture education!

(3) Share our campaign!

story:
Who We Are

We are students in the Conway School's graduate program in sustainable landscape planning and design. We’d like to share with you a special opportunity that will allow us to use our education to serve a community in need.

The Project

An integral part of our program is working with real-world clients on planning and design projects. For the spring term community planning project, our program was presented with a unique opportunity to aid in the long-term recovery and rebuilding of Tacloban, Philippines.  The city of Tacloban was terribly devastated in November 2013 by Typhoon Haiyan, known locally as Yolanda.

Kusog Tacloban (giving strength to Tacloban) is an organization working to make sure that aid is swiftly and equitably distributed to where it is needed most. Kusog Tacloban has asked our program to devise an audit strategy that can be used by Tacloban’s neighborhood councils to conduct site assessments during the rebuilding of the city. This audit strategy will equip community members with basic criteria which can be used to make ecologically and socially sustainable decisions regarding post-disaster development.

The Conway School, with the support of the student body, agreed to take on this project free of charge. We have been assigned to the project. Most of our work this spring will be conducted remotely from our campus in western Massachusetts. We believe, however, that a trip to Tacloban is essential to the design process that this project requires.

How You Can Help 

We would like to ask for your help in making this opportunity possible. If we are able to travel to Tacloban, we will use the trip to complete fieldwork, gather data, meet with local officials and non-governmental representatives, and—perhaps most importantly—familiarize ourselves with the neighborhood councils that will be implementing the audit strategy. By visiting with community members, we can make our report as relevant and contextually sensitive as possible.

Our goal is to raise $5,000, which we will use for airfare, travel immunizations, local transport, lodging, food, and other expenses related to an estimated 10-day-long trip. Our hope is that with your help we will surpass our fundraising goal, in which case we will donate the proceeds to Kusog Tacloban to further support its work. Our time frame for project completion is short, as we're working within school schedule constraints. The project will be completed at the end of June, so we're hoping to travel as soon as possible.

We appreciate any support that you might be able to offer; the smallest amount makes all the difference! With your contribution, we would like to involve you in the project. We commit to maintaining a blog documenting the progress of the project, and we will make the project report available to you upon its completion.

The links below have more information on Kusog Tacloban and the Conway School. Please let us know if you have any questions and feel free to contact us via this page, Facebook, email, or phone. Thank you for taking time to watch our video. We hope that you'll be a part of this project. Take care!

Trevor & Marie

tacloban@csld.edu

www.csld.edu

www.kusogtacloban.org

story:
We are delighted to announce the launch of the Blue Bahr Film Festival - the region's premier ocean celebration and film competition coming up this August in Beirut,  Lebanon!   To be held in Beirut's newest multi-complex Cinemacity theatres, The Blue Bahr Ocean film festival aims to offer a visually stunning showcase of local, regional and international ocean films and videos, designed to entertain, educate, and inspire the public and instill an appreciation for the ocean. The festival will place great emphasis on community outreach and public education about our oceans, the world’s most important resource.

Our oceans provide life for our entire planet.  Yet we are at a crucial moment in history where more than 90% of all the world’s big fish are gone, many of our coral reefs have disappeared, and our oceans are getting warmer and more acidic.  Our seas and oceans are in serious trouble, and Lebanon’s Mediterranean is no exception.  Lebanon’s beaches and coastal waters are in critical condition as threats from marine debris, plastic pollution and overfishing are acute.

By showcasing the world’s best ocean films and inviting top experts and filmmakers, the Blue Bahr Film Festival will become a much anticipated regional event.  The mission of Blue Bahr is also to encourage local filmmakers and our next generation of underwater filmmakers, and we will be awarding prizes to best local and regional films.  The 2014 Edition of the Blue Bahr Film Festival will showcase award winning films such as Sharkwater, Planet Ocean, Revolution, Here and Now,  Chasing Ice, Plastic Oceans, and local productions highlighting Lebanon’s underwater treasures and ocean enthusiasts.

We ask your support on this exciting initiative, in order to encourage the Lebanese, its younger generations and future leaders to understand and appreciate the importance of our oceans. Your generous contributions will be used to subtitle films in Arabic, print brochures, posters and marketing materials and to help develop a website to provide educational content and media online.  The Blue Bahr Film Festival operates as a not-for-profit organization and all profits and funds will be used to support the Blue Bahr Film Festival media and educational initiative. 

The Lebanese have shared a special bond with the sea since the time of the Phoenicians, let's show that we care about this precious resource.

Let’s celebrate the sea!
story_txt:
We are delighted to announce the launch of the Blue Bahr Film Festival - the region's premier ocean celebration and film competition coming up this August in Beirut,  Lebanon!   To be held in Beirut's newest multi-complex Cinemacity theatres, The Blue
Bahr Ocean film festival aims to offer a visually stunning showcase of local, regional and international ocean
films and videos, designed to entertain, educate, and inspire the public and
instill an appreciation for the ocean. The festival will place great emphasis on community outreach and public
education about our oceans, the world’s most important resource. 
Our oceans provide life for
our entire planet.  Yet we are at a
crucial moment in history where more than 90% of all the world’s big fish are
gone, many of our coral reefs have disappeared, and our
oceans are getting warmer and more acidic.  Our seas and oceans are in serious trouble, and Lebanon’s Mediterranean is no
exception.  Lebanon’s beaches and coastal waters are in critical condition
as threats from marine debris, plastic pollution and overfishing are acute. By
 showcasing the world’s best ocean films and inviting top experts and 
filmmakers, the Blue Bahr Film Festival will become a much
anticipated regional event.  The mission of Blue Bahr is also to 
encourage local filmmakers and our next generation of underwater 
filmmakers, and we will be awarding prizes to best local and regional 
films.  The 2014 Edition of the Blue Bahr Film
Festival will showcase award winning films such as Sharkwater, Planet Ocean,
Revolution, Here and Now,  Chasing Ice, Plastic Oceans, and local productions highlighting Lebanon’s
underwater treasures and ocean enthusiasts. We ask your support on this exciting
initiative, in order to encourage the Lebanese, its younger generations and
future leaders to understand and appreciate the importance of our oceans. Your generous contributions will be
used to subtitle films in Arabic, print brochures, posters and marketing
materials and to help develop a website to provide educational content and
media online.  The Blue Bahr Film Festival
operates as a not-for-profit organization and all profits and funds will be
used to support the Blue Bahr Film Festival media and educational
initiative.  The Lebanese have shared a special
bond with the sea since the time of the Phoenicians, let's show that we care
about this precious resource.Let’s celebrate the sea!

story:
Chi siamo e cosa faremo 

(English version below)

Ciao siamo Giulia e Michal, apprendisti linguisti e antropologi che hanno deciso di intraprendere una vita di maggiore autosufficienza e sostenibilità. Ci siamo fissati sull'idea che i rapporti umani e le relazioni con l'ambiente siano intrecciati ed eccoci qua come Echoes of Ecologies: il nostro progetto di ricerca indipendente, ossia organizzato da soli, in Sud America. Arrivati a San Paulo a fine gennaio 2016 ci muoveremo per quattro mesi per il sud del Brasile, verso la regione argentina di Misiones, per arrivare in Paraguay ed infine in Bolivia. Lì incontreremo ONG, associazioni, scuole ecologiche popolari, collettivi o singole persone impegnate quotidianamente in pratiche ecologiche e sostenibili. Conosceremo chi si occupa di:

  • agricoltura sostenibile, agro-ecologia e permacultura;
  • diritto all'acqua e alla terra;
  • sovranità alimentare ed alimentazione cosciente;
  • recupero di spazi urbani abbandonati per creare orti pubblici;
ma anche chi contribuisce, tramite media, scrittura e varie forme artistiche, alla sensibilizzazione verso modi di vivere più conviviali e rispettosi delle persone e dell'ambiente. Soprattutto condivideremo la loro quotidianità: ascoltando, imparando, facendo e vivendo. Questa esperienza non sarà solo nostra, ma anche tua perché tutto ciò verrà documentato in un blog foto-narrativo che seguirà contemporaneamente il nostro viaggio e le esperienze condivise.

Il vostro contributo è fondamentale perché questo progetto possa accadere! Non terminerà alla fine del viaggio, anzi segnerà l'inizio di un percorso più ampio e duraturo di azioni di sensibilizzazione.

Il seme è stata piantato. Aiutaci a far germogliare la pianta!

Le nostre necessità e le vostre ricompense

Abbiamo già i biglietti aerei, anche l'assicurazione medica (facciamo le corna!) e i vaccini. Secondo i nostri calcoli ci servono 3000 euro in due per percorrere all'incirca 8 mila chilometri andata e ritorno, in quattro mesi, usando il trasporto pubblico! Aiutateci ad iniziare questo progetto di vita, per il resto ci arrangeremo!



Durante questo tempo ci potrete seguire giorno per giorno dal nostro blog dedicato alla divulgazione delle pratiche di esistenza/resistenza che conosceremo. Andate già a visitarlo per vedere la lista delle associazioni che hanno già appoggiato la nostra idea e che non vedono l'ora di riceverci! Il nostro non sarà un itinerario fisso, ma cambierà se lungo il percorso troveremo altri luoghi o persone interessanti da incontrare per raccontarvelo!

Il vostro sostegno verrà ricompensato con il nostro immenso affetto, oltre a delle piccole sorprese personalizzate che prepareremo per voi in segno di riconoscenza!

L'impatto

Echoes of Ecologies sono gli echi delle ecologie che ascolteremo in Sud America. Ecologie intese come relazioni tra gli esseri umani e l'ambiente. Tutte queste voci le riporteremo a casa con noi e da voi. Ma non finisce qui! La nostra testimonianza delle tematiche ambientali e sociali, le problematiche e le risposte locali legate ad esse, non sarà solo importante per informare, ma al nostro rientro contribuirà a sensibilizzare in maniera pratica mostrando che le possibilità per una maggiore convivialità, tra le persone nell'ambiente, esistono.

Noi ci impegneremo a seguire e diffondere le vie della sostenibilità sociale ed ecologica che avremo appreso. Crediamo in questo progetto! E tu?

Vuoi impegnarti anche tu?

Sappiamo che non tutti potrete aiutarci economicamente, ma se siete appassionati non significa che non vi possiate impegnare.
Chiunque può mandare il link della nostra campagna e del nostro blog a chi pensa possa interessarsi al progetto.
Se inoltre credete di conoscere qualcuno occupato nelle pratiche che affronteremo, nei luoghi che visiteremo, fatevi vivi e scriveteci pure! Grazie a tutti!

Giulia e Michal
Siamo tutti echi delle ecologie!
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Who we are and what we will do

Hi! These are Giulia and Michal, young linguists and anthropologists who have decided to undertake a more self-sufficient and sustainable life. We got kind of obsessed about the idea that human relationships and relations with the environment are intertwined and here we are as Echoes of Ecologies: our independent, as in organised totally by ourselves, research project in South America. We'll be in Sao Paulo at the end of January 2016, from the south of Brasil we'll travel for four months going through the Argentinian region of Misiones, towards Paraguay and Bolivia at last. We will meet NGOs, associations, popular ecological schools, collectives and single people daily engaged in ecological and sustainable practices. Particularly who deals with:

  • sustainable agriculture, agroecology and permaculture;
  • water and land rights;
  • food sovereignty and conscious nutrition;
  • reappropriation of abandoned urban spaces to create public gardens;

but also who contributes, through the media, writing and various artistic forms to raise awareness about ways of living that are more convivial and respectful of people and the environment. Especially, we'll share their life on a daily basis: listening, learning, doing and living. This won't be just our experience, but also yours because everything will be documented in a photo-narrative blog that will follow our travel and shared experiences.

Your contribution is fundamental for our project to get started! It will not finish at the end of the journey, actually it'll mark  the beginning of a wider circle of awareness actions.

The seed has been planted. Help us make the plant sprout!

What you can give us and what we can offer

We already have the plane tickets, medical insurance (let's hope for best!) and the vaccinations. According to our calculations we will need 3000 euros for the two of us to cover around 8000 kilometres both ways, during four months, using public transport!

Help us start this life project, we'll sort out the rest! 



During this period you may follow us day by day on our blog dedicated to spread the word about the practices of existence/resistance that we'll discover. Visit our blog now to see the list of associations that already sustain our ideas and can't wait to receive us! Ours won't be a fixed itinerary, but it may change in case we find other interesting places or individuals to meet along the way for us to tell you!

Your support will be rewarded with our immense affection, plus our little personalised surprises that we'll prepare for you as a gratitude symbol!

The impact

Echoes of Ecologies are the echoes that we will listen to in South America. Ecologies intended as relations between humans and the environment. All of these voices we'll bring back home with us and to you. But it doesn't stop here! Our testimony about environmental and social matters - their related problems and local solutions - won't just be important to inform, but back home it will contribute to raise awareness through practical manners in order to show that possibilities for a more convivial life, between humans among the environment, actually exist. 

We will put  effort in disclosing the routes of social and ecological sustainability that we will have learnt. We believe in this project! And you?

Wanna get involved?

We understand that not all of you can help us economically, but if you are passionate about the topic it doesn't mean you cannot get involved.

Anyone can post the link to our campaign and blog, or send them to whoever might be interested in our project.

Moreover, if you happen to know anyone engaged in the practices we'll deal with, in the places we'll visit, do not hesitate to get in touch with us! Thanks to all of you!

Giulia e Michal

We are all echoes of ecologies!

story:
Hello,

I am Hunny Kaushal from Ludhiana,Punjab,India.

My Brother just visited Nepal.

A village was there in Nepal which had 35 homes.

Those 35 homes were Damaged during Earthquake.

These people are still homeless and eating from somewhere.

They said that they never get any help from their Government.

So i decided to collect money through Indiegogo and will help them to make their homes.

Let us Help each other and give the true meaning of Humanity to God.

picture attached is taken from Google.

Thank you

story:
Short Summary

In 2001 Chimp-n-Sea Wildlife Conservation Fund (www.chimp-n-sea.org) and Lembaga JARI founders were travelling in West Papua when they came up with a dream . . . to create an 'International Floating Marine Park' that would travel the Indonesian seas leaving marine protected areas, improved marine habitats, and sustainable fisheries in its wake. Twelve years later, in 2013, this dream started to become a reality with the purchase of a 51ft fishing vessel, 'Yosina', that is currently being retrofitted as a conservation education and research platform (see http://www.vecotourism.org/panos/prototours/yosina/). We are excited to launch the boat in the waters of Saleh Bay, Sumbawa, in the coming months but still have some work to do before then.

This is where you come in!

When the boat is completed we will partner with local communities, researchers, other wildlife NGOs, and Eco- and vEcotourists to further our mission of creating sustainable seas in West Nusa Tenggara, a beautiful region of Indonesia and home to blue whales, marlin, sea turtles and an abundance of corals and reef fish.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for funding to get 'Yosina' underway. The major retrofit has been completed, however we still need to finish the interior fixtures, bunks, kitchen, library etc, install freshwater tanks, as well as purchase diving, snorkelling and safety equipment, make a sail and mast, and paint the boat. We also need funding for a captain and crew . . .

Examples of funding required:

    • $200 - two water tanks
    • $250 - GPS unit
    • $700 - kitchen fixtures
    • $400 - mattresses and bedding
    • $100 - radio
    • $200 - generator
    • $100 - lifejackets
    • $400 - lifeboat / dinghy / paddles
    • $100 - rainwater collection system
    • $2000 - solar panels and batteries
    • $200 - compressor
    • $1000 - 10x snorkelling equipment
    • $5000 - 5x diving equipment
    • $200 - captain salary per month
    • $100 - assistant salary per month
    • $400 - project manager salary per month
    • $500 - advertising, painting, activities for launch party

All money raised on this site will go directly to funding 'Yosina'. If we do not make our goal, we will prioritize what is most in need of funding in order to get 'Yosina' underway. If we make more than our initial goal (which we hope will be the case!) the funding will go towards our projects including 'sign the reef' reef-rehabilitation, mangrove replanting, waste management, educational workshops, and conservation research.

Every contribution is helpful and we would like to honor all our donors with personalized thank-yous, and invitations to take part in upcoming vEcotours of Saleh Bay and elsewhere. Since Chimp-n-Sea is a 501(c)(3) organization, tax receipts will be issued.

The Impact

The Coral Triangle area between Indonesia, Philippines and Papua New Guinea is home to the greatest diversity of coral reefs and fishes in the world. It is also suffering from the impacts of trash in the oceans, and illegal fishing techniques such as dynamite and cyanide fishing, trawling and drift-netting which catch not only target species but also destroy other species and habitats. Lembaga JARI has been working with communities in Lombok and Sumbawa for more than 10 years to educate and encourage fishers to utilize more sustainable fishing practices, to monitor and adjust fishing pressure, to deal appropriately with waste, and to develop low-impact community-based ecotourism in order to ensure long-term sustainability of their marine resources.

The addition of 'Yosina' to the team will help deliver these messages, provide a base for 'in the water' education and vEcotourism, as well as providing a platform for conservation research in the region.

Other Ways You Can Help

Although we need funding to help make this project a reality, we could also do with help to get the word out about 'Yosina', the work that Chimp-n-Sea and JARI are doing and marine conservation in general.

  • Please tell your friends and family and others who may be interested (Indiegogo has share tools you can use to help with this)
  • Make wise choices when it comes to buying seafood and caring for our oceans
  • Volunteer with vEcotourism (www.vecotourism.org)

long-term sustainability of their marine resources. The 
addition of 'Yosina' to the team will help deliver these messages, 
provide a base for 'in the water' education and vEcotourism, as well as 
providing a platform for conservation research in the region. Other Ways You Can HelpAlthough we need funding to help make this project a reality, we 
could also do with help to get the word out about 'Yosina', the work 
that Chimp-n-Sea and JARI are doing and marine conservation in general. 
Please tell your friends and family and others who may be interested (Indiegogo has share tools you can use to help with this)
Make wise choices when it comes to buying seafood and caring for our oceans
Volunteer with vEcotourism (www.vecotourism.org)

story:
Short Summary:

My name is Richard Migliori, a High School Construction Skills instructor.  My wife and I own an All Volunteer, Endurance road race team.  We have been successfully opperating this team for seven years and have included many students.  Racing is expensive and we came up with this product to set an ongoing foundation to expand this valuable learning experience!  This product will allow me to establish an Auto X club at our local High School to teach the new generation about, disciplines, work ethics, respect, and Skills for a more productive adulthood.  Your contribution will open the doors for future mechanics, designers, and problem solvers. 

 

What We Need & What You Get:

We ae asking for assistance to raise $90,000, to tool, manufacture, and market this great product.  You will be eligable to receive a tye caddy and phoots of the race team and a progress news letter of the great learning experiences from the students.  Your name can be displayed on the race car and the possiblity of lots of magizine exposure! 

The students, volunteers, and me are so excited of this project that if more funds are needed to complete, I will seek private funding to make it happen!  This is PASSION, and I'm ALL IN! They make a great gift for the craftman in your family!

 

The Impact:

Today's education is losing sight of real "HANDS ON" training.  I see it everyday.  Here is my chance to make a better community and world by devoting this project to all that is good.  This pays dividends for the future!  It reduces industrial waste which translates to less in the lansfills regardless of how little or big. It can contribute to industry profits. It is teachng young adults about life, dependability, marketing, shipping, and becoming a model citizen. Seven years of successful racing, inviting students and volunteers has created a firm foundation and noteriety in the amatuer ranks,  Racing is expensive and this will help us continue and serve more students than ever before! Additional procedes from the sales of the Tye Caddy will be donated to Cancer research as my wife is a cancer survivor.  There are no losers in this adventure!

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Somebody always knows someone who knows someone that is interseted in helping! Cash is not always the ticket to success, but knowing the right people and getting them involved!  You can be that connection!  Be a TOWN CRYER, shout it at your next party!
