story:
One Island, One community, Caretakers of the Trees

I want to tell you a story about a young boy who stood in a blockade against the forestry company, Macmillan Blodel, in Squirrel Cove, many years ago. At the time of this blockade, his brothers and sisters were not defined by race or color. Where, in this moment of time, the only line drawn was the hand reaching out in friendship. The Island united, as one society, standing up for what they believed in. There is no greater power than being selfless! Linnaea Farm School and its parents made a conscious choice to close school and stand united as a community. There was no school, no chopping wood, no business -- only the idea that it was the right thing to do! He remembers that time. Everything stopped, his Cortesian society stood as one people, one voice, and one idea. At that moment, the community held the balance of nature in its hands, and it felt empowering.

The boy was a proud person that day, yes, demonstrating social democracy at its core-self. On that day, the community relationships with each other stopped the clear cutting of the forest. That boy is now a man, and hopes that the community will stand again and safe guard the forest where he grew up.

I will come home to continue what I started as a young boy. It is time to stand again as a community. That will not be a great day -- it will be an amazing day.

Kiyoshi Kosky

Dear Donors,

I am Kiyoshi Kosky and I grew up on Cortes Island. As a child, I was part of a blockade. We successfully stopped McMillan Bloedel from industrial clear cut logging our island and if we have to, we will do it again. Our island is threatened once again, as they are coming for our most precious resource, the old growth trees, and will be liquidating our mature second growth forest also.

This time, the beast is Brookfield Asset Management Corporation, based in Toronto. The company is an off-shore conglomerate avoiding Canadian taxes. It does not care for the well-being of our community and the ecology on the island. Brookfield Asset Management Corporation’s logging company, Island Timberlands, has stated that it will use herbicides to suppress foliage during the replanting process. They promise buffers to protect wetlands and waterways, but those are small compared to what many call for, and may poison our wetlands, shallow aquifers, and waterways if these toxic chemicals are used.

The old growth on Cortes is the heart and life force of the island. The old growth is what keeps our Island’s quality of health well. These old growth forests are the anchors of our shallow aquifers. Every person on the island relies on aquifers and Island Timberlands chemicals will not help those water supplies. Salt Spring Island fought hard to make sure it didn’t have to ship water onto the island when a logging company came knocking at their door looking to clear cut huge regions and we will do the same.

My parent’s former property on Cortes Island had a shallow well dug. When I was a kid, the well was dry two months of the year. Today, that well is dry six to eight months of the year. We cannot afford to sacrifice our island’s water supply for a corporation that will take our precious old growth and leave nothing for our community but dry wells.

We are not against forestry, we are against industrial clear cut logging that will leave little benefit to the community and threaten our water supplies. On Cortes Island, we practice Sustainable Forestry which creates local jobs while leaving the forest canopy in place. Cortes Island is a model of how to slow down climate change.

We have built a Forest Camp to defend our community and land. We need your donations to help fund our Forest Camp and help with the impending possibility of blockading against Island Timberlands. The money will be used to buy food and supplies for the camp. If for some reason, the money is not used to fight against this intrusion, then we will put the donated funds towards the purchase of Island Timberlands lands on the island.

With your financial help, we will overcome and be successful in our journey to protect our land and do the right thing for future generations. Thank you for your time and understanding about this special place in British Columbia, Canada.

 

ForestFest in the Media

Looking Forward to ForestFest

Aug. 22, 2012, by Jill Milton and Barry Miles, Island Tides

With logging slated to begin this September, it’s time to think about the future of our forests. Starting with a few parcels of land this year, Island Timberlands plans to clear-cut all of their substantial holdings over the next years. IT does own the land, and as a corporation, they manage it to maximize economic profit. Taking timber out of the forest is not the problem; its the process of industrial logging that ignores any values but the bottom line... Continue reading.

Cortes Island ForestFest: Forest activism for all generations

Aug. 26, 2012, by Carrie Saxifrage, Vancouver Observer

As September draws near, Cortes Islanders and other opponents of industrial logging are gearing up to protect Cortes forests from Island Timberlands.This weekend, a multipurpose “ForestFest” brought blockaders and friends together for strategy and inspiration... Continue reading.

Celebration, Education and Inspiration at Forestfest

Sept. 1, 2012, by Alexis Stoymenoff, Island Tides

There’s a reason why outsiders who visit Cortes Island often find it a difficult place to leave. It’s not just the lush wooded landscapes, pristine coastlines, rare species and towering, ancient trees. Those things are a huge part of what makes Cortes so special... Continue reading.

A Letter of Gratitude to my Community

Aug. 21, 2012, by Rosemary Bockner, Island Tides

What a gift I’ve been given, to be raised by a village. Here, on and around Cortes, human and non human community has given me priceless gifts, that only now, having lived elsewhere, in metropolis and clearcuts alike, I have come to more fully appreciate.

As a teenager I couldn't wait to get out of here, but now returning after 17 years, i've witnessed the devastation of industrialization on the biosphere and it's components, whether it’s in the stony straight lines of concrete and the grey frowning faces of the commuters in the cities,or miles of massive stumps in clearcuts, I realize how precious the remaining wilderness and in particular biodiverse old growth forest stands are to the retention of life on land and in the sea.

Thank you to my parents, who chose to raise me like they did, in a complex ecosystem where we could catch grow and collect our food, socialize and interact with people of all ages and spend our time in the natural world. Living in the Gorge Harbour on a float house at age six was the pinnacle of my idyllic childhood memories.

There was always a sorrow when my dad killed the fish, but he taught me to thank the fish for giving its life to sustain our own. Our thanks was to take only what we needed and never to waste. To protect it from our personal human potential to damage it and pollute it, and from other larger forces of industry that seek to profit without giving back.

I have spent ten years in clearcuts and know well the results of industrial logging practices. I've planted harvest trees, which is really in essence the same as cutting them down, so I have worked in the forestry industry and love the way of life and the hard working people I've met, the loggers, contractors, treeplanters, brushers checkers, camp workers, and many others who have made their living in forestry, many for generations. We are all on the same side, treecutters, treehuggers and treeplanters alike stand to lose our way of life.

Life in metropolis, I've been there, I know what it is to have no community, to pass 1000 people on the street and never say hello. I know many people that think the supermarket is where food comes from and the tap is where water comes from, and everything you flush down the toilet or put on the curb on garbage day just disappears.

I remember the cornucopia of life in the early 80's. Seagulls that fascinated my child self by swallowing starfish whole. Oysters that dad would shuck on the beach and let me chew on the salty 'muscle' left on the shell. Moss and lichens that my mom taught me to identify. Catching red snappers and cod in the dingy for our dinner. Baby otters, minks, curious seals, enormous sunstars, luminous in the depth. Limpets and barnacles. Eagles and herons and loons. Thank you.

Thank you forests. Mushroom walks like easter egg hunts, meaty and satisfying in mashed potatoes and soups. Cool shady depths, mother trees that seem to absord voices. Fern kingdoms, black bogs and striking bright yellow skunk cabbages. Old falling down homesteads, swathed now in brambles, the homesteaders long gone and their remnants almost taken back into the earth by so many wet and windy winters. As time passes and more and more of what I knew is lost forever, I am grateful to have experienced it.

Thank you for teaching me that the ultimate gift is to return home, to return your gifts to your home.

I am involved in the organizing of Forestfest this year, in advance of IT's planned start date for the logging of their corporately owned lands,to bring the community together to share in one another's gifts, to prepare ourselves for whatever comes next, so that we can meet the threat of corporate greed with one voice, a united song. I will sing with my sister Amy and my dear friend Marguerite on Friday the 24th at 7:30pm, and although I’m not particularly keen on public performance, I feel it is my responsibility to give my gifts back. I will be singing for the forest, forgetting my shyness, and adding my voice to the song.

I invite you all, my dear community, to bring your gifts, your talents, your strengths, your song to protect the community of plants & animals who give us these gifts in the first place, to come and add your voice. I implore you to see the sadness of IT's plans as a call to action, and not to give up.

We need each other, our abundant community, now more than ever. I love you Cortes, and all your children.

To protect it from our personal human potential to damage it and pollute it, and from other larger forces of industry that seek to profit without giving back.
I have spent ten years in clearcuts and know well the results of industrial logging practices. I've planted harvest trees, which is really in essence the same as cutting them down, so I have worked in the forestry industry and love the way of life and the hard working people I've met, the loggers, contractors, treeplanters, brushers checkers, camp workers, and many others who have made their living in forestry, many for generations. We are all on the same side, treecutters, treehuggers and treeplanters alike stand to lose our way of life.
Life in metropolis, I've been there, I know what it is to have no community, to pass 1000 people on the street and never say hello. I know many people that think the supermarket is where food comes from and the tap is where water comes from, and everything you flush down the toilet or put on the curb on garbage day just disappears.
I remember the cornucopia of life in the early 80's. Seagulls that fascinated my child self by swallowing starfish whole. Oysters that dad would shuck on the beach and let me chew on the salty 'muscle' left on the shell. Moss and lichens that my mom taught me to identify. Catching red snappers and cod in the dingy for our dinner. Baby otters, minks, curious seals, enormous sunstars, luminous in the depth. Limpets and barnacles. Eagles and herons and loons. Thank you.
Thank you forests. Mushroom walks like easter egg hunts, meaty and satisfying in mashed potatoes and soups. Cool shady depths, mother trees that seem to absord voices. Fern kingdoms, black bogs and striking bright yellow skunk cabbages. Old falling down homesteads, swathed now in brambles, the homesteaders long gone and their remnants almost taken back into the earth by so many wet and windy winters. As time passes and more and more of what I knew is lost forever, I am grateful to have experienced it.
Thank you for teaching me that the ultimate gift is to return home, to return your gifts to your home.
I am involved in the organizing of Forestfest this year, in advance of IT's planned start date for the logging of their corporately owned lands,to bring the community together to share in one another's gifts, to prepare ourselves for whatever comes next, so that we can meet the threat of corporate greed with one voice, a united song. I will sing with my sister Amy and my dear friend Marguerite on Friday the 24th at 7:30pm, and although I’m not particularly keen on public performance, I feel it is my responsibility to give my gifts back. I will be singing for the forest, forgetting my shyness, and adding my voice to the song.
I invite you all, my dear community, to bring your gifts, your talents, your strengths, your song to protect the community of plants & animals who give us these gifts in the first place, to come and add your voice. I implore you to see the sadness of IT's plans as a call to action, and not to give up.
We need each other, our abundant community, now more than ever. I love you Cortes, and all your children.

story:
This is a non-profit project concerned only with getting out the message, changing minds and saving the environment.

There is a drastic need to decrease emissions and create green transportation networks in the U.S. and around the world so what remains of the environment can be preserved. We believe the Swiss Rail system is the model to follow if we are ever going to accomplish these goals. Help us to open eyes and change the American perception of trains and transportation as a whole before it is too late. The Swiss model provides the perfect remedy to $4 gas, waiting in rush hour and the choking fumes of smog.

WHAT?:

Our documentary will focus on the Swiss rail network as the potential model that in addition to saving time, money and stress for the traveler saves precious natural resources and dramatically reduces pollution and its harmful effects on the global environment. Our findings will be used as a "how-to" guide for government agencies from the local to the federal level and private investors who wish to harness the potential windfall available to anyone who creates a transportation network based on the Swiss model. Our project is being undertaken with the blessing of the Swiss government and the open assistance of the Swiss Rail network who has graciously supplied our crew with all access permits to the rail system, stations, trains and employees of the railway, as well as unlimited passes to use any and all transportation within the network during filming.

WHY SWITZERLAND?

Let’s get technical for a minute…The Swiss rail system carries over 350 million passengers each year at an average rate of 17,750 km per person and 139,000 metric tons of total CO2 emissions. The average 6 cylinder gasoline engine car traveling the same distance emits about 4 metric tons of CO2. That means every 34,750 cars on the road traveling just under 11,000 miles per year emit as much Carbon as the entire Swiss Rail network. The U.S. alone has over 250 million registered vehicles. There are over 1 billion in the world.

Switzerland is one of the few places in the world with a nearly perfect rail travel efficiency record year after year, a rail system that is small enough to be manageable in standard length documentary and book form and a landscape and setting so beautiful that it alone is worthy of a feature film. Due to Switzerland’s rugged terrain the trains used are varied in gauge and style and have a classic look rarely found elsewhere. In all the country’s rail system is like a toy train set in large scale with incredibly photogenic properties. The best way to get a message across is to make it attractive so people seek it out and pay attention. Switzerland allows us to do that.

In addition to the green aspect of the rail system the documentary will feature the unique history, beauty, oddities and romance of the Swiss rail system. The project will involve trekking through the entire Swiss rail network, recording and photographing stations, trains, mountain passes, bridges, rail cars and the incredible vistas of the alpine region and Swiss lowlands in relation to the trains that serve them. We will highlight the most extreme sights including the highest rail link in the world the Top of Europe railway, the Glacier Express and the Bernina Express, both of which travel over mountains and into hidden valleys unreachable any other way. Special attention will be paid to the classic Swiss hamlets, historical structures and castles that dot the landscape atop the most impossible perches completely isolated from the outside world.

ADDITIONAL RESEARCH:

We have scheduled interviews with Swiss Rail executives to discuss how the railway attracts riders and gets its message out to the general public. We will focus on railway marketing, usage costs as compared to vehicle ownership and use and what the Swiss government is doing to make the train the way to go. We will compare these tactics with those in the U.S and around the world for effectiveness and approach. In the end the documentary should show the shortcomings of other rail systems versus the Swiss and how by adapting certain policies, marketing techniques and incentives, countries around the globe can make a significant dent in their vehicle exhaust emissions and the damage they are doing to the planet with each passing rush hour.

WHAT TO EXPECT:

Shooting and information gathering will take place over a one to two month long period starting in late Spring 2013. Documentary post production will be completed by Fall of 2013. A large scale photo-heavy book will be completed by the end of the year 2013 in time to accompany the documentary. The team is in discussions to arrange for presentations at public venues in major cities around the country as part of Earth Day 2014 and will be making appearances at high schools and universities to spread the message of green transportation.

FUNDING NEEDS:

The benefits provided by Swiss Rail and the Swiss government will help reduce the cost of the expedition by several thousand dollars but are not a total solution. On top of the tremendous benefits being provided by Swiss Rail, we are in need of funding for basic accommodations during the two month trek, some specialized equipment in addition to that we already possess, post production expenses and supplies.

THE TEAM:

Our NYC based team members possess unique skills each with a key role in the project. Our team consists of a professional writer, TV and film editor, PR and marketing specialist and destination expert who together make up an A-Team strike force of project completion.

story:
Some history...

Z-kollektivet is located in Höör, Skåne, in the south of Sweden and is an eco-friendly group of people who are creating an example of how people can live differently in a new healthy, loving, and sustainable way by sharing our life in as many ways as possible and being an example for the rest of the world. We started this project in 2010, a family of 5 persons who since then have tried to find a group of people who want to team up with us. Some years later we have now formed a core group and are ready to show the world what we are made of! Our common religion is, honesty, openness, respect, caring and sharing, and, doing as little harm as possible to people, plants and animals. 

The whole project will be open source model so anyone can follow us and take notes, learn and maybe do something similar themselves. And we will gladly support such actions! We decided to face the challenge of building a home for us all, with as little money as possible, while at the same time as much self sustainable as possible. It will be a house, a project, a place where people can come and visit, learn and be inspired.

What We Need & What You Get

In this first round of funding, we need $ 9000. This money will help us with the down payment to the land and pre approval building permission so we can buy the land and start collecting all material needed for the house and green house (biodome). 

(This is our friends straw bale house in Argentina) 

Once the down payment is done, we will continue to pay the on going loan until fully paid. If we should make it to this first goal and there should be any excess money, this will only go to material for the house and nothing else. In case we don't reach our goal, we will just continue a bit more until we reach it because we know this WILL happen! We are finding more and more people who want to help for free with building, tools, skills, material, etc… all to make this as cheap as possible and better than what you can buy! We have worked very hard for this and we plan not to stop until it's done! So help us out. ok!

The Impact

Fundamental to Z-kollektivet are a few principal factors: sustainability, recycled material, natural materials, local material, simpleness and a simple lifestyle in harmony with our surroundings. The goal is a zero energy sustainable straw bale community house. (about 4000 sqf = 375 kvm) One o four goals are to get as much material and help we can for free since we know there is an abundance of resources in the world, both material as well as people and skills.

By contributing to our campaign, you will help us create a unique idea and powerful message leading the way for the changes we need to make, to transition away from money, competition, separation and waste, to a world where we care and share our life with cooperation as our leading star. This funding will allow us to buy the land we have found (a wonderful piece of land) so we can raise awareness about the global madness we see today of wasting resources and a never ending consumption and ruining our planet. We love to see and live the change, specially for the children of our future!

Other Ways You Can Help

1. Buy a perk!

With your purchase, you will be making a real (BIG) difference to make this project happen. You become one of us!

2. Tell your friends about Z-kollektivet!

Share the link to this site and our website on all your social media platforms. Love is the movement! http://www.zkollektivet.trueloveismagic.com

3. Support the Z-kollektiv Trend!

Every now and then we will be giving you updates on how it goes, our development and progress and everything what's going on. and the more you spread the word and share this site, the sooner it will come true! Share it on your Facebook page and everywhere else! Together, we'll inspire the world!

4. Share this site with everyone you know!

If you can't help us out with a perk, don't worry. You can help us very much (maybe even more) by telling everyone about our campaign! You do us a great favor!  

- Opportunities – Get involved and experience first hand what’s most important to us. Hang out with the team at the Z-kollektivet in Höör. The ability to help others is truly the greatest gift!

Don't forget to check out the Updates tab here on this page so see the latest news about us!

We believe that we can invoke positive change to benefit the world. 

Hope and hugs from Z-kollektivet: Kosotie, Marie, Ingela, Dana

THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
My dream is to donate 100 backpacks to some really cool kids in (and around) OKC…just so they can go backpacking for the first time…. (Heck, just so they could go to the mountains for the first time)

For each backpack you contribute...I will donate a free backpack to a boy scout troop in OKC....IN YOUR NAME...and YOU will get you a tax deduction....I promise.

In Oklahoma, there are some great places for kids to go camping and backpacking …and once these 100 kids got a taste for it…they’d want to go to places like this:  This is “Washington Enchantment”, the place where this video was shot…

Even better, with some good guides and some good eco-teachers, these 100 kids would be taught to be kind to Mother Nature…they would learn to “pack out what they pack in”…to “leave it better than they found it”…they would learn what I call “Eco-Kindness” and they would start “Paying-it-Forward” for future generations……

IF we can just help 100 kids get back to the mountains (even little mountains like the Kiamichi’s, the Ozarks, the Wichita’s in Oklahoma)…they will be hooked…they will be jazzed…they will fall in love with the Great Outdoors, and they will be lovers of nature for the rest of their lives…

…and with this love for the planet, they will want to pay that Love forward….

You see,… if the Earth really is in trouble, if it really is getting too warm…if we really are cutting down too many trees…or whatever…I think that, starting with 100 kids seeing how BEAUTIFUL the planet really is…maybe we will ALL start fixing the problems..

But… like the saying” If I give you a fish, you eat for a day…if I teach you to fish…you eat for a lifetime”

Unfortunately, the same goes for backpacks…

I’m afraid that if we just GAVE 1000 kids BRAND NEW backpacks, they would they would just OUTGROW THEM…before they had a chance to do very much backpacking….

To make this DREAM work…these 100 kids will need a NEW KIND of Backpack, one that GROWS with them…one that FITS both BOYS and GIRLS…one that can be MODIFIED for ALL SORTS of camping trips….

And that’s WHY I invented onecoolbackpack…

Onecoolbackpack™ is a new type of backpack; it was INVENTED to SOLVE the typical problems of a traditional external-frame backpack.

The new innovations of Onecoolbackpack™ (patent-pending) are the following:

… It has a FLEXIBLE coil spring frame, made of Mylar, and encased in 1000 denier Cordura tubing.

…It has a new type of shoulder harness…with an adjustable torso length ranging from 5’ to 6’3.

…It has plenty of slots for outrigging…with DETACHABLE packbags…pack enough gear for the whole week, or just the weekend.

…this backpack FLEXES with your torso while you are hiking…No more aching back, no more hip bruises.


We have already been in contact with local non-profit groups, including individual Boy Scout (and Girl Scout) troops in the Greater OKC area, …we have also contacted other groups throughout the area who also need new backpacks… and they are ALL willing and eager to accept the gift of new backpacks.

SO, with your contributions, we will have all the funds necessary to produce and deliver 1000 backpacks to these people, who will be able to SHARE these backpacks with kids in their neighborhoods…so they can also GET BACK to Mother Nature….

Thanks ….

Campaign Deadline: April 22, 2014  [Earth Day]

story:
As the founders of this company, we were disturbed to find that many of the waterways we knew and loved in our youth are being destroyed by toxic algae blooms caused by man-made pollution. We, like many of you, have fond memories of going to these lakes and other natural waterways with family and friends. These memories that we all have of these pristine waterways are a gift that should be treasured, but when we saw that future generations may be limited in their abilities to enjoy these natural habitats due to the effects on local wildlife caused by runoff and contamination, we realized that we can no longer wait for governments to do this - it would be up to us and you to stop this.

THE PROBLEM:

The chief cause of algae blooms are cyanobacteria. Although they are naturally present in all bodies of water, certain industrial and recreational activities can often lead to them rapidly multiplying out of control. In addition to direct human factors, the addition of invasive species such as the zebra mussel has caused further loss of biodiversity (“Zebra Mussel Fact Sheet”) through predation of zooplankton, native phytoplankton, and other small organisms, all of which are necessary competitors and predators to the algae. The most obvious effect of this can be seen in the appearance of the infested body: massive tangled mats of algae will blanket the surface of a eutrophied lake with thick bluish-green slime, obscuring any natural beauty that might have been present – and also choking out anything that relies on sunlight filtering through the water. But the less obvious effects of an algae bloom can be far more sinister. Firstly, when an algae bloom occurs, excess nutrients from chemical runoff are siphoned from the body that is effected, which is what causes cyanobacterial population to explode. However, the exponentially increased population will rapidly deplete the nutrients that allowed it to grow, and once they are exhausted, mass starvation will occur throughout the bacterial colony. The resulting decomposition from the mass death draws massive amounts of oxygen from the water, leading to the suffocation of many larger life forms, even including fish and amphibians.

The second effect of algae blooms is the toxins that accumulate when they are present in large quantities. These toxins can range across many different categories, from hematoxins to neurotoxins, but the most prevalent form is microcystin, which primarily causes liver damage, and can even result in death when ingested by many large vertebraes, including pets, cattle, and even humans (Butler, Carlisle, Linville, & Washburn, 2009). In recent years, places such as lake Erie have even been affected, causing contamination that has in some cases forced over 400,000 residents of nearby towns to have to drink bottled water due to the toxins in the municipal water supply from algae blooms. (Malewitz, 2018). The effects that these cyanobacteria have has caused over $284 million in losses in Canada, and over $1 billion in losses in America in Lake Erie alone. The global damage of these blooms is immeasureable, as they have become more and more common due to climate change and increased industrialization.

In Oregon alone, there are several lakes and rivers that are directly affected by eutrophication; these would be the first places that we would target. According to the EPA, local Daphnia populations have decreased in recent years directly due to humans introducing chemicals into their water supplies (Borges, Dzubow, Orrick, & Stavola, 2004). Because of this, there are few major predators that are left to consume cyanobacteria and therefore prevent blooms.

During the summers, the rise in temperature along with increased runoff due to human activity is predicted to cause a further increase in algae blooms around Oregon ("Toxic algae blooms possible in Oregon lakes and rivers as temps rise", 2019)

 

OUR TEAM:

Christopher Lea – Christopher Lea has several years of experience managing aquaculture, algae, and zooplankton, and is very skilled at both breeding and maintaining samples of exotic marine life.
 

Ethan Szlovak – Ethan Szlovak has skills in a variety of computer science fields, and has had an interest in marine biology since childhood.

 

Robert Bosch – With several years of experience working as an United States Airforce Mechanic, Robert Bosch is well suited towards the maintenance and maintaining of all mechanical and electronic systems that will be used in our projects

 

Simeon Florea – As an organic chemistry student, Simeon Florea will ensure that we are raising all samples as effectively and ethically as possible, allowing both rapid deployment and healthy living in all creatures that we raise.

 

OUR SOLUTION:

Although cyanobacteria are toxic to humans, there are some forms of life that are not only able to consume them, but actually can rely on them as sources of food. The common water flea, (Daphnia Pulex) is one such species, and as it is naturally found in bodies of water around the world, we would not be risking the introduction of invasive species by using it to predate on the cyanobacterial blooms. Although astute readers may have heard of water fleas being one of top 100 worst invasive species, the species in that is listed as such is actually the fish-hook water flea, which is in an entirely different biological family (Cercopagididae) than Daphnia (Daphniidae), and therefore the introduction of Daphnia, which is already present in most lakes, would simply increase the local population back to acceptable, natural levels, which have been diminished due to the introduction of toxins, pollutants, and invasive species such as the Zebra Mussel.

After the algae bloom has been dealt with, the remaining Daphnia would simply be preyed upon by local fish and water fowl, which in turn could lead to a temporarily or permanently increased local population for both fishing and sightseeing.

Because Daphnia also exhibit a remarkable ability to adapt to new conditions, within a few generations they can be bred to selectively consume specific types of cyanobacteria.

We are only going to be using the best specimens of Daphnia from universities and companies such as Carolina Biological, or Texas University as our starting cultures, and will breed and feed them in order to acclimate them to the specific cyanobacteria that is causing the problem in the lake that we are working on clearing. We have also plans for a mobile mass growing and distribution system that we could bring to affected lakes.

In order to grow both the samples of the necessary cyanobacteria, and the Daphnia that we will be acclimating, we will be needing a larger facility in order to mass produce the algae and Daphnia, and facilitate distribution. Once we get a facility running, we will be growing many different forms of marine life for both hobbyists and professionals in order to become monetarily self sufficient so that we can sustain ourselves between large reclamation projects, and to fund this solution on a large scale. Due to the nature of this project, it is also easily scaleable and expandable to meet any scope.

This is where you come in: The money that you invest will be directly used in order to build or rent a facility in Oregon where we can begin testing. We will be using it to set up a facility, procure samples, begin research, and launch operations on areas such as the Umpqua River.


With your help, we can work together towards the goal of reclaiming the beauty that these lakes once had, by restoring the nature that we have for so long neglected.

The Scope of what we will be doing:

The main location that we would be focusing on would be South Umpqua River in Oregon. The river is under a permanent closure due to the highly dangerous algae blooms that are present, which have resulted in the deaths of domesticated dogs and cats. One of the major causes of this is the decreased amount of Daphnia due to human activity.

We would be solving this problem by introducing large amounts of Daphnia back into their natural environment so that they can properly predate upon the cyanobacteria and make the water more aesthetically pleasing, and most importantly, safe.

What exactly will your money be going towards?

A Commercial Grade RO/DI Filter System

In order to properly grow and feed the necessary zooplankton and algae, ordinary tap water has too many chemicals to do the job properly. Essentially, we will be needing an industrial sized aquarium water filter to ensure that we can purify enough to keep several vats of plankton alive for testing and distribution.

 

A Commecial Grade UV Filtration System

In addition to the filtration system mentioned above, we will also require a commercial grade UV Sterilization/Filtration system in order to ensure that local parasites and hitchhikers don't contaminate samples that we send to locations that could potentially be anywhere in the country, ensuring not only a high quality product, but preventing the unintentional spread of invasive species whenever possible.

 

 

Necessary Rent for 3 Years Lease of a Small Warehouse Facility from which we can expand

This undertaking requires an area from which we can work. A simple small warehouse or pole barn will be suitable for us to launch a base of operations, from which we can expand as we get more clients and grow our business.

The minimum monthy cost of this kind of facility will be $14,000 (Excess money will go towards purchasing a larger facility)

 

Freezers for long term algae storage

To ensure that we are able to quickly deploy systems in the event that we get a short-notice or long-distance contract, we will use freezers to stockpile live algae for rapid, local breeding of Daphnia or other zooplankton that are required in a cleanup operation. This will be critical for any large scale cleaning project, as the Daphnia will require large amounts of food in order to breed and grow.

 

A Van for easy transportation

To move materials around the local area, and in order to help us set up, a van or some other equivalent motor vehicle will be needed.

 

Basic Biological Examination Systems (Microscopes, Petri Dishes, etc etc.)

Basic lab equipment, such as microscopes, beakers, and petri dishes will allow us to conduct both on-location surveys, and help us ensure the health of specimens that we grow.

 

Multiple Tank and Vat Systems

To properly grow pure samples of any product, we will need specially designed tank and vat systems in order to prevent cross contamination, and ensure that we have multiple backups in the event of disease, human error, or other unpredictable events.

 

Algae Growing Tanks

In order to ensure that all zooplankton we grow are of the highest quality, various algae will be grown on-site in order to minimize transportation and cost required to maintain production.

 

T-5 Algae Growth Lighting Systems

As algae is a plant, it requires light, these systems will allow us to properly provide for it.

 

A Cargo Trailer for Moving Materials

We can't bring a warehouse with us, but we can bring the next best thing, a trailer equipped with a mobile lab, samples, a freezer, cover tents, and vats in order to perform on-site surveying, testing, and delivery.

 

A 45 Kilowatt Emergency Generator

There are many lakes where electrical infrastructure does not reach; in these cases, we will need to bring our own power supply – that is what this is for.

 

Commercial grade Refugium Tanks

In order to maintain livestock and a healthy water reserve, we will be needing one or two Commercial Refugium Tanks.

 

About the Rewards:

Because of the nature of the rewards, there isn't a real retail value, so the %off on the rewards section doesn't really mean anything, and we also just put really big numbers in the retail value section of the rewards. Basically, everything about the rewards are in their description.

Any discounts will be given as a card with unlimited uses that will be linked into an account system in our site database, so that when you purchase anything it will be properly discounted.

It will take us at least six months to get the facilities up and running so that we can begin production and deliver rewards.

We will be growing many different species of aquarium life in order to ensure that we can stay in business, so those things will be available for you to buy.

Also, anyone who donates will get a choice whether they would like to be on the website as a supporter.

Here are some of the things that we have grown in the past and will be growing in the future:

Partnerships

We would be honored to maintain long term partnerships, and that requires mutual trust on both ends. For that reason, we will be offering updates and progress reports at the very least, once per month, but likely even more often than that. All updates will be found on our social media.

*There is a video on the way that we will be putting up

Our Social Media

Twitter: @EcologyLake

Facebook: fb.me/EcologyLake

Instagram: instagram.com/lakeandrivereco/

Youtube: youtube.com/channel/UCWBx3xuBIN347h4-avQfGbw

Sources

Borges, S., Dzubow, C., Orrick, G., & Stavola, A. (2004). 2, 4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic Acid Analysis of Risks to Endangered and Threatened Salmon and Steelhead. Environmental Field Branch Office of Pesticide Programs.

Butler, N., Ph.D., Carlisle, J. C., D.V.M., Linville, R., Ph.D., & Washburn, B., Ph.D. (2009).

Malewitz, J. (2018, August 22). Lake Erie's algae bloom is growing again after paralyzing Toledo water system. Retrieved from https://www.bridgemi.com/michigan-environment-w... algae-bloom-growing-again-after-paralyzing-toledo-water-system

Microcystins: A brief overview of their toxicity and effects, with special reference to fish, wildlife, and livestock (United States, California Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment). CA.

Toxic algae blooms possible in Oregon lakes and rivers as temps rise. (2019, May 9). KVAL. Retrieved from https://kval.com/news/local/toxic-algae-blooms-...

Urrutia-Cordero, P., Ekvall, M. K., & Hansson, L. (2016). Controlling Harmful Cyanobacteria: Taxa- Specific Responses of Cyanobacteria to Grazing by Large-Bodied Daphnia in a Biomanipulation Scenario. Plos One, 11(4). doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0153032

Zebra Mussel Fact Sheet [PDF]. (n.d.). Millbrok: Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies.
story_txt: As the founders of this company, we were disturbed to find that many of the waterways we knew and loved in our youth are being destroyed by toxic algae blooms caused by man-made pollution. We, like many of you, have fond memories of going to these lakes and other natural waterways with family and friends. These memories that we all have of these pristine waterways are a gift that should be treasured, but when we saw that future generations may be limited in their abilities to enjoy these natural habitats due to the effects on local wildlife caused by runoff and contamination, we realized that we can no longer wait for governments to do this - it would be up to us and you to stop this.THE PROBLEM:The chief cause of algae blooms are cyanobacteria. Although they are naturally present in all bodies of water, certain industrial and recreational activities can often lead to them rapidly multiplying out of control. In addition to direct human factors, the addition of invasive species such as the zebra mussel has caused further loss of biodiversity (“Zebra Mussel Fact Sheet”) through predation of zooplankton, native phytoplankton, and other small organisms, all of which are necessary competitors and predators to the algae. The most obvious effect of this can be seen in the appearance of the infested body: massive tangled mats of algae will blanket the surface of a eutrophied lake with thick bluish-green slime, obscuring any natural beauty that might have been present – and also choking out anything that relies on sunlight filtering through the water. But the less obvious effects of an algae bloom can be far more sinister. Firstly, when an algae bloom occurs, excess nutrients from chemical runoff are siphoned from the body that is effected, which is what causes cyanobacterial population to explode. However, the exponentially increased population will rapidly deplete the nutrients that allowed it to grow, and once they are exhausted, mass starvation will occur throughout the bacterial colony. The resulting decomposition from the mass death draws massive amounts of oxygen from the water, leading to the suffocation of many larger life forms, even including fish and amphibians.The second effect of algae blooms is the toxins that accumulate when they are present in large quantities. These toxins can range across many different categories, from hematoxins to neurotoxins, but the most prevalent form is microcystin, which primarily causes liver damage, and can even result in death when ingested by many large vertebraes, including pets, cattle, and even humans (Butler, Carlisle, Linville, & Washburn, 2009). In recent years, places such as lake Erie have even been affected, causing contamination that has in some cases forced over 400,000 residents of nearby towns to have to drink bottled water due to the toxins in the municipal water supply from algae blooms. (Malewitz, 2018). The effects that these cyanobacteria have has caused over $284 million in losses in Canada, and over $1 billion in losses in America in Lake Erie alone. The global damage of these blooms is immeasureable, as they have become more and more common due to climate change and increased industrialization.In Oregon alone, there are several lakes and rivers that are directly affected by eutrophication; these would be the first places that we would target. According to the EPA, local Daphnia populations have decreased in recent years directly due to humans introducing chemicals into their water supplies (Borges, Dzubow, Orrick, & Stavola, 2004). Because of this, there are few major predators that are left to consume cyanobacteria and therefore prevent blooms.During the summers, the rise in temperature along with increased runoff due to human activity is predicted to cause a further increase in algae blooms around Oregon ("Toxic algae blooms possible in Oregon lakes and rivers as temps rise", 2019) OUR TEAM:Christopher Lea – Christopher Lea has several years of experience managing aquaculture, algae, and zooplankton, and is very skilled at both breeding and maintaining samples of exotic marine life. Ethan Szlovak – Ethan Szlovak has skills in a variety of computer science fields, and has had an interest in marine biology since childhood. Robert Bosch – With several years of experience working as an United States Airforce Mechanic, Robert Bosch is well suited towards the maintenance and maintaining of all mechanical and electronic systems that will be used in our projects Simeon Florea – As an organic chemistry student, Simeon Florea will ensure that we are raising all samples as effectively and ethically as possible, allowing both rapid deployment and healthy living in all creatures that we raise. OUR SOLUTION:Although cyanobacteria are toxic to humans, there are some forms of life that are not only able to consume them, but actually can rely on them as sources of food. The common water flea, (Daphnia Pulex) is one such species, and as it is naturally found in bodies of water around the world, we would not be risking the introduction of invasive species by using it to predate on the cyanobacterial blooms. Although astute readers may have heard of water fleas being one of top 100 worst invasive species, the species in that is listed as such is actually the fish-hook water flea, which is in an entirely different biological family (Cercopagididae) than Daphnia (Daphniidae), and therefore the introduction of Daphnia, which is already present in most lakes, would simply increase the local population back to acceptable, natural levels, which have been diminished due to the introduction of toxins, pollutants, and invasive species such as the Zebra Mussel.After the algae bloom has been dealt with, the remaining Daphnia would simply be preyed upon by local fish and water fowl, which in turn could lead to a temporarily or permanently increased local population for both fishing and sightseeing.Because Daphnia also exhibit a remarkable ability to adapt to new conditions, within a few generations they can be bred to selectively consume specific types of cyanobacteria.We are only going to be using the best specimens of Daphnia from universities and companies such as Carolina Biological, or Texas University as our starting cultures, and will breed and feed them in order to acclimate them to the specific cyanobacteria that is causing the problem in the lake that we are working on clearing. We have also plans for a mobile mass growing and distribution system that we could bring to affected lakes.In order to grow both the samples of the necessary cyanobacteria, and the Daphnia that we will be acclimating, we will be needing a larger facility in order to mass produce the algae and Daphnia, and facilitate distribution. story:
SLUG OFF!

100% Effective, Eco-Friendly 

Slug & Snail Repellent 

Hello, my name is Adam Harries, I introduce this amazing  project on behalf of my father who created Slug Off and my family who have used Slug Off effectively for years. The main reason we have put Slug Off  on Indiegogo is because there is nothing else like it. Slug Off is 100% effective and whether you like slugs and snails or not, Slug Off is non poisonous and will not harm the creatures or your pets like the current slug poisons on the market. Slug Off has been tested in all weathers, over three years (& counting). From a personal perspective, my mother and sister also use Slug Off to protect their plants. We all thought that this special paint must be made available to the public. Let's stop using poisons to kill slugs and snails.

  • Slug Off is a 100% effective Slug and Snail repellant paint that has been tested and lasted over a three year period and longer (it is still working now).
  • Slug Off can be painted on any surface, from plastic to brick.
  • Slug Off is non toxic, eco-friendly and pet friendly.
  • All packaging will be made from recycled materials.
  • Become the first to own this incredible product!

What Your Contributions Will Go Towards - Be One Of The First To Own Slug Off!

Your funding will go towards:

  • The wholesale purchases of Slug Off's secret ingredients.
  • Wholesale recycled containers, labelling & packaging.
  • Website design and server costs.
  • Advertising on social media.
  • As we grow we will employ staff to help with the whole creation & packaging  process.
  • Check out our perks! You can be one of the first people to ever own Slug Off!

The Impact

Slug Off will help the environment as it is non toxic, non poisonous and friendly to pets and all creatures. We want to slow down or even stop the slug and snail poisons that are currently being sold on the market.

Risks & Challenges

The more Slug Off we supply, the more we will need to grow. We intend to do this step by step and not rush into to too many 'overheads'. My father is retired now, but was a very successful business man, running and managing hotels and restaurants in Wales and England. He has also broken 3 world records including the largest easter egg in the world and the largest Yorkshire Pudding. I have worked with my father many times and, to say the least, my father is a brilliant entrepreneur. He and I are experienced and qualified (and very eager) to take on this challenge to get Slug Off out there! Please joins us and help!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please spread the word about Slug Off and this Indiegogo Campaign on social media like Facebook and Twitter.

Thank you for your time!  Be one of the first people to own Slug Off and help us get Slug Off worldwide! Let's stop using poisons to kill slugs and snails!

story: Hi guys! My name's Dan Hennessy and i'm 21 years old training to be a fitness instructor/personal trainer, the aim for this fundraiser is to raise £2990 for a cause called 'climb Kilimanjaro for clean water in Africa.'  This funding allows £1445 to the charity called 'dig deep' which provides villages across East Africa with clean water, the other £1445 funds me to fly to Africa to do the challenge itself (Climb the largest mountain in the world - Kilimanjaro!) to start off with i need £195 to register with the dig deep website and get my fundraising page set up, this page is for raising that £195, not the £2990! So please please please any little donation towards the £195 would be appreciated MASSIVELY! Dig deep into those pockets people!

story:
Background

Before my first visit to Dove Missions a few years back, I'd been to the Dominican Republic only to visit family or to relax on a resort. Hunting around for a new way to experience the country where my parents grew up, I stumbled upon Liz Rooney's work and decided to volunteer and learn more.

Even though I only spent five days at Dove Missions, I really connected with the students and with the leadership. I kept in touch with Liz as she and the team set up the temporary garden that I helped design, while construction on the second story of the youth center was being done.  I felt like it was somewhere I wanted to keep giving to.

The first incarnation of the garden was by any definition a success - both as a teaching tool and as a source of food. Meanwhile, I've been developing a master plan for the roof of the new building, which was under construction during my initial visit. 

The Plan

This summer, I'll be heading to Puerto Plata to make the first phase of this project happen. This phase of the project will include the construction of nine raised garden beds (8' by 4') and a 3-bin composting system. The final garden will also feature:

  • a rain water collection tank
  • hydroponic systems
  • an outdoor classroom
  • a gazebo and benches

By the end of Phase 1, the Dove Mission Youth Center will be able to grow hundreds of herbs and vegetables every month, while boosting students' gardening and sustainability skills. It will be a unique resource in this neighborhood, and will serve a key community building function.

What We Need

Lumber, soil, compost, and tools! (And the list goes on... but you get the picture.)

The garden will be built over time as the money for it is raised gradually.  Regardless of wether we reach our goal through this campaign, all the money raised here will go towards the garden itself, and will not fund labor. 

Experience

I've been with New York Restoration Project in a community engagement role for the last six years. I've seen my share of community gardens come together! With a good team of Dove Missions staff, students, and volunteers, I'm confident we can make Phase 1 happen in just a couple of work days.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word! Share our campaign on social media using the Indiegogo share tools.

Background
Before my first visit to Dove Missions a few years back, I'd been to the Dominican Republic only to visit family or to relax on a resort. Hunting around for a new way to experience the country where my parents grew up, I stumbled upon Liz Rooney's work and decided to volunteer and learn more.
Even though I only spent five days at Dove Missions, I really connected with the students and with the leadership. I kept in touch with Liz as she and the team set up the temporary garden that I helped design, while construction on the second story of the youth center was being done.  I felt like it was somewhere I wanted to keep giving to.
The first incarnation of the garden was by any definition a success - both as a teaching tool and as a source of food. Meanwhile, I've been developing a master plan for the roof of the new building, which was under construction during my initial visit. 
The Plan
This summer, I'll be heading to Puerto Plata to make the first phase of this project happen. This phase of the project will include the construction of nine raised garden beds (8' by 4') and a 3-bin composting system. The final garden will also feature:

a rain water collection tank
hydroponic systems
an outdoor classroom
a gazebo and benches

By the end of Phase 1, the Dove Mission Youth Center will be able to grow hundreds of herbs and vegetables every month, while boosting students' gardening and sustainability skills. It will be a unique resource in this neighborhood, and will serve a key community building function.
What We Need

Lumber, soil, compost, and tools! (And the list goes on... but you get the picture.)
The garden will be built over time as the money for it is raised gradually.  Regardless of wether we reach our goal through this campaign, all the money raised here will go towards the garden itself, and will not fund labor. 
Experience
I've been with New York Restoration Project in a community engagement role for the last six years. I've seen my share of community gardens come together! With a good team of Dove Missions staff, students, and volunteers, I'm confident we can make Phase 1 happen in just a couple of work days.
Other Ways You Can HelpHelp us spread the word! Share our campaign on social media using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
Greening The Camps is a newly established non-profit organisation that designs, develops, constructs and maintains rooftop gardens in Palestinian refugee camps. The project, entirely run by  volunteers experienced in architecture and permaculture, is driven by our passion for environmental care and our understanding of urban design and its toolsets. Sharing and gathering knowledge, as well as creating a truly sustainable livelihood are closely linked with our devotion to enrich impoverished urban and camp areas. The multi-layered process is, on every level, guided by the ideas and desires of the local community with whom we work. Through reconnecting displaced communities with food production from urban agricultural practices, we try to create opportunities for local empowerment and economic development. 

الأسطح الخضراء ، هي منظمة غير ربحية حديثة الإنشاء، تعنى باستصلاح أسطح البيوت بهدف إنشاء حدائق زراعية حضرية في المخيمات الفلسطينية، يدار المشروع بالكامل من قبل مطوعين شغوفين وعلى دراية بعلم الزراعة الحضرية والتصميم، يشاركون خبراتهم بهدف تأمين حياه غذائية مستدامة لإثراء الزراعة الحضرية في المخيمات الفلسطينية، تعتمد مراحل البناء على حاجات المجتمع المحلي في المخيم معتمداً على أفكار وإقتراحات الأهالي، وبذلك نقوم بتمكين ووصل مجتمع الاجئين بالزراعة من جديد مما يمكنهم من إنتاج غذاهم بنفسهم مما يحسن وضعهم الإقتصادي والمادي

 

Opening our first experimental garden on the rooftop of ‘Jadal for Knowledge and Culture’ in Amman enriched us with the essential experience of urban farming in the challenging natural conditions of the Middle East. Meeting a great amount of people that share a similar mindset and vision gives our team the motivation to start with the next phase: implementing the urban farming project in Jerash Refugee Camp.  

مخطط المشروع : ساعدنا إنشاء الحديقة التجريبية في جدل الثقافي في عمان على تحسين وتطوير درايتنا وفهمنا للوضع العام في المنطقة ومدى تأثير مشروعنا على الوضع الراهن كما أن تعرفنا على أناس يحملون نفس انماط تفكيرنا ساعدنا كثيراً على تحسين وتطوير خطة جديدة محكمة للبدء بتطبيق المشروع في مخيم غزة في جرش

With the help of your donation, we will add a next chapter to Greening The Camps’ story. We are currently working on our Pilot Project in the camp by greening the rooftop of a vocational training school. This school will enable Palestinian refugees in the camp to learn new professional and creative skills. 

This initiative offers an open platform for learning and a social space where cultural activities and sharing knowledge is key. The cooperation between Greening The Camps and the vocational school will turn the rooftop into a great meeting point for people who share a similar mindset and vision and who are interested in the project. By organizing  workshops about urban agriculture, creative waste management, building and maintaining installations and growing and harvesting crops, we aim to excite members of the community in taking part in the project. Within the next 6 months our goal is to build three additional rooftop gardens in cooperation with families. We will develop gardens that have been designed to be constructed with the bare minimum of funding.

With your contribution you would help us build three rooftop gardens, and make Jerash Camp a greener space.  

دعمكم المادي سيساعدنا على كتابة الفصل الجديد من قصة مشروعنا، علماً بأننا قد بدئنا العمل ببناء أول حديقة على سطح مركز شبابي تطوعي بالمخيم يعنى بالتعليم الإبداعي والحرفي لاهل المخيم، يعتبر هذا المركز أو المبادرة واحة تحتضن وتنظم نشاطات ثقافية ومعرفية في المخيم فمشاركتنا وتوصلنا مع مثل هذه المبادرة يساعدنا على توفير نقطة تواصل بيننا وبين المهتمين بتحسين وضع المخيم الذين يحملون نفس نمط التفكير الذي نحمله، سنقوم بتنظيم دورات مختصة بمواضع مختلفة حول الزراعة الحضرية ،الزراعة والحصاد ،إعادة التدوير وإدارة النفايات والبناء والتركيب مستهدفين أهل المخيم مما يرفع تأثير ومشاركة المجتمع المحلي في المخيم، نهدف إلى بناء ٣ حدائق سطوح أخرى خلال فترة ال-٦ أشهر القادمة في المخيم على سطوح ٣ منازل موجودة داخل المخيم، حيث أننا قمنا بدراسة ووضع خطة محكمة لبناء حدائق أكثر إنتاجية وفعالية بأقل كلفة، دعمكم المادي سيساعدنا على بناء هذه الحدائق الثلاث مما يجعل المخيم مكاناً أكثر خضرة

 

                Rewards

€5 - Good Karma

Sending you green vibes and positive energy! Thank you for being part of our story!

€10 - Palestinian Chef

This is the easiest way to pitch in a few bucks and get a personal thank you card with a traditional Palestinian recipe on the back. 

€25- Urban Farmer 

Become an urban farmer yourself! Harvest your homegrown herbs and experience the Palestinian cuisine. You will receive organic seeds and a delicious recipe.  

€50 - Green Supporter

What better way to show your support than by doing your groceries while sporting a cotton tote bag with our logo.

 €100 -Urban Beekeeper 

Attract our buzzing friends with this handmade bee mansion. Bees will support you in making your urban garden a thriving bio-diverse oasis by pollinating your lovely crops. (Don’t worry, the bees that you will attract are solitary, and won’t have any honey to protect, so no bee stings for you.)

€350 - Hummus Maker 

Stop throwing away your organic waste and see it for what it is: green gold. With this compact compost  bin you can turn your organic waste into valuable fertilizer for your own urban garden. This way your plants stay happy and healthy. 

€500 - Planet Saver

As a big thank you for your generous gift, we will plant a tree in your name. So besides helping us greatly with Greening The Camps, you will also make the air in Jordan extra clean with atree that bears your name! 

€1000 - Green Hero

Thank you for this beautiful gesture of support. For this or any donations above €1000 we will personally contact you to find a suitable way to show our appreciation.

مكافأت التبرع :

 (النذر الطيب)

، سنقوم بإرسال الطاقة الإيجابية وتمنيات الخير لك، شكراً لاهتمامك لتكون جزءًا من هذا المشروع/

 (الطباخ الفلسطيني)

: دعمك ب-١٠ دولارات سيكون طريقة سهلا لك للحصول على بطاقة شكر على ظهرها وصفة طبخ لأحد الأطباق الفلسطينية التقليدية الشهية 

 (مزارع حضري)

 يمكنك أن تصبح مزارع حضري تزرع وتحصد انتاجك من الأعشاب الفلسطينية والتمتع بتجربة أطباق فلسطينية شهية حيث أننا سنقوم بإرسال بذور عضوية وعدة وصفات لأطباق فلسطينية مختلفة وشهية /

 (دعم للخضرة):

 لا يوجد طريقة أفضل لدعم المشروع من خلال إستعمال كيس قطني يحمل شعارنا تستطيع إستعماله خلال تسوقك

 (مربي نحل حضري)

 قم بجذب أصدقائك من النحل بعد استلامك لبيت نحل نرسله لك، سيقوم بيت النحل بجذب النحل ليساعدك على تلقيح نباتاتك ، لا تخف هذا البيت يجذب النحل الملقح وليس نحل المملكة، فلا تخف من اللدغ 

 (صانع الحمص )

 :سنقوم بارسال سلة إنتاج السماد لك، لتحول مخالفتك العضوية إلى سماد مفيد ومغذي لنباتاتك لتبقى صحية وسعيدة 

 (منقذ للكوكب)

 كشكر وتقدير منا لكرمك سنقوم بزراعة شجرة تحمل اسمك حيث أنك لن تساعد المشروع فقط بل أنك ستساعد في جعل الهواء الأردني أنقى

البطل الأخضر

 

.نشكركم جزيل الشكر على دعمكم، سنقوم بالتواصل معكم مباشرةً إذا كانت قيمة تبرعكم أكبر من 1000 يورو لنبدي إمتنانا 

 

Urban agriculture is the cultivation of plants and animals in urban environments. In essence, it aims to be integrated in and intertwined with urban social, economic and ecological structures, but it can also be a precious source of both physical and psychosocial benefits for urban residents. It has a direct impact on urban ecology, improving both biodiversity and health. Organic waste, non-organic waste and wastewater are deployed and upcycled as valuable resources. This in return creates a healthier living environment. It transforms the passive consumer into an active producer who becomes aware of the opaque and hard-to-discern food supply chain that is entrenched around the world. 

 ترعى الزراعة الحضرية في اساسها الحيوانات والنباتات كما أنها تعمل على دمج المجتمع الحضري بالبيئة والإقتصاد ، كما أنها تسطيع الرجوع بالمنفعة النفسية على هذا المجتمع،بحيث أنها تؤثر بشكل مباشر على البيئة الحضرية من خلال تحسين التنوع البيئي والصحة بشكل عام ، فإنها تحول المخالفات العضوية والمياه العادمة إلى مصادر مفيدة وبالمحصلة الوصول إلى حياه أكثر صحية في بيئة صحية وسليمة، كما أن الزراعة الحضرية تحول الناس من مستهلكين سلبين إلا أناس منتجين واعين بأليات إنتاج الطعام واستهلاكها بالشكل الصحيح

Urban populations have exploded in the last century, to the point that more than half of the world’s population resides in cities today. Generations are born and live solely in cities, severing the connection between nature and society. As a result, contemporary city dwellers have lost their relationship with the food supply. The distance between food production and consumption has resulted in the art of growing and harvesting healthy crops being lost. This vanished connection has an even more damaging impact on the climate and vulnerable ecosystems. Urban agriculture plays an essential role in changing this status quo for the better,  by creating an urban food system and propagating the creation of a circular economy where resources, produce and waste remain within the urban ecosystem. Whilst it minimizes contributors’ footprints in terms of transportation, food and water wastage, urban agriculture is about more than food alone; it is about sustainability, health and social justice. It is a reflection upon the scarcity of resources, upon our increasing disconnection with the environment and a bold experiment in tackling these issues whilst empowering communities.

تضخمت المجتمعات الحضرية في القرن الماضي بشكل كبير مما أدى إلا إنتقال 50 بالمئة من مجتمعات العالم للعيش في المدينة الحديثة وبالتالي توالت الأجيال وعاشت في المدينة لمدة طويلة مما أدى إلا فقدان علاقة المجتمعات الحديثة بالبيئة و علاقة هذه المدن بإنتاج الطعام العضوي الصحي وزادت الفجوة شيئاً فشيئاً لتمحو فنون الزراعة والحصاد بشكل تدريجي وبالتالي إستنزاف موارد البيئة وتخريبها . وتلعب الزراعة الحضرية دوراً كبيراً ومهماً في أعاده الحياه البيئية السليمة إلا مجراها فالزراعة الحضرية تبني من جديد دوائر إنتاجيية إقتصادية وإستهلاكية بيئية، تستطيع إنشاء نظام إقتصادي قادر على الإنتاج وإعادة التدوير داخل دائرة محكمة دون الحاجة إلا إستنزاف الموارد الإقتصادية المختلفة مثل المواصلات والمياه بشكل كبير فالزراعة الحضرية لا تهدف لإنتاج الطعام فقط بل أنها تعمل على استدامة حياه إجتماعية كاملة وصحية بالإضافة لأمن الموارد وتوفرها .

 

Agriculture is an important cultural tradition and heritage of the Palestinian refugee communities. The long running Israeli-Palestinian conflict has caused displaced communities to lose the connection with private food production and affordable organic food. The dense concrete fabric of the refugee camps lack the space and fertile earth for sustainable agriculture. This scarcity of green space in combination with a regional water shortage has caused a real and lasting disconnection between agriculture and a generation that has known only the camps. Rooftop gardens address this directly by creating a green oasis where a family or community can take charge of its own food provision, find rest and foster their connection with the natural world.

لعبت الزراعة دوراً كبيراً في الارث الحضاري الفلسطيني منذ قدم الزمان إلا أن الإحتلال الإسرائيلي حال دون إرتباط الفلسطينين بانتاج غذاهم بأنفسهم من خلال الزراعة بعد ارسالهم للمخيمات، أضف إلا ذلك أن النسيج البيئي بالمخيم يفتقر إلى المساحة الزراعية التي كان يتمتع بها الفلسطينين في بلادهم عداك عن مشكله شح المياه التي تعاني منها المنطقة بالأساس وبالتالي وللاسف أدى ذلك إلا خلق جيل فلسطيني غير متصل بالبيئة ، جيل جديد لا يعرف شيئاً إلا المخيم وبيئته الفقيرة، تعمل حدائق السطوح بشكل مباشر مع هذه المعضلة وتحاول علاجها من خلال خلق مساحة خضراء تسمح للعائلات بأخذ السيطرة على إنتاج طعامهم بأنفسهم وبالتالي الوصول إلى نوع من الإكتفاء الذاتي

Overall unemployment and the serious lack of self-esteem among women and youth in the refugee camps are pressing problems. Our project encourages engagement of women, youth and children in green and organic food production methods. The entire process is from start to finish designed with the families who own the rooftops. Improvements to food security, livelihood, creating a safe haven for women, youth and children and empowering people to explore and develop their talents and creativity are our ambitions,. As a result, one of our core principles is the involvement of the families in every step of designing and building the gardens. 

تلعب البطالة والفقر دوراً سلبياً في ثقة النساء والشباب بأنفسهم بشكل عام داخل المخيم إلا أن مشروعنا يعمل على تدعيم وتمكين هذه الفئات وأعطاهم الدعم النفسي من خلال تعزيز دورهم كعناصر منتجة ، ومن أهم اهدافنا في هذا المشروع هو تشجيع الأهالي بأن يقومو بتحسين أمنهم الغذائي لتحسين وضعهم المعيشي ، فعملية البناء لهذه الحدائق تعتمد بالكامل منذ البداية حتى النهاية على أراء الأهالي وابداعاتهم وتصاميمهم ، ستكون هذه الحدائق بمثابة جنة خضراء يستخدمها الأهالي ليستكشفو ابداعاتهم ومهاراتهم

 

The first garden that we built is located on the rooftop of Jadal, a cultural café in the heart of Amman. This project brings together like-minded people; ranging from volunteers who helped us to build the garden to farmers and carpenters with whom we collaborated to expand the network of organisations that raise awareness for environmental issues. After the official opening of the garden we received nothing but positive feedback and messages from volunteers who want to join us on our green journey. On top of that, many people were inspired after seeing our garden to green their own rooftops in Amman. This first garden has been an amazing experience for us and by building and planting everything ourselves we gathered a tremendous amount of knowledge and technical skills. This experience will help us succeed in taking the next step: building three rooftop gardens in Jerash camp. After seeing what we brought about in Amman by greening a small rooftop, we are motivated more than ever to continue our journey and green Jerash camp. 

جدل : قمنا ببناء أول حديقة سطوح في مركز جدل الثقافي الواقع في قلب عمان حيث ساعدنا المشروع على إستقطاب متطوعين يعملون بنفس نمط تفكيرنا ويأتون من خلفيات مختلفة، فمنهم من كان نجاراً ومهم من إمتلك خبرة في الزراعة والكثير الكثير اللذين إستخدمو مهاراتهم وخبرتهم للمساعدة في البناء والتوسع والعمل على زيادة الوعي حول البيئة ومشاكلها ، تلقينا الكثير من الثناء والمدح من قبل الذين ساعدونا بعد الإفتتاح الرسمي للحديقة في مركز جدل والهمنا الكثير من الناس بعد خوضنا هذه التجربة المميزة، فرأينا أن المهتمين أبدو رغبةً بالطوع والقيام ببناء حدائقهم ومشاريعهم التطوعية الخاصة كما أن هذه الخبرة ساعدتنا كثيراً على التعلم وتوير مهارتنا مما سيساعدنا في أخذ الخطوة القادمة في العمل في المخيم وبناء 3 حدائق في مخيم جرش

Risks & Challenges

An important obstacle that we are facing in the camp is water shortage. With only 60 cubic metres of renewable water resources available annually per capita, Jordan is among the most water-scarce nations in the world. To supply adequate amounts of water for drinking, sanitation, industry, and agriculture, the World Bank estimates an annual per capita threshold of 1,000 cubic meters. On top of that, Jerash governorate has the lowest average of water share per capita within Jordan, with only 71 liters per day. The country is already being confronted with the effects of climate change and its resources are expected to diminish even further. At the same time, Jordan’s population is continuing to increase and the country has received more than 655,000 refugees since the beginning of the Syrian crisis. Factors such as these have resulted in the systematic overuse of its water resources for many years. If the nature and the extent of water usage are not reversed soon, the water security of Jordan’s population will be at serious risk. We will solve this problem with at least two availables techniques: rainwater harvesting and the reuse of greywater. Since winter is the only season with rainfall, we will accompany rainwater harvesting with the reuse of greywater from washing machines, kitchen sinks and showers, to flush toilets and irrigate crops. These two solutions will ensure that we will have adequate water supplies throughout the year.              

يعتبر شح المياه في المنطقة عقبة كبيرة في طريق انجاح هذا المشروع فكمية 60 متر مكعب سنوياً تضع الأردن في مقدمة البلدان الفقيرة من ناحيه المياه، حسب إحصائيات البنك العالمي للمياه يعتبر معدل إستهلاك الفرد بالأردن للمياه حوالي الألف متر مكعب أضف إلا ذلك اقتطاعات الحكومة من كمية المياه المستهلكة بشكل عام وبشكل خاص في المخيم ليتدنى معدل الإستهلاك إلى 71 لتر فقط يومياً في المخيم، تواجه الأردن صعوبات الاحتباس الحراري ويتزايد عدد السكان بشكل مستمر وكبير بالإضافة إلى دخول الكثير من اللاجئين السورين (حوالي 655000 لاجئ تقريباً) منذ بداية الأزمة السورية مم أثر ذلك بشكل كبير على الخزينة المائية على مر عدة سنين مما يضع ضغوطات واخطار على المجتمع الأردني من ناحية توفر الماء إلا أننا قد قمنا بوضع حلول لهذه المشكلة من خلال طريقتين : حصاد مياه الأمطار وتكرير المياه العادمة .

Help us Grow!  

Spread the word by sharing this page with all your friends! Follow our story on social media. 

Like us on Facebook, follow us on Instagram and visit our website. Talk to us. We love hearing your ideas and feedback!

Creating environmental  awareness is crucial, so spread some green love and tell your friends about it! 

Yalla, Spread the love and help us build a brighter and greener future!

Thank You for your support! 

Team Greening The Camps
